text: 1.1.1 Meaning of the Failure Typically, a failure is defined as a condition in which a device (system) or component has lost its specified functionality. From a systems perspective, failure carries two key meanings: first, it refers to the mechanical system deviating from its normal function. The primary cause of this deviation lies in Chapter 1—Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Electromechanical Equipment. 3 Work conditions (including components) are abnormal, and these types of failures can be resolved by adjusting parameters or repairing the affected parts, allowing the system to return to normal operation. The second scenario is functional failure, where the system continuously deviates from its intended performance, with the degree of deviation steadily worsening—eventually rendering the equipment unable to perform its basic functions. Such situations are classified as failures. Typically, failed individual components can be replaced; however, if critical components fail, it often results in the complete loss of the machine’s functionality. The primary goal of failure analysis is to identify failure modes, uncover underlying failure mechanisms, and develop strategies to minimize failures, ultimately enhancing the reliability and effective utilization of electromechanical equipment. For the fault, the following points should be clarified:

(1) The defined object. This refers to a single machine, a system composed of several individual machines, or a specific component on the equipment. Different objects may experience varying failure conditions at the same time. For instance, on an automated production line, the failure of a single machine can be enough to disable the entire system; however, in a workshop with a clustered machine layout, the failure of one machine would not necessarily be linked to a breakdown affecting the entire workshop. (2) Time-to-failure. This refers to the fact that the probability of a failure increases as time goes on. In addition to using direct units like years, months, days, or hours, time can also be measured by the number of equipment operations, mileage, or cycles. For instance, vehicles typically use total miles driven as their unit of measurement, while gears might be measured by the number of load-bearing cycles they endure. (3) The specified conditions. These refer to the operational and maintenance conditions during equipment operation, the skill level of personnel, environmental factors, and more. Different conditions will lead to different types of failures. (4) The specified function. It depends on the particular issue at hand. For example, in a lathe operating in the same state, damage to the feed screw would be considered a malfunction when it comes to threading operations—but not when machining end faces, since the two scenarios require different functional capabilities from the lathe. (5) A certain degree of failure. This refers to assessing the severity of functional loss from a quantitative perspective. In production practice, to encompass all possible events, a broad definition of failure has been established: "A failure is an unqualified state." 1.1.2 Classification of Failures Mechanical and electrical equipment failures can be categorized from various perspectives, with each classification method highlighting a different aspect of the fault. The purpose of categorizing failures is to assess the severity of the incident, analyze its root causes, and ultimately enable more effective, tailored responses to address the specific types of malfunctions. By examining factors such as failure nature, underlying causes, and distinctive characteristics, faults can be grouped into the following categories. By fault nature (1) Intermittent failures. The equipment temporarily loses certain functions, with the faults often caused by external factors affecting the mechanical and electrical systems—such as operator error, climate changes, or inadequate environmental conditions. Once the external interference is removed or the equipment undergoes minor repairs and adjustments, its functionality typically resumes. (2) Permanent failure. Once this type of failure occurs, it can only be restored through manual repair; otherwise, the fault will persist indefinitely. Such failures are typically caused by damage to specific components. 2) By Severity of the Fault (1) Localized failure. A specific part of the机电 equipment is malfunctioning, causing that particular component to lose its functionality while other parts continue to operate as intended—essentially, a partial functional breakdown. (2) Systemic Failure. A failure that results in the complete loss of system functionality—though it may initially appear as a malfunction in a specific component, it ultimately prevents the device from performing its intended function altogether. Case Studies in Diagnostics and Maintenance of Mechatronic Systems. 4

3) By the rate at which the fault develops (1) Sudden failures. These failures occur unexpectedly and spontaneously, typically independent of the equipment’s usage time. They are often preceded by no obvious warning signs, making them difficult to predict even through early-stage testing or trials. Such failures usually result from a combination of inherent adverse factors within the process system and unpredictable external influences. (2) Gradual failure. These failures develop slowly and typically occur during the later stages of an electromechanical device's useful life. Their likelihood of occurrence is closely tied to the equipment's usage time, and they can often be predicted through early-stage testing or monitoring. Such failures usually result from the gradual progression of issues like corrosion, wear, fatigue, and material aging in the components. 4) By the cause of fault formation (1) Failures caused by operational or management errors, such as using机电 equipment under conditions that deviate from the original design specifications, leading to improper equipment usage. (2) Failures caused by inherent system factors. These typically arise from defects left over from system design or manufacturing—such as residual stresses or localized weak points—or from latent flaws within the materials themselves. Such failures are unpredictable and represent a major cause of sudden, unexpected breakdowns. (3) Natural failures. During the operational and maintenance period, mechanical and electrical equipment may experience failures caused by various external or internal natural factors—such as wear, fracture, corrosion, deformation, creep, aging, and other forms of damage that occur under normal conditions. 5) By the consequences caused by the failure (1) Critical Failure: A failure that endangers personal safety, results in injury or death, causes the scrapping of机电 equipment, or leads to significant financial losses. Examples include frame or body separation, wheel detachment, and complete engine assembly failure. (2) Minor faults. These are issues that affect the normal operation of mechanical and electrical equipment but can be resolved within a relatively short time. Examples include broken drive belts, damaged control handles, cracks or loose welds in sheet metal components, faulty electrical switches, minor leaks, and loose general fasteners. 6) By the period when the fault occurred (1) Early-stage failures. These faults may arise from design, manufacturing, or material defects and typically become apparent shortly after the equipment is first put into operation. Alternatively, certain components—such as gear pairs in gearboxes or other friction-based assemblies—often require an initial "running-in" period before their performance gradually improves. Once these early-stage issues are identified, addressed, and optimized, the failure rate tends to decline over time. (2) Failure during the useful life. This refers to failures that occur within a product's effective lifespan, caused by unpredictable, random factors related to both external loads (such as operational conditions) and intrinsic system characteristics (including internal factors like component failures or structural damage). Since equipment typically operates in this condition for most of its lifetime, the failure rate during this period remains relatively constant. Therefore, monitoring and diagnosing failures during this phase is critically important. (3) Late-stage failures (dissipation-phase failures). These typically occur during the latter part of a device's lifespan, often after the equipment has been in use for an extended period—or even beyond its intended service life. Such failures arise due to gradual wear, fatigue, and aging of the equipment's components, leading to a decline in system functionality. Ultimately, this can result in sudden, hazardous, and potentially widespread system breakdowns. During this phase, the failure rate of the equipment tends to increase steadily. To prevent accidents, it’s crucial to monitor and diagnose the system regularly, promptly replacing any identified failing components before they cause a major incident. As illustrated by the classification of these failures, mechanical and electrical equipment malfunctions are often interconnected and can evolve over time—shifting from one type of failure to another. Ultimately, every type of machinery and equipment failure will manifest as a specific issue, underscoring the importance of comprehensive diagnostic and maintenance strategies. 5

The material condition and characteristics. 1.1.3 Characteristics of the Failure Diversity Various pieces of equipment not only differ in structure and process parameters, but also vary in their manufacturing, installation processes, and operating environments—leading to a wide range of potential failures during operation. Hierarchical Structure Once a device exhibits a certain failure symptom, it becomes necessary to investigate the root cause of the malfunction. However, some failure causes are often deeply rooted—meaning that a higher-level failure stems from a lower-level one, creating a hierarchical pattern. Multifactorial and Correlation The components of the equipment—and even individual devices—are interconnected through mechanical structures or material transfer. If one component or device fails, it can trigger malfunctions in other components or devices as well, highlighting the multifactorial and interconnected nature of failures. Therefore, when diagnosing the root cause of a malfunction, it’s essential to thoroughly consider all relevant factors involved. Delayed Response During operation, equipment components are continuously subjected to factors such as impact, stress, friction, wear, and corrosion, leading to vibrations, displacements, deformations, fatigue, and crack propagation. These processes gradually degrade the equipment's condition—until, at a certain point, the degradation becomes severe enough to result in mechanical malfunctions or even complete loss of functionality. The time-lag inherent in this failure progression underscores the importance of identifying potential issues early on and implementing preventive measures promptly, thereby minimizing the damage that could arise when a failure ultimately occurs. Uncertainty (Ambiguity) A single fault phenomenon can arise from multiple underlying causes; conversely, a single cause may manifest in various fault symptoms. The occurrence of faults, their specific manifestations, quantitative descriptions, and detection analyses all involve inherent uncertainties, thereby complicating the tasks of fault diagnosis and repair. Restorative
Most failures are repairable.

1.1.4 Management of Failures Equipment failure management is a critical component of overall equipment maintenance. Effectively leveraging the fault information generated during equipment operation—by analyzing data from multiple perspectives and predicting potential failures—and subsequently implementing proactive measures to minimize equipment-related losses are essential for enhancing overall equipment management practices. Establishing a procedure for managing enterprise equipment failures is the first step in building an accident early-warning mechanism, and correctly developing such a procedure is of great significance. To effectively manage equipment failures, it’s essential to thoroughly understand the root causes of breakdowns, systematically collect data and information on common and typical failures, conduct in-depth failure analyses, emphasize research into failure patterns and mechanisms, and strengthen routine maintenance, inspections, and preventive repairs. The purpose of equipment failure management is to monitor and diagnose equipment conditions before failures occur, enabling operators to identify any signs of degradation. This proactive approach aims to detect early warning indicators and potential risks, allowing for timely preventive maintenance to effectively control the occurrence of failures. After a failure does happen, the process involves promptly analyzing the root cause, developing targeted solutions, and implementing measures to either resolve the issue or improve the equipment—ultimately preventing future occurrences. Case Study Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechatronic Systems

6 The procedure for equipment failure management is outlined below. (1) Conduct thorough education and awareness campaigns to ensure that operators and maintenance personnel voluntarily comply with relevant rules and regulations regarding operation, maintenance, inspection, etc., properly use and carefully maintain equipment, and diligently record, compile statistics, and analyze any equipment malfunctions. (2) Based on the company’s actual production conditions, equipment status, and specific features, determine the key areas for equipment failure management. (3) Use monitoring instruments and diagnostic techniques to systematically monitor critical equipment, enabling timely detection of fault indicators and deterioration. Information on equipment condition. Typically, equipment can undergo daily inspections, routine patrols, and periodic checks (including precision assessments), as well as integrity assessments—using human senses and common diagnostic tools—to closely monitor the technical status and any unusual signs in components, mechanisms, and areas prone to failure. At the same time, inspection standards should be established to clearly define the boundaries between normal operation, abnormalities, and equipment failures. (4) To quickly locate the fault location and its cause, in addition to providing training to ensure that maintenance and operational staff acquire a solid understanding of electrical and hydraulic technologies, it is also essential to compile common equipment failure symptoms, analysis procedures, and troubleshooting methods into a fault-finding logic flowchart. This will enable operators to swiftly identify the source and root cause of any malfunction after it occurs, allowing for timely diagnosis, repair, and restoration of equipment functionality. (5) Improve the fault recording system. Fault records serve as the foundational data for effective fault management and also provide the original basis for conducting fault analysis and troubleshooting. Records must be complete and accurate. After on-site inspections and fault repairs, maintenance personnel should follow the "Equipment Carefully complete the  "Equipment Failure Repair Form " and submit monthly statistical analyses to the equipment management department. (6) Conduct timely statistics and analysis of equipment failures. In addition to monitoring failur e situations on a daily basis, staff members should compile  "Failure Repair Forms " and maintenance records on a monthly basis. By systematically collecting, organizing, and analyzing failure data, it’s possible to calculate the failure frequency and mean time b etween failures for each type of equipment. Furthermore, this process allows for an in-depth analysis of individual equipment failure trends and identifies key root causes, helping  to pinpoint recurring patterns. Armed with this insight, teams can prioritize their response strategies effectively. Finally, the compiled and analyzed failure information should  be shared back with the planning department, enabling them to schedule preventive maintenance or implement improvement measures. This data can also serve as a valuable reference fo r adjusting the intervals, content, and standards of routine inspections. (7) Implement different countermeasures based on the nature of the failure, the type of fault, and the spe cific characteristics of the equipment. For newly acquired equipment, strengthen management during the initial phase of use—carefully monitor and document the equipment’s precision , performance, and any emerging defects from the outset. During operation, emphasize routine maintenance, regular patrol inspections, and periodic checks to promptly identify early  warning signs and take appropriate adjustment or troubleshooting actions. For critical equipment, conduct condition monitoring and diagnostics. Establish a flexible and responsive  maintenance team equipped with advanced technical expertise, employing rapid repair techniques such as component-by-component fixes or group-based replacements. Ensure timely avai lability of high-quality spare parts, leverage production downtime for equipment overhauls, and apply measures like retrofitting or replacing components when wear patterns have bee n thoroughly understood. (8) Carry out routine maintenance tasks effectively to control equipment failures. Utilize status information and early warning signs of potential issues g athered during daily rounds by regional maintenance workers, as well as scheduled equipment condition checks, along with relevant records and analysis data. Based on the specific c haracteristics of each type of equipment and the general defects already identified, the workshop’s equipment mechanic (technician) or maintenance team leader should promptly sched ule routine repairs—ideally during production downtime or weekend slots—to proactively address problems before they escalate, thereby minimizing breakdowns. For certain failure ind icators or hidden risks that exceed the scope of routine maintenance, these should be reported back to the planning department for scheduling dedicated, planned maintenance activit ies instead. (9) Establish a rational fault information management flowchart.

1.1.5 Key Factors Influencing Failure Generation The more complex the mechanical and electrical equipment, the more diverse the potential causes of failure. The main factors influencing these failures include the following aspects. 1) Design Planning In the design planning phase, accurate estimates of the equipment's future operating conditions are essential, and potential variations should be thoroughly considered. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 7 Consideration: Imperfect design solutions and inadequate review of design drawings and technical documents are major causes of failures. 2) Material Selection In design, manufacturing, and maintenance, it is essential to correctly select materials based on the nature and characteristics of the part’s function. Improper material selection, failure to meet specified material standards, or the use of inappropriate substitutes are major causes of phenomena such as wear, corrosion, excessive deformation, fatigue, cracking, and aging. Additionally, during manufacturing and repair processes, many materials undergo various fabrication steps, including casting, forging, welding, and heat treatment. Throughout these processes, the microstructure and mechanical/physical properties of the materials often undergo significant changes—among which the effects of heating and cooling are particularly critical. 3) Manufacturing Quality Errors exist in every step of the manufacturing process. The variability in process conditions and material properties inevitably leads to differences among parts during casting, Stress concentrations, local defects, and microscopic cracks—such as those arising during forging, welding, heat treatment, and machining—are common issues. These flaws are often overlooked during process inspections. As a result, the manufacturing quality of parts frequently fails to meet requirements, which is a major reason behind the short lifespan of mechanical equipment. 4) Assembly Quality First, there must be proper fit requirements. The tolerance limits for the clearance include the initial clearance that remains after assembly and running-in. If the initial clearance is too large, the effective service life will be shortened. Additionally, the positional accuracy between individual components during assembly is critical—failure to meet these specifications can lead to additional stresses, uneven wear, and ultimately accelerate component failure. 5) Proper Maintenance

Following the principles of process rationality, cost-effectiveness, and production feasibility, carry out repairs in a sensible manner to ensure high-quality outcomes. Most importantly and critically, it’s essential to carefully select and apply the appropriate repair techniques, paying close attention to preparatory steps before restoration and adhering strictly to established procedures throughout the repair process. Operation procedures, as well as post-repair handling tasks.

6) Use correctly Under normal operating conditions, mechanical equipment follows its own failure patterns; however, when operating conditions change, these failure patterns also shift accordingly. The primary operating conditions include the following: (1) Load. The primary causes of wear and fatigue failure in mechanical equipment are the wear of components and their fatigue-induced damage. Under specified operating conditions, the rate of component wear over a given period is directly proportional to the magnitude of the load applied. Meanwhile, fatigue damage to components occurs only under certain types of cyclic loading and intensifies as the load increases. Thus, both wear and fatigue are functions of the applied load. Exceeding the design-rated load levels can lead to severe failure, which is unacceptable. (2) Environment. The environment includes the effects of climate, corrosive media, and other harmful substances, as well as the condition of the working object itself. Increased temperatures accelerate wear and corrosion, while excessively high humidity and corrosive agents present in the air can lead to both corrosion and corrosive wear. Additionally, excessive dust levels in the air and harsh operating conditions often contribute to equipment failures. However, the environment is an objective factor, and in certain situations, measures can be taken manually to improve it. (3) Maintenance and Operation. Establishing a sound maintenance system and strictly adhering to technical maintenance guidelines and operational procedures are crucial for ensuring the reliable performance of mechanical equipment and extending its service life. Additionally, it is essential to provide training for personnel to enhance their skills and expertise.

1.2 Basics of Equipment Maintenance 1.2.1 Maintenance Method The method of equipment maintenance carries the meaning of a maintenance strategy. Modern equipment management emphasizes applying different maintenance approaches to various types of equipment, underscoring that equipment repair should align with the objective principles governing the physical lifecycle of machinery and materials. This approach ensures production continuity while optimizing the efficient use of maintenance resources, ultimately achieving the most cost-effective outcome over the equipment's entire lifespan. Commonly used maintenance methods for electromechanical equipment include the following: Reactive Maintenance Post-failure maintenance, also known as breakdown maintenance, damage repair, or unplanned maintenance, refers to repairs carried out after mechanical and electrical equipment has malfunctioned—essentially, "if it breaks, we fix it." For certain critical equipment, post-failure maintenance should be minimized whenever possible; however, for devices that have minimal impact on production or are backed up by redundant units, opting for post-failure maintenance is often the most cost-effective approach. Preventive Maintenance Maintenance performed before mechanical and electrical equipment fails is called preventive maintenance. Its main benefits include reducing unexpected equipment failures, ensuring continuous production, integrating equipment upkeep and repair tasks into a structured plan—thereby minimizing unplanned disruptions in production—and ultimately improving equipment utilization, lowering maintenance costs, and extending the equipment's natural lifespan. Preventive maintenance is categorized into two basic forms: Regular maintenance Regular maintenance is also known as planned maintenance or time-based preventive maintenance. It involves carrying out preventive maintenance activities at predetermined intervals and follows a cyclical pattern. This type of maintenance is based on the wear patterns of components, with specific guidelines for setting maintenance intervals, defining maintenance categories, outlining maintenance tasks, and estimating the associated workload. However, this approach to maintenance can lead to certain challenges: First, when equipment is still in good technical condition and fully capable of continuing operation, it may undergo major over-maintenance simply because the scheduled interval has arrived—resulting in unnecessary repairs. Second, if a machine’s technical condition has already deteriorated to the point where it can no longer meet production requirements, but the prescribed maintenance interval hasn’t yet been reached, no repair plan will be implemented, leading to under-maintenance. This method is particularly well-suited for process-oriented production equipment or power systems where the wear patterns are well understood, and operations are stable and contin uous—such as large-scale assembly line equipment or key machinery operating on automated production lines. Currently, China primarily implements two main types of equipment mainten ance systems: the Planned Preventive Maintenance System and the Planned Warranty System. (1) Planned Preventive Maintenance System (referred to as Planned Pre-Maintenance). This sy stem involves maintaining, inspecting, and repairing equipment according to its wear patterns, adhering to predetermined maintenance cycles and procedures, to ensure that the equip ment consistently remains in optimal technical condition. Its key features are outlined below. ① Perform daily cleaning, inspection, lubrication, tightening, and adjustments on equ ipment as required to minimize wear and ensure proper operation. ② Conduct regular inspections and adjustments of the equipment's operational status and wear levels according to th e prescribed schedule, ensuring that potential issues are promptly addressed. This allows you to monitor changes in the equipment's technical condition and adequately prepare the n ecessary resources for scheduled maintenance. ③ Conduct preventive maintenance on equipment in a planned and prepared manner. (2) The Planned Maintenance System (also known as the  Maintenance and Repair System) is a equipment maintenance approach that combines routine upkeep with scheduled inspections and repairs. Its key features are outlined below. ① Based  on the equipment's characteristics and condition, different maintenance categories and intervals are specified according to operational hours (such as production output and mileag e).

② Based on maintenance practices, establish different repair categories and intervals for the equipment. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Di agnosis and Maintenance 9 ③ When the equipment reaches its specified operational period, it must undergo strict inspection, maintenance, and scheduled repairs—as required—regardles s of its technical condition or the priority of the production tasks.

2) Condition Monitoring and Maintenance This is a preventive maintenance approach based on the equipment's tec hnical condition, carried out precisely when needed. It relies on condition monitoring and advanced diagnostic techniques to track the gradual deterioration of equipment over time.  By leveraging highly predictive insights, this method allows for timely scheduling of preventive maintenance activities, which is why it’s also referred to as  "predictive maintenance. " At its core, this maintenance strategy integrates comprehensive data from various sources—such as inspections, routine upkeep, operational use, and repair activities—especially insights gained from diagnostics and monitoring. Through rigorous statistical analysis, it accurately assesses the extent of equipment degradation, identifies specific areas where failures may occur (or are likely to occur), and predicts trends in the equipment’s overall technical condition. Armed with this information, operators can then determine the most appropriate type of maintenance intervention. By doing so, organizations gain full control over maintenance activities, ensuring thorough preparation before repairs begin. Moreover, this approach enables seamless coordination with production schedules, maximizing equipment utilization while simultaneously extending the lifespan of critical components. However, this method does come with some drawbacks: it tends to be more expensive and requires sophisticated diagnostic capabilities. Additionally, it demands highly skilled technicians who can interpret complex data and make informed decisions. This approach is particularly well-suited for critical, high-value equipment, key assets on production lines, machinery that cannot be easily disassembled for inspection (such as precision machine tools), and systems whose failure could lead to significant environmental or public health concerns.

3. Reliability Maintenance Also known as Reliability-Centered Maintenance (RCM), this approach emerged in the U.S. civil aviation industry during the 1960s and is now widely implemented in industries with particularly high demands for equipment operational reliability, such as the nuclear and military sectors. While the time it takes for a potential failure in operating equipment to evolve into a functional failure can vary, all failure patterns eventually reveal detectable trends through systematic monitoring. This technique leverages these predictable patterns to implement proactive maintenance measures—making it a reliability-focused maintenance strategy aimed at enhancing equipment dependability. Rooted in reliability theory, RCM involves detailed analysis and experimentation of factors influencing system reliability, followed by the application of logical decision-making processes. This approach enables the scientific development of tailored maintenance plans, the optimal selection of repair methods, and the precise determination of equipment lifespan—all designed to maintain and restore the inherent reliability of assets while minimizing costs. Reliability-based maintenance is advancing equipment repair work toward greater scientific rigor and modernization, making it worthy of further attention and research. 4. Quality Maintenance This is an equipment maintenance procedure developed with a focus on ensuring product quality, aiming to keep all critical quality characteristics of product components and parts in optimal condition. To achieve this goal, the method manages key factors influencing quality—such as people, machines, and materials—and places particular emphasis on the relationship between equipment performance and product quality. It employs tools from Total Quality Management, including graphical techniques like Pareto charts, as well as statistical analysis methods. By closely monitoring product quality conditions, the process identifies problematic production steps, pinpointing faulty equipment areas and their root causes, and then systematically categorizes and organizes this information. Based on the severity of each issue, critical problems are prioritized, analyzed one by one, and targeted recovery measures are formulated. For chronic quality issues where the root cause remains unclear, PM analysis (Process-Machine Phenomenon Analysis) is utilized to investigate further. Perform a root cause analysis to identify the reasons and solutions, and establish a management system to prevent future failures.

5. Improve Maintenance Improvement maintenance, also known as corrective maintenance, refers to a type of repair that enhances the technical performance of mechanical and electrical equipment to prevent recurring failures. It involves integrating maintenance activities with technological upgrades, ensuring that after repairs, key aspects such as precision, performance, and efficiency of the equipment are improved. Rate. During operation, mechanical and electrical equipment often has certain weak links, which necessitates technical improvements and structural modifications to specific devices or components. These enhancements aim to boost reliability and elevate the overall technological level of the equipment, ultimately leading to better economic outcomes. A key feature of improvement-based maintenance is its integrated approach, frequently combined with major overhauls and targeted repairs in actual production settings. When implementing such improvement maintenance, it’s essential to systematically address and refine the mechanisms of the equipment, as well as enhance the diagnostic and repair capabilities of electromechanical systems—based on thorough inspection and analysis of component failures. 10

Material details, etc. 6. Maintenance-Free Design Maintenance-free design is the ideal goal for equipment maintenance—it refers to implementing improvement measures during the design phase of new machinery and electrical equipment to address common failures encountered during maintenance, aiming to minimize maintenance efforts or even eliminate the need for repairs altogether. 1.2.2 Maintenance Method Selection The purpose of maintenance is to ensure the reliable operation of equipment—specifically, to guarantee the dependable fulfillment of its intended use—and, at the same time, minimize maintenance costs. Therefore, the fundamental requirements for maintenance decisions are: ① Reliability must not fall below the permissible minimum value [R], meaning that ()[] R ≥ R(t); ② Maintenance costs (KI) must be kept as low as possible—or, alternatively, must not exceed a predetermined maintenance cost limit (KImin), i.e., K ≤ KImin. To optimize maintenance decisions, the first step should be to choose an appropriate maintenance approach. The six maintenance methods mentioned above each have a specific scope of applicability; however, their effectiveness can vary depending on how appropriately they are applied. To maximize equipment efficiency, minimize downtime-related losses, and reduce maintenance costs, it’s essential to select the most suitable approach based on the characteristics of mechatronic systems and the conditions under which they are used. Looking ahead, the trend in maintenance practices is shifting from routine preventive maintenance toward planned, periodic inspections—and then, based on inspection findings, scheduling timely condition-based repairs. As the technological sophistication of factory equipment continues to rise, with increasingly complex system designs and broader adoption of mechatronic solutions, production activities are becoming more reliant on equipment performance and reliability. Consequently, the traditional static approach to maintenance management is evolving into a more dynamic model, gradually moving toward advanced strategies such as reliability-centered maintenance and quality-focused repair practices. Mechatronic equipment comes in a wide variety of types and is widely applied, making it essential to select one or a combination of maintenance methods tailored to the specific situation. When choosing a maintenance approach for mechatronic systems, reliability typically becomes the primary focus. For critical components, implementing condition-based monitoring allows for timely preventive measures. Meanwhile, for equipment at quality control points, it’s crucial to closely track changes in product quality during the manufacturing process and promptly address any detected anomalies through quality repairs. Additionally, it’s important to equip teams with personnel who are well-versed in microelectronics technology, providing them with supervision and guidance while fostering the development of skilled, integrated mechatronics technicians. Regular inspections and logical fault analysis should be conducted on CNC and other mechatronic systems, and any failed components identified must be promptly replaced and properly adjusted to ensure optimal performance. 1.2.3 Maintenance System Maintenance work is not only a technical task but also a managerial one. A maintenance system refers to a set of guidelines established under specific maintenance theories and principles, encompassing elements such as maintenance plans, categories, methods, timing, scope, levels, organizational structures, and performance evaluation metrics. Implementing a rational maintenance system helps optimize the allocation of human, material, and financial resources, enabling timely preparation before maintenance tasks, ensuring repairs are carried out appropriately, meeting operational requirements, enhancing the technical condition, reliability, and service life of机电 equipment, reducing downtime, and minimizing maintenance costs and production losses due to equipment shutdowns. Meanwhile, maintenance systems are continuously evolving and improving—currently, the main approaches include the following: Planned Preventive Maintenance System It is based on a thorough understanding of the wear and failure patterns of mechanical and electrical equipment, applying the principle of pre vention being better than cure—and addressing potential issues before they escalate—by systematically organizing maintenance and repairs according to the rate of wear and expected  service life of each component. This approach helps prevent premature wear, compensates for natural degradation, minimizes or avoids failures altogether, extends equipment lifespan , and ultimately saves time spent on repairs, thereby enhancing operational efficiency and boosting economic returns. The practical implementation of planned preventive maintenance  can be summarized as  "regular inspections, timely upkeep, and scheduled repairs, " making it particularly suitable for Chapter 1 of this guide: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment. 11 Macro-level management. I mplementing a planned preventive maintenance system requires the following conditions: ① Determining the maintenance intervals for assemblies and key components through statistical analysis, measurements, and experimental studies, and rationally categorizing mainten ance tasks;
② Establishing a set of corresponding technical standards for maintenance teams;

③ Having well-equipped maintenance facilities organized according to functional divisions and strategically located for optimal efficiency. The main drawback of the planned preven tive maintenance system is its poor cost-effectiveness. With fixed maintenance cycles and scopes, it often leads to unnecessary repairs of certain components—what’s known as over-m aintenance. During the maintenance process, repairs are categorized into several levels and types based on the depth and breadth of the work required, including major overhauls, mi d-level repairs, minor repairs, item-specific repairs, retrofits, and unplanned maintenance tasks—all determined by the scale and nature of the repair workload. (1) Overhaul: A com prehensive or fundamental restoration of the functionality of mechanical and electrical equipment, typically carried out by specialized maintenance teams within factories and mines —or at repair centers established in regions with a high concentration of industrial facilities. During an overhaul, the equipment is either fully or extensively disassembled, with  a focus on repairing critical components, replacing or refurbishing parts that have lost their function or are on the verge of doing so. After the repairs, the equipment’s precisi on is restored to nearly its original factory specifications, while also receiving a fresh cosmetic overhaul to enhance its appearance. (2) Intermediate Overhaul. This is a level o f maintenance that falls between major and minor overhauls, serving as a balanced approach to upkeep. (3) Minor Repair. This involves replacing or repairing components that have si gnificantly worn out or are nearing failure within the maintenance interval, without addressing any underlying structural issues. It is a troubleshooting-based repair aimed at rest oring functionality. The three levels—major overhaul, mid-term repair, and minor repair—objectively reflect the chronological progression of机电 equipment, making them ideally suited  for implementing time-based planned preventive maintenance, a practice widely adopted by most organizations. However, these levels still require complementary repair tiers to addr ess unforeseen maintenance needs effectively. (4) Item-based maintenance. Based on condition monitoring of mechanical and electrical equipment, this involves proactively planning r epairs specifically for components or technical items that are about to fail. Item-based maintenance is conducted between major, medium, and minor overhauls—it’s a non-periodic, pl anned maintenance level that doesn’t follow a fixed cycle. (5) Retrofitting. This involves making localized modifications to existing mechanical and electrical equipment using new  technologies, materials, structures, and processes, with the goal of enhancing its precision, functionality, productivity, and reliability. Such repairs are classified as improveme nt-oriented, and the extent of the work required depends on how well the original equipment’s design accommodates the retrofitting process—as well as on the specific level of perfo rmance enhancement desired for the equipment. Retrofitting is also referred to as modernization or upgrading. (6) Unscheduled Maintenance. This is a level of maintenance required f or mechanical and electrical equipment due to sudden breakdowns and accidents. The fewer the number and scope of unscheduled maintenance activities, the higher the level of managem ent.

Condition-Based Maintenance System It is based on reliability theory, condition monitoring, and fault diagnosis, determining the timing and scope of maintenance based on actual technical condition assessments of mechanical and electrical equipment. Given that many complex mechanical and electrical systems typically experience only early or occasional failures—without a wear-out phase—regular, scheduled maintenance often proves ineffective against such faults. Moreover, in modern mechanical and electrical systems, only a small number of component failures pose safety risks; thus, maintenance tasks should be tailored specifically to the functional requirements of each part, considering potential functional failures, their root causes, and their consequences. This maintenance approach is characterized by flexible decision-making regarding maintenance cycles, procedures, and scopes—adapting dynamically to the actual conditions of the equipment. It shifts the focus of maintenance activities from routine repairs and upkeep to proactive inspections, underpinned by the implementation of a systematic inspection system. Not only does this inspection process provide critical information for determining optimal maintenance timing and scope, but it also allows certain maintenance tasks to be carried out incrementally and efficiently. By conducting daily, periodic, and precision inspections of mechanical and electrical equipment, combined with thorough analysis of condition-monitoring and fault-diagnosis data, operators can accurately assess the degree of degradation and proactively address issues before they escalate into full-blown failures. This approach ensures that equipment remains reliably operational while maximizing the lifespan of its components—making it far more efficient and cost-effective than traditional planned preventive maintenance strategies. To successfully implement condition-based maintenance, several prerequisites must be met: robust reliability testing data and comprehensive documentation are essential for effectively managing the mechanical and electrical systems. 12 As a basis for determining equipment condition; it requires close collaboration between the design, manufacturing, and maintenance departments to develop a comprehensive maintenance plan for mechanical and electrical equipment, along with access to necessary testing methods and standards. 3. Targeted Maintenance System This maintenance system is based on comprehensive management principles and reliability-centered maintenance thinking, adopting a practical approach tailored to the specific characteristics of mechanical and electrical equipment—such as their design, performance, and operating conditions. Building upon the implementation of a condition-based inspection system, it strategically incorporates various maintenance methods, including predictive maintenance, preventive maintenance, and corrective maintenance. By leveraging advanced decision-making tools, computer technologies, as well as state monitoring and fault diagnosis techniques, the system ensures that maintenance activities are conducted in a scientifically sound manner. Ultimately, this approach aims to minimize the total lifecycle costs of equipment while maximizing overall operational efficiency and profitability. The characteristics of the targeted maintenance system are as follows: (1) It adopts and refines the classification management approach, strengthening maintenance management for key mechanical and electrical equipment as well as critical areas. Moreov er, it implements tailored maintenance strategies based on the specific characteristics and current condition of each asset, maximizing their respective suitability and effectivene ss to achieve optimal maintenance outcomes. (2) Among various maintenance approaches, condition monitoring and predictive maintenance should be promoted as the primary methods. Imp lement a systematic inspection system that embodies reliability-centered thinking, focusing maintenance efforts on routine upkeep while striving for targeted, proactive interventio ns whenever possible. (3) Emphasize the role of information, leverage computer technology for dynamic management, and make timely decisions to ensure that maintenance efforts are t ruly targeted and effective. The content of the targeted maintenance system includes: ① implementing a periodic inspection system, categorizing mechanical and electrical equipment,  and applying various maintenance methods in a targeted manner; ② enhancing planned preventive maintenance by adopting maintenance type decisions for equipment equipped with condit ion-monitoring systems, allowing for tailored corrective or major overhauls; ③ establishing a set of maintenance and inspection standards, along with standardized work-hour quotas;  ④ introducing computer-aided dynamic management, including decision-support systems for all relevant processes. 4. Operation and Maintenance System This is a standardized requirem ent for personnel behavior, serving as an essential software engineering practice in机电 equipment management, and it primarily consists of five disciplines and four key requirements . Five disciplines: ① Implement operator-specific machine assignments; ② Maintain cleanliness of mechanical and electrical equipment, ensuring proper lubrication and maintenance; ③ Follow safety operating procedures and the shift handover system; ④ Properly manage tools and accessories; ⑤ Immediately stop and inspect the machine upon detecting any malfunction. Four requirements: ① Neatness; ② Cleanliness; ③ Lubrication; ④ Safety.

1.2.4 Use of Mechanical and Elect rical Equipment During operation, equipment's technical condition changes—and its performance gradually declines—due to various forces acting upon it, as well as factors such as en vironmental conditions, usage methods, operational guidelines, and the duration of use. To effectively manage these changes in technical condition and slow down the decline in equi pment performance, the most critical measure is to ensure the equipment is used properly and correctly. Maintenance of mechanical and electrical equipment is a crucial method for i mproving utilization and ensuring its functionality—it consists of two forms: daily maintenance and periodic maintenance. Daily maintenance is primarily carried out by operators of  mechanical and electrical equipment—conducting pre-shift inspections and post-shift cleaning to ensure that the equipment remains in optimal technical condition. Regular maintenan ce, also known as Level 1 care, is carried out by operators with assistance from maintenance personnel. It’s similar to minor repairs and is covered in Chapter 1 of the  "Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance. " 13

It varies depending on the type of mechanical and electrical equipment. The content includes dismantling and inspecting maintenance and critical areas; cleaning and clearing o il lines and lubrication systems; adjusting and checking clearances in various components; tightening all parts and components; and maintaining and repairing electrical elements, a mong other tasks. Here are a few key points to keep in mind when using机电 equipment.

Economically and rationally equip various types of equipment Enterprises must equip themselves with a diverse range of equipment in specific proportions, tailored to their process and technical requirements. Additionally, as businesses grow and expand—both in terms of product variety and output volume—process technologies inevitably evolve as well. Therefore, it is essential to promptly adjust the proportional relationships among equipment to ensure they align seamlessly with the materials being processed and the production tasks at hand. Create a favorable working environment for the equipment The working environment of machinery and equipment significantly impacts their precision and performance—especially for high-precision devices, where temperature plays a crucial role. Environmental factors such as dust, vibration, and corrosion require strict control, and it’s also essential to create optimal conditions for equipment with standard precision. Generally, direct sunlight and other forms of thermal radiation should be avoided, as should excessively humid environments, areas with high dust levels, or locations exposed to corrosive gases. Additionally, the equipment should be kept away from devices that generate significant vibrations. 3. Reliable Power Supply Assurance To avoid significant power fluctuations (exceeding ±10%) and potential transient interference signals, precision equipment typically relies on dedicated power lines—such as a separate circuit routed directly from the low-voltage distribution room—or incorporates additional voltage-stabilizing devices. Both of these measures can significantly reduce electrical interference. 4. Properly Manage Equipment Workload

Based on the performance, structure, and technical features of various equipment, appropriately schedule production tasks and workloads to maximize equipment utilization and avoid situations like "using large machines for minor tasks or coarse machinery for precision work."

5. Not suitable for long-term storage After purchasing the equipment, make sure to utilize it fully—especially during its first year of operation. This will help identify any weak points that are prone to failure early  on, allowing issues to be addressed promptly within the warranty period. During the machining process, minimize frequent starts and stops of the machine spindle to reduce wear on  components like clutches and gears. Even when no machining tasks are scheduled, ensure the equipment remains powered on regularly—ideally, running it once or twice a week for about  an hour each time under no-load conditions. This practice leverages the heat generated by the equipment itself to lower humidity levels inside, preventing moisture buildup that co uld damage electronic components. Can promptly detect battery low-level alarms, preventing loss of device parameters.

6. Develop effective operating procedures, establish a sound e quipment usage accountability system, and strictly adhere to them during operation. Establishing and adhering to operating procedures is one of the key measures to ensure the safe  operation of equipment. Leaders at all levels within the enterprise, as well as equipment management departments, production team leaders, and production workers, all bear correspo nding responsibilities in ensuring the proper use of equipment. Practical experience has shown that many equipment failures can be significantly reduced simply by following establi shed operating procedures. 7. Pre-employment Training for Operators Operators must be thoroughly familiar with and proficient in the equipment’s performance, structure, processing  capabilities, and maintenance procedures. New operators are required to undergo a technical assessment before operating the machine; only those who pass can independently perform s etup tasks. For precision, complex, or critical production equipment, designated operators with specialized expertise should be assigned—adhering to the principle of  "designated personnel for specific machines, operating only with proper certification. " Additionally, employees should receive ongoing education and training on the proper use and care of equipment. The level of care operators demonstrate toward machinery directly i mpacts the equipment’s lifespan and operational efficiency. Therefore, companies must regularly provide employees with both ideological guidance and technical training, equipping t hem with the skills needed to diagnose and troubleshoot mechanical and electrical system failures effectively. 14

Cultivate a culture and habit of consciously caring for equipment,  ensuring it remains regularly clean, safe, and in optimal technical condition. 1.2.5 Maintenance and保养 of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment 1) Principles of Operation and Maintenance Procedures Mechanical and electrical equipment maintenance refers to the tasks performed to eliminate inevitable abnormal technical conditions that arise during operation (such as loose parts , dry friction, or unusual noises). Overall, maintaining mechanical and electrical equipment requires meeting four fundamental criteria: neatness, cleanliness, lubrication, and saf ety. Developing clear equipment operation and maintenance procedures is a crucial step in ensuring that all subsequent operations are carried out systematically and efficiently. Th e principles for creating these operational and maintenance guidelines are outlined below. (1) General guidelines should list precautions according to the equipment operation seque nce, as well as before, during, and after shifts—aiming for concise, clear, and practical content. (2) List the structural features, processing range, operational precautions, main tenance requirements, and more separately by equipment category, making it easier for operators to grasp the key points and ensure proper implementation. (3) Common elements across  various types of mechanical and electrical equipment can be used to develop a unified, standard general procedure. (4) Key equipment, high-precision, large and medium-sized, as we ll as rare and critical electromechanical devices, must have operation and maintenance procedures prepared separately. Also, post prominent signage near the machine tool, clearly i ndicating that operators should pay special attention and strictly adhere to the guidelines. 2) Basic Content of Operation and Maintenance Procedures

The basic content of operation  and maintenance procedures generally includes the following aspects. (1) Operators must wear appropriate personal protective equipment as required during operation. When inspectin g or approaching the equipment, they should avoid wearing loose-fitting clothing. Female employees are not permitted to wear long hair loose. (2) Before starting work, clear the wo rkspace. Before turning on the equipment, inspect each operating handle and control device according to the items specified in the daily inspection checklist to ensure they are in  the off position. Check whether any components show signs of severe wear, damage requiring replacement, or loose connections posing safety risks. Verify that all safety protection  devices are intact and securely fastened. Also, confirm that the power supply is functioning properly and keep a detailed inspection record. If any issues are found that fail to me et safety standards, promptly submit safety improvement suggestions or solutions to the workshop supervisor to prevent the equipment from operating while faulty. (3) Check whether  the wires and control cabinets are damaged, whether the surrounding environment is reliable, and whether the equipment's grounding or earthing facilities are safe. If any issues ar e detected, take protective measures immediately. (4) Check the oil quality and level in lubrication and hydraulic systems; replenish oil according to the lubrication chart, ensuri ng the oil remains clean, the oil lines are unobstructed, and lubrication is optimal. Proper lubrication not only guarantees effective cooling and heat dissipation but also provide s sealing and protective functions. Additionally, it plays a significant role in cleaning away contaminants and reducing wear. (5) After confirming that all components are function ing correctly, you may first run the machine at low speed for 3–5 minutes with no load. Ensure that all parts operate smoothly and are well-lubricated before proceeding with actual  work. Never exceed the recommended load or use the equipment outside of specified guidelines. (6) While the equipment is running, it is strictly prohibited to adjust the workpiece  by hand or to perform lubrication, remove debris, or wipe down the machine. When leaving the machine tool, always turn off the power supply. During operation, closely monitor the  condition of all components; if any abnormalities are detected, immediately stop the machine and address the issue. (7) When maintaining, servicing, or cleaning equipment and instr uments, ensure that the equipment and instruments are powered down and the power supply is completely turned off. Additionally, clearly display or hang warning signs at the work si te to indicate that the equipment is undergoing maintenance or repair, or that personnel are present for ongoing work. (8) Before maintenance and servicing, personnel should be awa re of the precautions specific to this task and follow the proper maintenance procedures. During maintenance, staff must remain fully focused, wear appropriate safety gear, and ens ure their standing position is secure. (9) When maintaining equipment, use disassembly tools correctly; unauthorized assembly or disassembly is strictly prohibited. Do not remove o r alter the equipment's Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance at will. 15 Safety protection device: When positioning or ass embling the equipment, never insert your hands into the mating surfaces or use your fingers to align holes. (10) After completing maintenance, repair, and other operational tasks,  equipment should be removed from the work area, and the workspace along with machinery must be thoroughly cleaned. Every component of the equipment’s instruments and gauges should  be carefully inspected, ensuring that no tools or other items are left behind—either on the equipment or inside it. Additionally, the workshop should conduct regular maintenance, u pkeep, and repairs to ensure the smooth operation of all machinery. (11) Instructions, safety signs, and signage located within the workshop and on machinery must be strictly follo wed at all times. (12) It is strictly prohibited to use flammable or volatile substances for wiping equipment. Oil-soaked rags must not be left on the equipment, and no flammable o r explosive materials are allowed to be stored near the equipment. (13) When working in flammable and explosive hazard areas, appropriate safety measures must be taken beforehand a nd approved by the production safety department and management before proceeding. Additionally, when welding or grinding containers or pipelines containing flammable, explosive, or  toxic materials, these must first be properly purged and thoroughly cleaned—and all openings must be fully opened—before work can begin. (14) The work area should be dry and clean . Used oil and waste rags must not be discarded randomly on the floor. Raw materials, semi-finished products, and finished goods must be neatly stacked, and blocking passageways is  strictly prohibited. (15) Regularly maintain the cleanliness of lubrication and hydraulic systems. Keep the tank lid securely closed, ensuring no water, dust, metal chips, or othe r contaminants enter the oil tank or electrical equipment. (16) After finishing work and before leaving for the day, clean the machine tools and equipment thoroughly, ensuring they  remain tidy. Return operating handles, buttons, and other controls to their non-working positions, turn off the power supply, and complete the handover procedures with the next sh ift. 3) Classification of Maintenance and Servicing Tasks Depending on the depth, scope, and volume of work involved in equipment maintenance and upkeep, maintenance tasks can be c ategorized into the following types. (1) Daily Maintenance (Routine Maintenance). Its main tasks include: inspecting and lubricating the equipment; strictly following the equipment  operation procedures. Cheng uses the equipment to tighten any loose parts; cleans and wipes down the equipment, checks its operational status, and records the condition in the shi ft handover log. This type of maintenance is relatively simple, with most tasks performed on the equipment's surface. Daily maintenance should be carried out by the operating perso nnel. (2) First-Level Maintenance (Monthly Maintenance). The main tasks include: disassembling specified components such as the housing cover and protective shields, thoroughly cle aning and wiping both the inside and outside of the equipment; inspecting and adjusting clearance gaps between parts, tightening any loose components, and replacing individual wear -and-tear parts; clearing oil passages, cleaning filters, and replacing coolant while also flushing the coolant tank; cleaning guideways and sliding surfaces, removing burrs and sc ratches; and inspecting and adjusting electrical wiring and related devices. This first-level maintenance is performed after the equipment has been running for 1 to 2 months (under  a two-shift system), primarily by operational staff with support from maintenance technicians. (3) Second-Level Maintenance (Annual Maintenance). In addition to the tasks included  in first-level maintenance, second-level maintenance also involves repairing or replacing worn parts, adjusting clearances in components such as guides, maintaining the electrical  system, and inspecting and fine-tuning equipment accuracy. This type of maintenance is carried out once a year after the equipment has been in operation, primarily by maintenance  technicians with the participation of operators. 1.2.6 Equipment Fault Diagnosis Technology When equipment malfunctions, certain characteristics change accordingly, leading to vari ations in mechanical, thermal, acoustic, and electromagnetic physical and chemical parameters—each carrying distinct types of information. By capturing these altered indicators, de tecting the underlying signals and patterns, and analyzing their causes and anomalies, fault diagnosis technology enables us to pinpoint the location, nature, and severity of the f ailure, as well as forecast future issues, assess damage conditions, make informed decisions, eliminate potential hazards, and ultimately prevent accidents from occurring. This is  precisely what fault diagnosis technology aims to achieve. Mechatronic System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Studies Tutorial

16 1. Equipment Fault Diagnosis Process Equipment fault diagnosis encompasses three key areas: condition monitoring, analytical diagnosis, and fault prediction. The specific implementation process can be summarized into the following four steps. 1) Signal Acquisition During operation, equipment inevitably experiences changes in various quantities such as force, heat, vibration, and energy, generating a wide range of distinct information. Depending on specific diagnostic needs, it is crucial to select signals that accurately reflect the equipment's operational status—such as vibration, pressure, or temperature—since these signals are typically captured using different types of sensors. 2) Signal Processing This is the process of classifying and processing the collected signals to extract features that accurately represent the machine's characteristics—also known as feature extraction. For example, transforming a vibration signal from the time domain to the frequency domain for spectral analysis is part of this process. 3) State Recognition The device's characteristic parameters, obtained after signal processing, are compared with the specified allowable or discriminant parameters to determine the device's condition. The current status—whether a fault exists, and if so, its type and nature. To address this, appropriate identification criteria and diagnostic strategies should be carefully developed. 4) Diagnostic Decision-making

Based on the assessment of the equipment's current status, determine the appropriate responses and actions to take. At the same time, forecast how the equipment's condition may evolve based on existing signals, and conduct a trend analysis to anticipate future developments. The above four steps form a cycle; often, a complex or challenging fault cannot be correctly identified in just one cycle. Instead, it requires multiple iterations of the diagnostic process (as shown in Figure 1.1), gradually deepening both your understanding and the accuracy of your assessments—only then can the issue ultimately be resolved. Figure 1.1: Fault Diagnosis Process

Equipment Fault Diagnosis Levels Equipment fault diagnosis is generally divided into two levels: simple diagnosis and precision diagnosis. Most equipment faults can be identified using simple diagnostic techniques, making this approach the foundation of diagnostic work. Precision diagnostic techniques are only employed when simple diagnostics fail to pinpoint the issue. Simple Diagnostic Technique Simple diagnostic techniques involve using straightforward instruments and methods to quickly provide a general assessment of equipment condition. Technique, which generally includes: (1) Use a variety of simple and portable diagnostic instruments and testing devices.

(2) Detection and analysis conducted on-site by equipment maintenance and repair personnel. (3) Provide only a qualitative initial assessment of whether the equipment is functioning properly, its severity level, and the trend of its development. (4) The technical knowledge and experience involved are relatively simple, making them easy to learn and master. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 17

(5) The collected fault signals need to be stored and documented. Regular or online monitoring in equipment condition monitoring also falls under the category of simplified diagnostic techniques. It primarily involves checking specific parameters that reflect the equipment's technical condition to determine whether everything is functioning properly. If any abnormalities are detected or if parameters exceed predefined limits, the equipment should automatically trigger an alarm or shut down. However, condition monitoring differs from identifying and diagnosing actual faults. The simplified diagnostic method is suitable for the installation and commissioning phase, used to inspect and eliminate defects caused during transportation and installation work. It is also applicable during the maintenance phase for condition monitoring, enabling early detection of potential hazards and providing insights into the equipment's degradation trends. 2) Precision Diagnostic Technology Precision diagnostic technology uses sophisticated instruments and methods to provide a detailed evaluation of equipment that is difficult to diagnose accurately with simpler techniques. It typically includes: (1) Utilize a variety of sophisticated diagnostic analysis instruments or specialized diagnostic equipment. (2) Conducted on-site at the production facility and in the diagnostic center by experienced engineering technicians and experts. (3) Identify the location of equipment failures, determine their root causes, and perform a quantitative diagnosis of the failure types. (4) The technical knowledge and work experience involved are relatively complex, requiring collaboration across multiple disciplines. (5) Perform advanced signal processing and, if necessary, predict equipment lifespan. Precision diagnostic technologies are used not only in the development and design of equipment but, increasingly, during the operation and maintenance phases. For devices that have already undergone preliminary diagnostics and been identified as exhibiting anomalies or malfunctions, these advanced techniques further pinpoint the specific locations, root causes, and types of failures—enabling more accurate and targeted repairs. It facilitates making repair decisions. Since it involves higher costs, it’s typically used in advance only when a simple diagnosis fails to provide a clear answer.

1.2.7 Patterns of Failure Occurrence Mechanical and electrical equipment failures exhibit two notable characteristics: first, the likelihood of failure increases as the equipment ages; second, failures occur randomly, making it difficult to predict the exact timing of any given failure. Consequently, over the equipment's lifespan, the probability of a failure can be expressed using statistical methods. The failure rate, denoted by ( \lambda(t) ), represents the conditional probability that a failure will occur within the infinitesimal time interval ( dt ), given that no failure has yet happened up to time ( t ). Most failures occur at times and frequencies that correlate with the machine's The usage time of electrical equipment is closely linked. Engineering practice Experience and experimentation show that the failure rate of机电 equipment varies. Divided into the early failure phase, the random failure phase, and the wear-out failure phase. It consists of 3 stages, as shown in Figure 1.2. 1. Early Failure Phase The early failure period is characterized by a higher failure rate, but The failure rate decreases rapidly as the equipment's operating time increases. Early failures are typically caused by design or manufacturing defects.
