Due to various reasons, the early failure period may reappear after major equipment repairs or upgrades. 2. Random Failure Period During the random failure period, the failure rate remains low and stable, nearly constant. Random failures are caused by偶然 factors—they are unpredictable and cannot be eliminated even by extending the running-in phase. Design flaws, component defects, inadequate maintenance, and improper operation can all lead to random failures. 3. Wear-Out Failure Phase The characteristic of wear-out failures is that the failure rate increases as operating time accumulates. Wear-out failures are caused by factors such as wear fatigue, aging, and corrosion of equipment components. These types of failures typically indicate that the equipment is approaching its major overhaul period or nearing the end of its service life. 1.3 Failure Modes of Mechanical Components and Corresponding Countermeasures During equipment operation, the phenomenon where mechanical components lose their intended functionality due to various factors such as design, materials, manufacturing processes, and assembly—rendering them unable to continue working—is referred to as failure. When critical components of machinery fail, it indicates that the equipment has entered a state of malfunction. Machine failures are inherently linked to the failure of mechanical parts. Given the wide variety of mechanical equipment types, along with significant differences in operating conditions and environmental factors, the failure modes of mechanical components also vary widely. Among these, the four most common and representative failure modes are wear, corrosion, deformation, and fracture. 1.3.1 Wear of Mechanical Components Wear of mechanical components is the primary failure mode for parts. In typical mechanical equipment, approximately 80% of failed or scrapped components are due to wear-related issues. Wear not only reduces the efficiency and reliability of机电设备 but can also lead to premature failure of the equipment itself. Therefore, conducting research into the wear mechanisms of机电设备 can help us understand the specific wear characteristics of various components, providing a solid foundation for developing effective maintenance strategies and schedules—and ultimately extending the service life of the equipment. 1. General Patterns of Part Wear Wear is a microscopic and dynamic process that occurs as parts wear down. Various physical, chemical, and mechanical phenomena occur, along with their external manifestations. The state refers to the wear of the surface material, and the extent of wear is typically measured by abrasion. Measure, measure. Under normal operating conditions, the wear process of the part is divided into 3 stages. Phase, as shown in Figure 1.3, where w represents the wear amount. 1) Fitting-in Phase OA It occurs during the initial phase of equipment use. At this stage, the surfaces of the friction pair exhibit micro-… Observing the wave peaks results in a smaller actual contact area between the parts, leading to increased contact stress. Very large, resulting in plastic deformation and wear at the surface of the running parts at a rapid rate.

The degree is very high. Choose a reasonable running-in load, relative motion speed, and lubrication. Slip conditions and other parameters are key to shortening the break-in period. 2) Stable Wear Phase AB The wear characteristic of this stage is a low and stable wear rate, which is why the duration of this phase is relatively long. But by mid- Figure 1.3: Wear Characteristic Curve –  Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 19 Later on, the wear rate becomes relatively faster, but the equipment can still fu nction for a while. When the wear amount reaches point B, the wear rate sharply accelerates, marking the onset of the severe wear phase. Proper usage, along with regular maintenanc e and upkeep of the equipment, is key to extending this critical stage. 3) Rapid Wear Phase BC Once this stage is reached, significant changes in friction conditions occur, such as  altered lubrication or shifts in the geometric dimensions of components. Changes, such as increased clearance between mating parts and the generation of impact loads, can cause we ar rates to rise sharply. At this point, mechanical efficiency noticeably declines, and precision deteriorates—conditions that, if left unaddressed, could lead to equipment failure  or even unexpected accidents. Therefore, promptly identifying and repairing components that are about to enter this stage is critically important. According to wear results, wear  is categorized into pitting wear, adhesive wear, abrasive wear, and more; while based on wear mechanisms, it is classified into abrasive wear, fatigue wear, adhesive wear, fretting  wear, and others. Abrasive wear occurs when a hard protruding part on one surface of a friction pair comes into contact with the other surface, or when abrasive particles are pres ent between the two rubbing surfaces. Wear occurs when hard particulates—such as dust in the air or metal particles generated by abrasion—cause material transfer from one surface t o another, or even simultaneous material loss on both surfaces, during relative motion. Among the many wear failure modes, abrasive wear is not only the most common but also the mo st severe type of failure. Fretting wear refers to a type of wear where localized areas on the surfaces of friction pairs develop fatigue cracks under cyclic contact stresses, lead ing to the detachment of micro-sheets or particles. Depending on the nature of contact and relative motion between the friction pairs, fretting wear can be categorized into two mai n forms: rolling-contact fatigue wear and sliding-contact fatigue wear. In practical applications, pure rolling-contact fatigue wear is relatively rare; most often, it occurs as a  combination of rolling and sliding motions. Adhesive wear occurs when, at the points of contact between mating surfaces,  "cold welding " takes place, causing material from one surface to transfer to the other during relative sliding. Micro-motion wear is a type of wear that occurs when two contacting objects under go relative vibrations with very small amplitudes. It happens on two closely matched surfaces that appear nominally stationary but actually experience cyclic, minute-scale relative  sliding—typically at the micrometer level (2–20 μm). For instance, this phenomenon can be observed at interference or transition-fit interfaces between shafts and holes, on keyway  surfaces, or in threaded fasteners. Wear occurring on working surfaces, such as the working surface of the rivet, and other similar areas. Fretting wear not only reduces mating ac curacy, loosens tight-fitting components, and degrades the quality of the mating surfaces, but can also lead to the formation of fatigue cracks, significantly diminishing the fatig ue strength of the part. 2. Measures to Prevent or Reduce Wear

According to theoretical studies on wear, combined with practical production experience, the methods and approaches t o prevent or reduce wear can be summarized into the following areas. Lubrication Choosing the right lubricant and lubrication method, and replacing dry friction with ideal fluid friction, is the most effective way to reduce friction and wear. Correctly selecting materials Selecting the right materials based on their fundamental wear characteristics is one of the key factors in enhancing wear resistance. High fatigue strength, excellent corrosion resistance, and superior wear and high-temperature performance should be prioritized when choosing new steel grades or advanced materials. Additionally, it’s important to consider the compatibility between mating materials to ensure they form an optimal combination. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial

3) Perform surface treatment By employing various surface treatment methods—such as surface heat treatment (e.g., surface hardening of steel), surface chemical heat treatments (e.g., carburizing and nitriding of steel), thermal spraying, flame spraying, coatings, deposition, ion implantation, roll forming, and shot peening—surface wear resistance can be significantly improved. This is one of the most effective and cost-efficient approaches available. 4) Rational structural design Proper and rational structural design is an effective way to reduce wear and enhance wear resistance. The structure should facilitate the formation and restoration of protective surface films between friction pairs, ensure uniform pressure distribution, promote efficient dissipation of frictional heat, enable smooth removal of wear debris, and prevent the ingress of external abrasive particles and dust. In structural design, the principle of substitution can be applied—allowing one component in the system to wear while protecting another critical part—or the principle of transfer, where one member of the friction pair is intentionally worn more rapidly to safeguard the other. More valuable parts.

5) Improve working conditions Avoid excessive loads, excessively high speeds, and elevated operating temperatures whenever possible. Creating optimal environmental conditions can help reduce wear and tear. 6) Enhance repair quality Improving machining quality, enhancing repair quality, boosting assembly quality, and elevating installation quality are effective measures to prevent and reduce wear. 7) Proper Use and Maintenance Strengthening scientific management and staff training, along with strict adherence to operating procedures and other relevant regulations, helps reduce wear and tear. During the initial phase of machinery use, ensure proper running-in procedures are followed. Whenever possible, leverage advanced monitoring and testing technologies.

1.3.2 Corrosion of Metal Parts In the field of engineering, metal corrosion leads to enormous economic losses—estimates suggest that globally, steel and equipment scrapped annually due to corrosion account for approximately 30% of the world’s annual steel production. Corrosion is the process by which metals are damaged as a result of interactions with their surrounding environment, typically occurring when metal components undergo chemical or electrochemical reactions under specific environmental conditions. Corrosive damage always begins at the metal’s surface, gradually progressing inward—sometimes rapidly, sometimes more slowly—leading to material loss, degradation of surface quality, and even internal crystal structure damage. This ultimately results in irregularly shaped defects such as pits and spots, severely compromising the component’s integrity and eventually causing it to fail. Metal corrosion is broadly classified into two main categories based on its mechanism and underlying processes: chemical corrosion and electrochemical corrosion. Chemical Corrosion of Metal Parts Chemical corrosion of metals is caused by purely chemical reactions. When the surface material of a metal part interacts chemically with harmful components present in surrounding gases or non-electrolytic liquids, a corrosion layer forms on the metal surface. As this layer continuously flakes off and regenerates, the part gradually deteriorates. The primary harmful substances that react chemically with mechanical components include gases like O₂, H₂S, and SO₂, as well as certain corrosive byproducts found in lubricating oils. Among these, the chemical reaction between iron and oxygen is the most common form of chemical corrosion. Erosion, the process is as follows.

4Fe + 3O₂ → 2Fe₂O₃ 3Fe + 2O₂ → Fe₃O₄ Corrosion products such as Fe₂O₃ or Fe₃O₄ typically form a protective film that coats the metal surface. During friction, Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment 21 After the surface oxide film is worn away, the friction surface quickly reacts with the oxidizing medium, forming a new oxide layer that is subsequently removed during the friction  process. This cyclical process ultimately leads to metal corrosion. A key characteristic of oxidative wear is the presence of uniform, fine grooves aligned along the sliding direc tion on the friction surface, accompanied by reddish-brown flaky Fe₂O₃ or grayish-black filamentous Fe₃O₄ debris. Debris is generated. The primary factors influencing oxidative wea r are the density and integrity of the oxide film, as well as how firmly it adheres to the substrate. If the oxide film is dense, intact, free of pores, and strongly bonded to the  metal substrate, it exhibits excellent wear resistance, resists being worn away easily, and effectively helps prevent corrosion of the metal surface. 2. Electrochemical Corrosion o f Metal Parts Electrochemical corrosion is a complex physical and chemical process of corrosion. It can be defined as the continuous, charge-driven chemical corrosion that occurs w hen two metal electrodes with a potential difference are immersed in an electrolyte solution. This type of corrosion happens when metals come into contact with electrolytic substan ces, and its key distinction from ordinary chemical corrosion lies in the fact that it involves the flow of electric current during the process. The fundamental conditions necessar y for electrochemical corrosion to occur are: ① the presence of two or more objects with differing electrode potentials—or, within a single object, regions exhibiting different ele ctrode potentials—that act as positive and negative electrodes; ② a conductive pathway connecting the electrodes, either through a conductor or direct contact, allowing charges in  the corrosion zone to flow freely; and ③ the simultaneous presence of an electrolyte solution. Common forms of electrochemical corrosion include the following: (1) Uniform corrosio n. When a metal part or component exhibits a uniform corrosion pattern across its surface, it is referred to as uniform corrosion. This type of corrosion can occur in liquids, the  atmosphere, or soil. Among mechanical equipment, the most common form of uniform corrosion is atmospheric corrosion. In industrial areas, the atmosphere often contains higher conce ntrations of corrosive gases such as CO₂, SO₂, H₂S, NO₂, and Cl₂. Additionally, airborne dust particles may carry acidic, alkaline, or saline micro-particles, which, when adhering  to the surface of components, can absorb moisture from the air and form an electrolyte, ultimately leading to corrosion on the part's surface. (2) Pitting corrosion. On most surfac es of metal components, corrosion either doesn’t occur at all or is very mild; however, localized areas develop small corrosion pits that penetrate deeply into the material. This t ype of corrosion is known as pitting corrosion. Because metals used in industry often contain extremely tiny microelectrodes, they are highly susceptible to pitting corrosion when  exposed to aqueous solutions or humid environments. In the case of steel components, when pitting corrosion occurs alongside uniform corrosion, the corrosion spots can easily becom e obscured by the porous structure formed during uniform corrosion, making them difficult to detect and identify. As a result, pitting corrosion is one of the most dangerous forms  of corrosion. (3) Crevice corrosion. In机电 equipment, gaps exist between various connected components—typically ranging from 0.025 to 0.1 mm. When corrosive media enter these gaps a nd remain trapped, localized corrosion can occur precisely at the crevices. For instance, this type of crevice corrosion often happens at flange faces where pipes are connected, as  well as at the riveted joints of metal rivets. (4) Corrosion Fatigue. When metallic components subjected to cyclic stress experience reduced fatigue strength or shortened fatigue  life—and ultimately fail—due to the presence of a corrosive environment, this phenomenon is known as corrosion fatigue or corrosion fatigue fracture. Corrosion fatigue can cause me tal components to fracture even under very low levels of cyclic (pulsating) stress, and often there is no clear fatigue limit. As a result, damage caused by corrosion fatigue tends  to be more severe than that resulting from pure mechanical fatigue alone. To prevent and reduce corrosion failures, as well as minimize their harmful effects on equipment, special  attention must be paid during the manufacturing process to correctly selecting materials for components and thoughtfully designing various structural elements. Additionally, for p arts operating in corrosive environments, advanced anti-corrosion measures such as surface coating technologies, electrochemical protection techniques, and the addition of corrosio n inhibitors should be employed to ensure that these components remain protected—or at least minimally affected—by corrosive agents.

3. Cavitation When a part comes into contact wi th a liquid and experiences relative motion, bubbles form at the contact point if the local pressure drops below the liquid's vapor pressure. As these bubbles move toward high-pres sure areas, they are compressed and deformed by the intense external pressure—eventually leading to their collapse. A Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Electro-Mechanical Systems Involving Bubble Formation 22 When bubbles are forced to collapse, their rapid implosion—at speeds as high a s 250 m/s—immediately generates an enormous impact force and extremely high temperatures. Under the combined effects of this intense force and extreme heat, localized liquids can e ject tiny jets of liquid outward. This phenomenon is known as cavitation. If a bubble collapses right at the surface of a component, the surface itself comes under direct impact from these microjets. Over time, as bubbles repeatedly form and burst in close proximity to the surface, the material on the component’s surface is continuously bombarded by these high-speed liquid jets. This relentless erosion eventually leads to fatigue, causing the material to gradually flake off—initially forming small pitting marks that, over time, expand into a sponge-like, foam-like texture. This process is commonly referred to as cavitation damage. Cavitation is a relatively complex destructive phenomenon that involves not only mechanical effects but also chemical and electrochemical processes. This destructive process is exacerbated when the liquid contains impurities or abrasive particles. Cavitation commonly occurs on the outer walls of diesel engine cylinder liners, pump components, turbine blades, and hydraulic pumps, among other areas. Measures to reduce cavitation primarily include: (1) To reduce the occurrence of water hammer by minimizing vibrations on surfaces in contact with liquids, methods such as increasing rigidity, improving support systems, and implementing vibration-damping measures can be employed. (2) Select materials resistant to cavitation, such as cast iron with spherical or nodular graphite, stainless steel, nylon, and others. (3) Parts can be coated with anti-cavitation materials such as plastic or ceramic, or they can also be surface-chromed. (4) Improve the part structure, reduce surface roughness values, and minimize vortex formation during liquid flow. (5) Add emulsified oil to the water to reduce the impact force during bubble bursts. 1.3.3 Deformation of Mechanical Parts In practice, it often happens that although worn parts have been repaired and restored to their original dimensions, shape, and fit, the equipment still fails to achieve its original technical performance after assembly. This is usually due to deformation of the parts, particularly It is caused by the deformation of basic components, which disrupts the positional accuracy between parts and, in turn, affects the relationships among the individual components. Deformation in mechanical parts or components can be categorized into two types: elastic deformation and plastic deformation. Elastic Deformation Elastic deformation is the type of deformation that fully recovers once the external force is removed. After a material undergoes elastic deformation, it may exhibit an elastic aftereffect: when the external force is suddenly released, the strain doesn’t vanish entirely right away—it disappears only partially, with the remaining portion gradually dissipating over time. This phenomenon, where the strain lags behind the applied stress, is known as the elastic aftereffect. The extent of the elastic aftereffect depends on factors such as the material’s properties, the magnitude of the stress, its initial state, and the temperature. Specifically, the more non-uniform the metal’s microstructure, the greater the applied stress, and the higher the temperature, the more pronounced the elastic aftereffect will be. Typically, after straightening, shaft-like components tend to bend again after some time—this is a clear manifestation of the elastic aftereffect. To eliminate this phenomenon, one effective method is to perform prolonged tempering, which ensures that residual stresses are completely relieved within a short period. Plastic Deformation Plastic deformation refers to the type of deformation that does not fully recover once the external force is removed. Its key characteristics include: ① it leads to changes in the material's microstructure and properties, resulting in work hardening of the metal; ② since polycrystalline materials undergo uneven deformation across individual grains and even within the same grain during plastic deformation, the elastic recovery of each grain differs after the external force is removed, leading to residual stresses; ③ plastic deformation enhances atomic mobility, thereby reducing the metal's corrosion resistance. Plastic deformation of metal parts, viewed from macroscopic morphological features, includes volume deformation, warping deformation, and aging deformation. Volume deformation refers to the phenomenon where metal parts expand or contract in volume due to changes in thermal capacity caused by phase transformations during heating and cooling processes. Warping deformation, on the other hand, involves plastic deformation that results in bending or twisting of the part, with the primary cause being failures outlined in Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance. 23 It involves deformations of various types (such as bending, torsion, tension-compression, etc.) and in different directions. These deformations are commonly observed in slender shaft-like, thin plate-shaped components, as well as in thin-walled annular and sleeve-type parts. Age-related deformation is caused by changes in stress. 3. Measures to Prevent and Reduce Deformation of Mechanical Parts Deformation is inevitable, but appropriate measures can be taken from the following four areas to prevent and minimize mechanical part deformation. 1) Design aspect

When designing, it's essential to consider not only the strength of the parts but also their stiffness, as well as issues related to manufacturing, assembly, usage, disassembly, and maintenance. (1) Select materials carefully, paying attention to their process properties—such as casting fluidity and shrinkage, forging ductility and cold-heading capability, weldability characteristics like susceptibility to cold and hot cracking, machinability for ease of cutting, and heat-treatment properties including hardenability and resistance to cold brittleness. (2) Properly arrange the parts to optimize their stress distribution. Select appropriate structural dimensions, ensuring uniform wall thicknesses as much as possible, and minimize deformation during hot working processes. For instance, avoid sharp corners by replacing them with rounded or chamfered edges; for areas with significant thickness variations, consider adding process holes or reinforcing excessively thin sections. Additionally, carefully position any existing holes—transforming blind holes into through-holes where feasible. For parts with complex geometries, whenever possible, opt for modular or assembled designs to further enhance stress management. (3) In the design process, ensure the application of new technologies, processes, and materials to minimize internal stresses and deformation during manufacturing. 2) Manufacturing In the rough casting manufacturing process, it is important to address deformation issues and implement various process measures to minimize residual stresses in the blank. After the raw parts are produced and during subsequent machining processes, it is essential to incorporate sufficient steps for relieving internal stresses, aiming to minimize residual stresses within the components. One effective method to eliminate these residuals is through aging treatment, which can be either natural or artificial. Natural aging involves leaving the finished raw parts exposed outdoors for 1 to 2 years. This approach leverages the material’s inherent property of gradually releasing internal stresses over a period of 12 to 20 months—making it particularly effective—but the main drawback is the excessively long aging cycle. On the other hand, artificial aging accelerates the stress-relief process by subjecting the parts to high-temperature annealing followed by controlled cooling at a slow pace. Alternatively, vibrational techniques can also be employed to achieve artificial aging. For high-precision components, artificial aging must be integrated into the final machining stages to ensure optimal dimensional accuracy and stability. During machining and repair processes, minimize the number of datum shifts, preserving the original machining datums for use during maintenance, thereby reducing repair time. Errors caused by inconsistent benchmarks during machining. For parts that have undergone heat treatment, be sure to allow sufficient machining allowances and adjust the machining dimensions accordingly. Pre-applying controlled deformation is crucial—once the deformation patterns of the part are understood, you can counteract them in advance by introducing an equal but opposite amount of deformation. Alternatively, you can pre-stress the part or carefully manage the generation and evolution of stresses, ensuring that the final deformation aligns with specifications and effectively minimizes distortion. 3) Maintenance Aspects During maintenance, it is essential to not only meet the technical requirements—such as restoring part dimensions, ensuring proper fit tolerances, and achieving high surface quality—but also to inspect and correct any shape or positional errors in critical components. To minimize stress and deformation of parts during repair, standardized guidelines and maintenance procedures specifically addressing deformation issues should be established. Additionally, simple, reliable, and user-friendly specialized measuring tools and fixtures should be designed. Finally, it’s important to actively promote "three new" technologies, particularly innovative repair techniques like brush plating and bonding. 4) Usage Instructions

Usage guidelines include strengthening equipment management, establishing and rigorously enforcing operating procedures, enhancing inspection and maintenance of mechanical equipment, avoiding overloading, and preventing localized overloads or overheating. Case Study Tutorial on Diagnosis and Repair of Electromechanical System Failures 24

1.3.4 Fracture of Mechanical Parts Fracture refers to the phenomenon where a mechanical component develops localized cracks or splits into several parts under the influence of certain factors. It is one of the primary modes of mechanical component failure—once a part fractures, it not only completely loses its functionality but can also lead to significant economic losses and even cause accidents resulting in injuries or fatalities. Particularly as modern manufacturing systems continue to evolve toward higher power levels and faster rotational speeds, the operating conditions for components have changed dramatically, increasing the likelihood of fracture-related failures. As a result, fracture failure has become a hot topic of research today. The fracture surface formed after a part breaks can accurately capture the dynamic evolution of the failure process. By analyzing the fracture surface, it is possible to identify the primary cause of the fracture, providing valuable insights that help refine designs and enable effective repairs. Based on the cause of failure, fractures can be categorized into types such as brittle fracture and fatigue fracture. Brittle Fracture Before fracturing, the component exhibits no noticeable plastic deformation; this type of fracture, which develops extremely rapidly, is known as brittle fracture.  Brittle fracture occurs without any prior warning signs, making it a sudden and highly dangerous form of failure. Metal parts may become brittle—and thus prone to sudden fracture— due to improper manufacturing processes, exposure to corrosive media during use, or adverse environmental conditions. For instance, the penetration of hydrogen or hydrides into met al materials can lead to  "hydrogen embrittlement, " while chloride ions infiltrating austenitic stainless steel may cause  "chloride stress corrosion cracking. " Similarly, nitrate ions entering carbon steel can trigger  "nitrate embrittlement, " and steel in contact with alkaline substances might suffer from  "alkali embrittlement. " Additionally, copper components exposed to ammonia can experience  "ammonia-induced embrittlement. " Furthermore, at ambient temperatures between 10°C and 15°C, medium- to low-strength carbon steels are particularly susceptible to  "cold embrittlement " (often caused by elevated phosphorus content in the steel). Meanwhile, aluminum-containing alloys, if not carefully temperature-controlled during heat treatment, can easily overh eat—even with only a slight deviation from the optimal range—leading to severe embrittlement. The hazards posed by brittle fracture in metals are significant, second only to those  associated with fatigue failure. Fatigue Fracture The fracture phenomenon that occurs in metal parts after being subjected to a certain number of cyclic loads or alternating stresses is known as fatigue failure. In fact, 80% of fractures in mechanical components during use are caused by fatigue. Typically, fatigue failure progresses through three distinct stages: the initiation phase of fatigue cracks; the propagation phase of fatigue cracks; and finally, catastrophic failure—the unstable, rapid growth phase of the fatigue crack. Below, we will analyze the fracture surfaces associated with fatigue failure. A typical fatigue fracture typically exhibits 3 distinct features based on the fracture process. Regions with distinct characteristics: fatigue core zone, fatigue crack propagation Zone and transient zone, as shown in Figure 1.4. Fatigue Core Zone It is the source region of fatigue fracture, visible to the naked eye or under low magnification. A magnifying glass can pinpoint the location of the fatigue core on the fracture surface—it typically does. Appearing in the area with the lowest intensity, highest stress, and closest to the surface Position. But if there are defects inside the material, this fatigue core... It could also occur at the defect site. Scratches left behind during the machining, storage, transportation, and assembly processes are highly likely to become fatigue nuclei, as these marks not only cause stress concentrations but also remain vulnerable to corrosion damage from air and other environmental factors. Figure 1.4: Schematic Diagram of Fatigue Fracture Features (Uniaxial Bending)
Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance, Page 25

2) Fatigue Crack Propagation Zone This region is the most critical feature area on the fracture surface, often appearing shell-like or resembling beach ripples. Each individual line marks the trace left behind after a single crack extension event—typically corresponding to a change in applied load, such as when a machine starts up or shuts down. These lines radiate outward from the fatigue core, advancing perpendicularly to the direction of crack propagation. The smoother the crack propagation zone on the fatigue fracture surface, the more load cycles the component endured prior to failure. Conversely, the denser the shell-like lines near the instantaneous fracture zone indicate lower load magnitudes. On the other hand, if this area appears rougher, it suggests that the crack propagated rapidly under relatively high loading conditions. 3) Transient Break Zone Commonly referred to as the "static fracture surface," it is the fracture region formed when a fatigue crack rapidly propagates upon reaching a critical size. Its macroscopic features closely resemble the radial zone and shear lips typically observed in fast-fracture areas of static tensile fractures. The location and size of the instantaneous fracture zone are directly influenced by the applied load—specifically, the greater the load, the closer the final fracture area moves toward the center of the fracture surface. Conversely, a smaller fracture area indicates that the component was subjected to a lower load. 3. Fracture Failure Analysis

The steps for fracture failure analysis are generally as follows. 1) On-site recording and photography After a major equipment accident occurs, promptly investigate and understand all circumstances before and after the incident, and take photographs or videos if necessary. Unless there are casualties requiring immediate attention, efforts should be made to preserve the scene as much as possible. 2) Analyze the dominant failure component When a critical component fails due to fracture, it often leads to the failure of other related parts and structural elements. In such cases, it’s essential to carefully determine the sequence of events and accurately identify the primary fracture-causing component—otherwise, the analysis results could be misleading. 3) Identify the dominant crack on the primary failure component The dominant failure component may already be fragmented; therefore, the remaining fragments should be collected, carefully pieced together, and analyzed to identify which crack initiated first—this crack is the dominant one. 4) Identifying the Failure Source Area Once the dominant crack is identified, you can then examine the corresponding fracture surface to locate the crack initiation zone. 5) Fracture Surface Treatment If further microscopic analysis of the fracture surface is required, or if it’s necessary to preserve evidence, the fracture surface should be cleaned. Typically, clean with compressed air or alcohol, then dry thoroughly afterward. If long-term storage is required, apply rust-preventive oil or grease and store in a sealed container equipped with a desiccant. 6) Determine the cause of failure

When determining the failure cause of a part, consider the material properties, manufacturing process, load conditions, assembly quality, and years of use. Carefully examine and analyze factors such as the medium and temperature in the working environment, as well as the usage conditions of similar parts, before combining this information with the macroscopic and microscopic features of the fracture surface to make an accurate assessment and identify the primary and secondary causes of the failure. 7) Identify Failure Countermeasures Once the cause of failure is identified, targeted solutions are proposed to effectively leverage existing conditions and prevent fracture incidents from occurring. A Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Cases for Mechatronic Systems 26

4. Measures to Reduce Fracture Failure Fracture failure is one of the most dangerous forms of failure, and most metal parts fail due to various factors arising from metallurgy and part manufacturing processes. Because all of them contain cracks of varying sizes and characteristics, ranging from atomic-level dislocations to macroscopic cracks visible to the naked eye. However, a part with cracks doesn’t necessarily fail immediately—there’s typically a period during which these cracks undergo subcritical propagation. Moreover, under certain conditions, cracks may even remain stable without expanding at all. Therefore, by implementing effective measures, it’s possible to ensure that parts containing cracks do not ultimately fracture. Strategies to minimize fracture failures can be considered from the following perspectives. 1) Optimize the shape and structural design of parts, and carefully select appropriate materials for the components. Both geometric discontinuities in part shapes and material imperfections can lead to stress concentration. Geometric discontinuities are commonly referred to as notches, such as fillets at shoulders, grooves, oil holes, keyways, threads, and machining marks. Material-related discontinuities are typically called material defects, including shrinkage porosity, shrinkage cavities, non-metallic inclusions, and welding flaws. These areas prone to stress concentration are particularly susceptible to crack initiation and propagation under cyclic or impact loading, ultimately leading to fracture. Therefore, in part design, it’s crucial to minimize stress-concentration zones while carefully considering the part’s operating environment—such as the presence of corrosive media, temperature variations, and applied loads—and selecting appropriate materials accordingly. This approach helps effectively reduce the risk of fatigue failure. 2) Properly select the part machining method During various machining, welding, and heat treatment processes, residual stresses remain inside components due to factors such as plastic deformation, thermal expansion and contraction, and phase transformations occurring during these operations. Residual stresses are categorized into two types: residual tensile stress and residual compressive stress. While residual tensile stress is detrimental to component performance, residual compressive stress can significantly enhance the fatigue life of the part. Therefore, it is advisable to prioritize processes like carburizing, nitriding, shot peening, and surface rolling—methods known for generating beneficial compressive stresses—in component manufacturing. By inducing compressive stresses on the component’s surface, these techniques help counteract some of the tensile stresses caused by external loads, thereby improving the overall durability and longevity of the part. 3) Installation and Usage Instructions

① Ensure proper installation to prevent the development of additional stress and vibration. For critical components, avoid dents and scratches, as even the smallest damage could become a potential fracture point. ② Care should be taken to protect the equipment's operating environment, preventing erosion from corrosive media and avoiding excessive temperature differences between its various components. ③ To prevent equipment overload, strictly follow the equipment operating procedures. ④ Take timely corrective measures for parts with cracks.

1.4 Mechanical Equipment Maintenance Procedures and Implementation With the continuous advancement of new materials, processes, and technologies, repairing mechanical parts has evolved beyond simply restoring them to their original condition. Many advanced techniques now not only revive components but also enhance their performance and extend their service life. For instance, methods such as electroplating, surfacing welding, application of wear-resistant coatings, thermal spraying and flame spraying, adhesive bonding, and various surface-hardening treatments allow for the precise deposition of small amounts of high-performance materials onto part surfaces—at relatively low costs—while significantly boosting wear resistance. As a result, in the maintenance of electromechanical equipment, fully leveraging these repair techniques and carefully selecting appropriate processes can reduce downtime, cut maintenance expenses, and ultimately lead to substantial improvements in a company’s economic efficiency. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Repair for Electromechanical Equipment 27

1.4.1 Preparations Before Mechanical Equipment Maintenance Electromechanical equipment occupies a critically important position in the production and operational activities of modern industrial enterprises. To ensure smooth equipment operation and safe production, implementing planned preventive maintenance is an essential component of equipment management and repair practices in industrial companies. This section will cover the detailed process of major equipment overhauls, the determination of equipment repair plans, as well as the technical and material preparations required prior to equipment maintenance. 1. Equipment Major Overhaul Process To ensure the precision and operational performance of mechanical and electrical equipment, preventive scheduled maintenance must be carried out in addition to routine upkeep. Among these preventive measures, major overhauls stand out as a critical task aimed at restoring the equipment's accuracy. Within the category of preventive maintenance, major overhauls—often referred to simply as "overhauls"—represent the most extensive and time-consuming type of repair. An overhaul involves completely or largely disassembling the equipment, repairing or replacing foundational components, refurbishing mechanical and electrical parts, recalibrating the electrical systems, and finally reassembling and fine-tuning the entire unit. The ultimate goal is to thoroughly eliminate any pre-existing defects and restore the equipment to its specified performance standards. The purpose of precision and performance. The major steps involved in the overhaul of mechanical and electrical equipment typically include: pre-disassembly unit inspection, component removal, component inspection, necessary component disassembly, parts cleaning and examination, component repair and assembly, final assembly, no-load trial operation, load testing, overall machine precision verification, and final acceptance. In practice, these tasks should be carried out according to the overhaul work plan, while also ensuring effective job scheduling, quality control during operations, and thorough completion acceptance. The major overhaul process for mechanical and electrical equipment is typically divided into three stages: pre-repair preparation, the repair process itself, and post-repair acceptance. Pre-repair preparation phase To ensure the repair work proceeds smoothly and accurately, maintenance personnel should carefully listen to operators' requirements for equipment repairs and thoroughly understand the issues affecting the equipment being serviced—such as loss of precision, the extent of wear on major mechanical components, the accuracy of the transmission system, and any visible defects. They should also identify which parts need improvement or modification to meet the equipment’s operational specifications. Additionally, they should review relevant technical documentation, equipment manuals, and previous maintenance records to become familiar with the device’s structural features, transmission system, and original design precision standards. This preparation will enable them to propose comprehensive pre-inspection tasks. Following the pre-inspection, specific repair methods for critical and large components can be determined, allowing for the preparation of specialized tools and precision measuring instruments. Finally, the team must define the post-repair precision testing procedures and establish clear acceptance criteria for trial runs, ensuring all technical preparations are fully in place before proceeding with the complete overhaul of the equipment.

2) Maintenance Process Stage Once the maintenance process begins, the first step is to disassemble the equipment—following a sequence and approach that reverses the original assembly order, adhering to the principle of "top-down and outside-in." This systematic method carefully releases the components from their interlocking and fixed positions within the machine. After removal, each part should undergo a secondary pre-inspection. Based on the findings from this second check, any additional repair parts required will be identified. Furthermore, the availability of replacement and repaired components, along with their current status, will help establish a rough schedule for the maintenance tasks. This ensures that the repair work progresses methodically and according to plan, preventing delays caused by poor coordination in organizational efforts. The precision and performance achievable during equipment maintenance depend on factors such as the technical expertise available for repair work, the number of major overhauls the equipment has undergone, and its pre-repair technical condition. Generally speaking, for machinery undergoing its first major overhaul, both its precision and performance should ideally meet the original factory standards. However, after two or more major overhauls, the equipment’s post-repair precision and performance typically fall short of those of a new unit. That said, if the equipment was in relatively good technical condition prior to the last overhaul, it will likely be easier to restore its quality closer to the original factory standards this time around. Conversely, if the previous overhaul left the equipment in suboptimal condition, it may create significant challenges for the next major repair—and in some cases, the resulting quality might even fail to meet the original factory standards, making further repairs impractical altogether. The assembly of the complete equipment is carried out according to acceptance criteria. During assembly, appropriate reference surfaces should be selected for accurate mechanical and electrical system fault diagnosis and maintenance case studies.

28 Determine the form and compensation method for the error compensation环节, ensuring assembly accuracy among all components—such as parallelism, coaxiality, perpendicularity, and the required meshing precision of the transmission. 3) Post-Repair Acceptance Phase All equipment that has undergone repair, assembly, and adjustment must be subjected to comprehensive precision checks and tests—such as geometric accuracy inspections, no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision evaluations—in accordance with the relevant prescribed accuracy standards or the precision criteria established prior to repair. These measures ensure a thorough assessment of the repaired equipment’s quality, restored precision, and overall performance. After equipment maintenance, record the modifications made to the original technical documentation and document any lessons learned during the repair process. Prepare a thorough post-repair summary and file it alongside the original documents for future reference during the next maintenance task. 2. Determining the Equipment Maintenance Plan Major equipment overhauls must not only meet the predetermined technical requirements but also strive to enhance economic efficiency. Therefore, before starting repairs, it’s essential to thoroughly assess the equipment’s technical condition, develop a practical and feasible repair plan, and ensure comprehensive preparation—both technically and in terms of production readiness. During the repair process, actively incorporate new technologies, materials, processes, and modern management techniques, while diligently managing technical, financial, and organizational aspects to guarantee high-quality workmanship, minimize downtime, and reduce overall maintenance costs. A pre-inspection must be conducted to thoroughly assess the equipment's technical condition before repairs, identify the main defects present, and analyze the product-specific process requirements that influence the equipment's technical specifications—allowing for the immediate development of a repair plan. 3. Technical Preparation Before Equipment Maintenance Preparation for equipment maintenance involves two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness. The technical preparation prior to maintenance is the responsibility of the lead technician, and its main tasks include pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the actual pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation. Meanwhile, production readiness before the overhaul is managed by personnel responsible for spare parts, materials, and tools, as well as the production planners from the maintenance unit. Their primary responsibilities encompass ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, and specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipment—along with developing the overall maintenance production schedule. Pre-inspection survey preparation work To gain a comprehensive understanding of the specific condition of equipment degradation, schedule a shutdown inspection before the major overhaul—this is referred to as a pre-inspection. Before conducting the equipment pre-inspection, ensure the following preparatory investigations are completed. (1) Review the following equipment records: factory inspection reports; precision and performance verification records from equipment installation acceptance tests; details of all past equipment incidents, malfunctions, and repairs, including any remaining issues after repairs; records of all previous maintenance activities, including replaced or repaired components, as well as any unresolved problems left behind after servicing; and operational status monitoring logs and comprehensive equipment inspection records.

(2) Read the equipment manual and equipment catalog. (3) Survey equipment operators and maintenance personnel: Identify parts of the equipment that are prone to failures during operation and the underlying causes; assess the equipment’s precision and overall performance; highlight the major existing defects; and gather specific recommendations for repairs and improvements required during major overhauls. (4) Solicit input from departments such as Technology, Quality, and Production Management regarding localized equipment improvements. Pre-screening (1) The purpose of the pre-inspection. Through pre-inspection, we can comprehensively and thoroughly assess the deterioration of equipment conditions, gain a clearer understanding of how product processes affect the equipment’s precision and performance, thereby identifying which parts need to be replaced or repaired. This information then allows us to create detailed drawings or verify existing ones for these parts, ensuring they meet the requirements for manufacturing and repair work. (2) Pre-inspection content: Typically, the pre-inspection content is determined based on the equipment type and the pre-repair investigation. (3) Inspect geometric and operational accuracy item by item, according to the equipment manufacturer's precision standards and inspection methods for each country or enterprise. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance

29 Record the measured values. (4) Check the machine tool's operational condition: Verify whether the control system responds sensitively and reliably during movement; ensure that all movements meet the specified values; and confirm that the motion is smooth, without vibrations, noise, or stick-slip phenomena. (5) Inspect the machine tool guideways, lead screws, and racks for wear, and measure the extent of the wear. (6) Inspect the hydraulic, pneumatic, and lubrication systems: Verify that movements are accurate, check for any component damage or leaks, and if leaks are present, identify the cause. (7) Inspect the electrical system: Check whether electrical components are aged or malfunctioning. (8) Inspect safety protection devices: Verify that all limit switches and interlock mechanisms are sensitive and reliable, and check whether any of the indicator instruments or protective guards are damaged. (9) Inspect the equipment's appearance and accessories: Check for chipped paint, damage to any handles, ensure all labels are present, and verify that accessories are complete and free from wear or damage. (10) Partial disassembly inspection to determine whether parts need replacement or repair based on their wear condition. During the pre-inspection, especially large and complex castings and forgings, high-precision critical components, and purchased parts must be checked one by one to determine whether they need replacement or repair. Preparing overhaul technical documentation By conducting a pre-inspection to assess the equipment's condition and determine whether repairs or component replacements are necessary, we can then proceed to analyze, develop a repair plan, and prepare the corresponding technical documentation. These technical documents serve as the foundation for major equipment overhauls. Commonly used technical documents for equipment overhauls include the following types: (1) Prepare the equipment maintenance technical specification. The equipment maintenance technical specification should include the following content. ① The technical condition of the equipment before major overhaul. ② Key maintenance activities include detailing the disassembly, cleaning, and inspection of components to identify parts that require repair or replacement; briefly outlining the r epair methods for basic and critical components; specifying mechanisms that must be thoroughly inspected and adjusted, as well as other areas requiring attention; and highlighting  specific parts and aspects that can be improved during the overhaul process. ③ Maintenance quality requirements: Specify the names and numbers of the general technical standards ap plicable to each quality inspection during major equipment overhauls, and attach the content of any specialized technical standards to the back of the task specification. (2) Prepa ring Maintenance Procedures. The maintenance procedures for mechanical equipment are the technical documents that must be carefully followed and implemented during major overhauls.  When developing overhaul procedures, it’s essential to consider the actual conditions, ensuring both technical feasibility and economic viability. Mechanical equipment overhaul pr ocedures can be categorized into two types: standard maintenance procedures and specialized maintenance procedures. The overhaul procedures for mechanical equipment typically inclu de the following elements. ① Disassembly procedures and methods for the complete machine and its components, as well as the data to be monitored and precautions to observe during t he disassembly process.

② Inspection, maintenance, and assembly procedures for key components, as well as the technical specifications to be achieved. ③ The overall assembly proced ure and the precision requirements, technical specifications, and inspection/measurement methods that the assembly process must meet. ④ Adjustment processes for critical components  and the corresponding technical specifications to be achieved. ⑤ Test run procedures, specifications, and technical requirements to be achieved after final assembly. ⑥ Detailed li st of general or specialized tools, inspection and testing equipment, research fixtures, and measuring instruments required during major equipment overhauls, with specific notes in dicating items that are custom-made. ⑦ Safety measures during major overhaul operations, etc. (3) Major Maintenance Quality Standards. When accepting the repair of mechanical equip ment, reference can be made to general technical specifications for major equipment repairs established and issued by national and ministerial authorities, such as the General Tech nical Specifications for Major Repairs of Metal Cutting Machine Tools and the General Technical Specifications for Major Repairs of Forging and Pressing Equipment. Industries and e nterprises may also develop their own specialized quality standards for major equipment repairs based on these relevant general technical guidelines. A Practical Guide to Fault Dia gnosis and Repair Cases in Mechatronic Systems 30

If none of the above standards apply, refer to the equipment manufacturer's technical specifications. (4) Preparation of spare par ts, materials, and specialized tools, inspection equipment, and research fixtures. The lead technical personnel should promptly provide the management team with detailed lists of r eplacement parts, material specifications, as well as lists of specialized tools, inspection equipment, and research fixtures, along with relevant drawings. After verifying the inv entory, the management team will place orders or arrange for manufacturing to ensure that these items are available on time for use during major equipment overhauls. (5) Preparing  the Overhaul Work Plan. The overhaul work plan is prepared by the planning personnel in the maintenance department, who are responsible for equipment management. Personnel, chief t echnicians, and maintenance foremen (team leaders) review it together. The overhaul work plan includes: work procedures, the number of workers required for each phase and stage of  the job, along with the corresponding duration in days; requirements for seamless coordination between individual work phases; and details on projects that need to be outsourced to  external partners, including specific timeframes. A general overhaul work plan can be presented using a "bar chart" format, supplemented by necessary explanatory text. For overhauls of complex, high-precision, large-scale, and critical equipment, network scheduling techniques should be employed to ensure efficient resource utilization, shorten project timelines, and enhance overall economic benefits. 4. Material Preparation Before Equipment Maintenance Material preparation before equipment maintenance is a critically important task, serving as the essential logistical foundation for successful repairs. In practice, delays often occur due to insufficient availability of spare parts and components, disrupting the normal flow of maintenance work, prolonging downtime, and ultimately leading to inefficiencies and production losses. Therefore, it is imperative to strengthen material preparation efforts prior to equipment maintenance. After the lead maintenance technician has prepared detailed lists of replacement parts and materials, they should promptly hand these over to the responsible personnel managing spare parts and supplies. Once the inventory has been verified, these managers will place orders accordingly. Meanwhile, after finalizing the repair procedures, the lead maintenance technician must immediately provide the tool management team with detailed lists and drawings of specialized tools, inspection devices, and testing equipment. The tool management staff will then cross-check the existing inventory and forward any necessary items—such as specialized tools, inspection devices, or testing equipment—to the relevant departments for evaluation. Based on the evaluation results, if repairs are indeed required, the departments will arrange for the necessary maintenance activities. Additionally, the tool management team will initiate new procurement requests for any additional specialized tools, inspection devices, or testing equipment that may be needed. 1.4.2 General Process for Mechanical Equipment Maintenance

(2) During hydraulic transmission, vibrations must not occur at any speed, and there should be no noise or noticeable phenomena such as impact, stalling, or creeping. ( 3) The pressure gauge must be sensitive and reliable, with clear markings. The safety device for regulating pressure should be dependable and comply with the instructions provided  in the manual. (4) When the hydraulic system is operating, no foam should form in the oil tank, and the oil temperature should generally not exceed 60°C. If the ambient temperature  is higher than 35°C, the oil tank temperature must not rise above 70°C during continuous operation lasting 4 hours. (5) The hydraulic oil lines should be neatly arranged, with tub ing kept as short as possible. The inner walls of the oil pipes must be thoroughly cleaned, and the pipes must be free from crushing, obvious dents, or marks caused by impact. (6)  The oil tank and oil inlet should be equipped with a filtration system and an oil-level indicator. Both the inside and outside of the tank must be kept clean, and the indicator sho uld be clear and easily visible. (7) All oil return pipe outlets must extend below the oil level by a sufficient depth to prevent foaming and air intake. 4) Quality of the lubrication system (1) The lubrication system must be completely intact, and all lubricati on components—such as oil lines and oil holes—must be thoroughly cleaned to ensure unobstructed flow. Oil lines should be neatly arranged, with bends avoiding sharp right angles, a nd there must be no oil leaks at the joints. (2) All lubrication points should be equipped with appropriate oiling devices, such as oil cups, grease nipples, oil cans, or oiling ho les. Oil cups, grease nipples, and oil holes must have covers or plugs to prevent chips and dust from entering. (3) The oil level indicator must be clear, allowing easy observation  of the oil surface or the flow of lubricant drops. (4) When using capillary tubes for lubrication drip applications, a clean cotton thread must always be installed, and the oil tu be must extend above the oil level in the storage reservoir. 5) Quality of the electrical components

(1) Different-colored wires should be used for different circuits; if the same  color wire is employed, it must have insulating tubes of different colors fitted at both ends. (2) In the machine tool's control circuit, both ends of the wires should be fitted wi th numerical markers that match the wiring positions indicated on the terminal block. These marker numbers must be resistant to peeling off and staining. (3) For machine tool elect rical components, ensure their safety and reliability; they must not be damaged by cutting fluids, lubricants, or chips. (4) The insulation resistance at all grounded points of the  machine tool's electrical components must not be less than 1 MΩ when measured with a 500 V megohmmeter; additionally, the insulation resistance of motor windings (excluding wiring ) must be at least 0.5 MΩ. (5) Motors operated by magnetic contactors must be equipped with undervoltage protection. This ensures that the circuit is disconnected in the event of a  sudden power failure or a drop in supply voltage, and prevents automatic restart when power is restored. (6) To protect the machine tool's motor and electrical equipment from shor t circuits, it is essential to install a fusible fuse or a similar fast-acting protective device that meets technical specifications, as well as comply with safety requirements for  electrical installations. (7) The machine tool lighting circuit should use a power supply with a voltage no higher than 36V. (8) The machine tool base, as well as the electrical b ox and cabinet bodies, should be equipped with dedicated grounding screws and grounding wires. (9) The door covers of electrical boxes and cabinets should be equipped with latches. 6) The aesthetic quality of the machine tool (1) The external surfaces of machine tools that are not being machined should be sprayed with light gray paint, or painted in any othe r color as specified. (2) The inner walls of the electrical box, oil tank, spindle box, gearbox, and other enclosures should all be painted white or another light color. (3) The pa inting process must meet standards, with no peeling, flaking, wrinkling, or loss of surface gloss allowed. (4) All machine tool signs should be complete, clearly visible, and secur ely mounted in the correct position. (5) The surfaces of handwheels and handles should be smooth and shiny, with no signs of rust. (6) All machine tool guards and hole covers, amon g other components, must remain intact. (7) The unfinished surfaces of the machine tool’s auxiliary electrical components and attachments should all match the surface paint color of the machine tool itself.

7) Machine Tool Operation Test (1) The main drive mechanism of the machine tool should be started from the lowest speed and run sequentially through each gear stage, with each speed level maintained for at least 2 minutes. The highest speed should be run continuously for no less than 30 minutes, ensuring that the spindle bearings reach a stable temperature. For machine tools equipped with change gears, belt-driven variable-speed systems, or stepless transmissions, low-, medium-, and high-speed gear-shifting operations must also be performed. (2) When the spindle bearing reaches a stable temperature, check its temperature and temperature rise—these must not exceed the limits specified in Table 1.4.

Rolling bearing: 70°C vs. 40°C (3) The machine tool's feed mechanism should undergo no-load tests at low, medium, and high feed speeds, while the rapid traverse mechanism should be tested under no-load conditions at its maximum rapid-speed setting. (4) During the machine tool's operational test, all mechanisms undergo startup, stopping, braking, automatic motion, gear-shift transitions, and rapid movements. All should be flexible and reliable. (5) All hydraulic, lubrication, and cooling systems must be free of leaks. (6) The pneumatic system and piping must not have any air leaks. (7) The machine tool's safety guards and protective devices must be complete, secure, and function reliably and sensitively. (8) The machine tool's accuracy must be checked both before and after the load test. For machine tools that do not undergo a load test, accuracy verification should be performed after the no-load running test. 2. Precision Inspection of Mechanical Equipment Maintenance After major overhauls of mechanical equipment, acceptance checks are conducted according to established standards, with each type of equipment having its own specific acceptance criteria and inspection methods. Take metal cutting machine tools as an example: the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) has established various precision testing standards for different types of machine tools, along with general guidelines for machine tool accuracy verification. Similarly, China has developed its own standards that are either equivalent to or closely aligned with international benchmarks. These standards specify the inspection items, criteria, methods, and tolerances for machine tool accuracy—serving as the fundamental basis for conducting precision tests. Currently, machine tool maintenance is carried out based on both geometric and operational precision standards during acceptance procedures. Inspection of Machine Tool Geometric Accuracy Geometric accuracy of machine tools refers to the precision of the components that ultimately affect the machine's operational accuracy. It encompasses individual accuracies of basic structural elements, positional accuracy between various parts, as well as motion accuracy, positioning accuracy, indexing accuracy, and transmission chain accuracy. Typically, geometric accuracy checks are performed while the machine tool is stationary. Before conducting these inspections, it’s essential to first ensure proper installation and leveling. Follow the machine tool’s instruction manual carefully to install the equipment on a suitable foundation and achieve precise leveling. The primary goal of leveling is to guarantee the machine’s static stability, which facilitates accurate measurements during testing—especially those related to the straightness of machine components. Additionally, national standards have standardized methods for inspecting both geometric and operational accuracy of machine tools, providing a reliable reference for conducting geometric accuracy tests. Machine Tool Testing Since the geometric accuracy of machine tools is checked under static conditions, it cannot fully reflect the quality of machine tool maintenance. To determine  whether a machine tool can maintain its original geometric accuracy under operational conditions and load applications, it must be evaluated through various machine tool tests. Th e key components of machine tool maintenance testing include no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests. (1) No-load operation test of the machine tool. The pur pose of the no-load operation test is to further verify the correct functioning of each component of the machine tool. Sex, reliability, ease and normality of operation, as well as  whether the temperature rise and noise levels of each moving component are within acceptable limits. The primary focus of the machine tool's no-load running test is to simultaneou sly check the operational status of relevant parts while testing the spindle and feed speeds. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Mai ntenance 35 Before conducting the no-load operation test of the machine tool, ensure that all major overhaul tasks have been completed and that each repair has met the required qua lity standards. Next, fill all oil reservoirs with lubricant and properly grease all lubrication points. It is crucial to note: Only after completing all necessary preparations in  accordance with the safety operating procedures can you proceed with the no-load tests as outlined by the precision inspection standards specific to the machine tool being used. (2 ) Machine Tool Load Testing. The machine tool load test evaluates whether the machine’s main motion system can achieve the maximum torque and power allowed by the design, as well a s checks if all machine components are functioning properly under these conditions, whether there are any positional changes between parts, and if such changes remain within the pe rmissible limits. Additionally, it ensures that vibrations, noise levels, and temperature rise remain within normal operating ranges. The machine tool load test primarily involves  performing a cutting-load test, where tools and cutting parameters are selected according to specified requirements to machine the surface of test specimens made from a particular  material and in a specific size. During the load test, the spindle speed and feed rate are allowed to deviate by no more than 5% compared to the theoretical values. (3) Machine Too l Working Accuracy Test. The purpose of the machine tool working accuracy test is to determine whether the positional accuracy between the machine’s various components during the m achining process meets the precision requirements of the parts being manufactured. Before the test, its geometric accuracy must be rechecked. The machine tool working accuracy test  involves machining the surface of a specified test piece using cutting tools and appropriate cutting parameters, as outlined in the machine tool accuracy testing standards for wor king precision requirements. The geometric accuracy of the machined workpiece surface must fall within the tolerance range specified by the precision standards of the machine tool  used, and the surface roughness value should not exceed the prescribed standard.

1.4.3 General Principles and Requirements for Mechanical Equipment Disassembly Any piece of machine ry is assembled from numerous components. When machinery requires maintenance, it must first be disassembled so that faulty parts can be repaired or replaced. The primary purpose o f dismantling machinery is to facilitate the inspection and repair of its components; in fact, the disassembly process typically accounts for about 20% of the total maintenance wor kload. Therefore, to ensure high-quality repairs, it’s essential to carefully plan ahead and anticipate potential challenges before starting to take apart the equipment. This way,  the dismantling can proceed methodically—following a structured approach that adheres to the following rules and guidelines. Preparations Before Disassembly (1) Selection and Cleanup of the Disassembly Site. Before disassembly, choose an appropriate work area—avoid locations prone to windblown sand or dust. The workspace should be kept free from frequent unauthorized access by unrelated personnel to prevent unnecessary disruptions or accidents. Additionally, ensure that the ground in the work area remains clean, free from dirt, oil, or other contaminants. Prior to entering the disassembly site, all machinery must undergo an external cleaning process to guarantee that the disassembly procedure does not compromise the equipment’s precision. (2) Protective Measures: Before cleaning the exterior of mechanical equipment, electrical devices should be either removed or properly protected to prevent moisture damage. Additionally, parts prone to oxidation and rust should promptly undergo appropriate protective and maintenance measures. (3) Draining the oil before disassembly. Whenever possible, drain the lubricating oil from the machinery while it’s still hot prior to disassembly, ensuring smoother and more efficient removal work. (4) Understand the structure, performance, and operating principles of mechanical equipment. To avoid unnecessary disassembly and ensure the smooth progress of maintenance work, thoroughly assess all aspects of the machinery before dismantling. Familiarize yourself with the structural features of each component, the transmission system, as well as the specific design characteristics and interrelationships of individual parts. Clearly identify their intended functions and how they interact with one another, enabling you to plan the disassembly process logically and select the appropriate tools or equipment for the job. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial

General Principles for Disassembly (1) Based on the structural characteristics of the mechanical equipment, select a logical disassembly sequence. Typically, the process involves dismantling from the overall unit into subassemblies, then breaking down subassemblies into individual components, and finally separating components into their constituent parts—or alternatively, proceeding from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward. When disassembling particularly complex components, it’s essential to thoroughly study the assembly drawings and carefully analyze the component’s structure as well as the specific roles its parts play within the assembly. Pay special attention to components that require high precision during assembly. This approach helps prevent confusion, ensures an orderly disassembly process, and ultimately facilitates cleaning, inspection, and identification—laying a solid foundation for effective maintenance work. (2) Rational disassembly. During the maintenance and disassembly of mechanical equipment, adhere to the principle of avoiding unnecessary disassembly while ensuring that components requiring removal are indeed taken apart. (3) Use disassembly tools and equipment correctly. After understanding the steps involved in removing mechanical components, it’s crucial to select and properly apply the appropriate disassembly tools. When dismantling, always opt for specialized or suitably matched tools and equipment whenever possible, avoiding random hammering or forceful techniques to prevent damage or deformation of the parts. For instance, when removing shaft sleeves, rolling bearings, gears, pulleys, and similar components, use pullers or hydraulic presses; and for unscrewing studs or nuts, always prefer wrenches that match their dimensions precisely. Precautions During Disassembly: When performing mechanical equipment maintenance, disassembly should also take into account the subsequent assembly tasks. To ensure a smooth process, keep the following points in mind. (1) Ensure thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts. Mechanical equipment often contains numerous precisely matched components and parts, many of which have been specifically selected or balanced for weight—meaning their assembly positions and orientations must not be altered under any circumstances. Therefore, when dismantling, carefully check parts that already bear original markings. If these markings are unclear, misaligned, or missing altogether, re-mark them exactly as they were originally to ensure proper alignment during reassembly, preventing any confusion or errors. (2) Store parts by category. When storing disassembled parts, follow these principles: Parts belonging to the same type or component should be kept together whenever possible; store items according to their size and precision level; non-interchangeable parts must be stored separately in groups; delicate components that are sensitive to dirt or damage should be removed and stored individually; rubber parts should never be stored alongside oil-bearing components; and ensure that easily lost items are carefully accounted for. Parts such as washers and nuts should be strung together with wire or stored in dedicated containers; all types of studs must be fitted with nuts before being placed in storage. Additionally, parts like steel components, aluminum items, rubber pieces, and leather goods should be stored separately in different containers, categorized by their respective material types. (3) Protect the machined surfaces of removed parts. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apart—doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment. 1.4.4 Disassembly Methods for Commonly Used Components The disassembly of commonly used components should follow general disassembly principles, while also considering their specific characteristics and employing appropriate methods tailored to each component in order to achieve the intended purpose. 1. Disassembly of the Spindle Assembly To prevent reduced assembly accuracy due to improper disassembly, mark the relative positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and spindles around the circumference during removal. After disassembling, group each bearing along with its corresponding inner and outer washers separately and store them in distinct locations—do not mix them up. Ensure that the workbench and surrounding area at the disassembly site remain clean, and immediately place all removed parts into oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them according to their original marked orientations. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment

Disassembly of the Gear Pair To improve the precision of the transmission chain, the gear pair with a transmission ratio of 1 is assembled using an error-compensation method: specifically, the tooth space at the point of maximum radial runout on one external gear is engaged with the tooth space at the point of minimum radial runout on the other gear. To prevent errors introduced during reassembly from remaining unresolved, a mark is made at the mating points of the two gears during disassembly, ensuring that the original precision can be restored during reassembly. Removing Axially Positioned Parts

When disassembling shaft components from the gearbox, it is essential to first determine the direction of the shaft's steps, which will dictate the movement direction during removal.
