55 2.1 Repair and Assembly of Shaft Components

2.1.1 Main Failure Modes of Shaft-Type Components Shaft-type components are among the most critical parts in mechanical equipment, directly influencing both the operational precision and longevity of machinery. Their primary function is to support rotating components while transmitting motion and torque. Shafts can be categorized into three main types: rotating shafts (e.g., lathe spindles, shafts with pulleys), stationary shafts (e.g., train axle wheels, bicycle axles, or car front axles), and transmission shafts (e.g., leadscrews used on lathes). These shaft components are primarily designed to withstand various loads and efficiently transfer power. Structure Composition of the Shaft As shown in Figure 2.1, the shaft consists of three parts. 1—Shaft; 2, 5—Shaft ends; 3—Journal; 4—Shaft body Figure 2.1: Structural Components of the Shaft Axle head: The part that mates with transmission components or couplings and clutches. Journal: The part that fits into the bearing. Shaft body: The section connecting the shaft head and the shaft journal. Failure Modes of Shaft Components The main failure modes include fatigue fracture due to insufficient fatigue strength, plastic deformation or brittle fracture caused by inadequate static strength, wear, deformation exceeding allowable limits, and vibration, among others. Performance Requirements for Shaft Components The performance requirements for shaft-type components include sufficient tensile strength and stiffness; adequate impact toughness and high fatigue resistance; excellent machinability and hardenability; and, for friction-prone areas at the shaft journals, high hardness and wear resistance. Manufacturing Materials for Shaft Components Manufacturing materials typically include low-carbon steel, medium-carbon steel, or alloy steel, which are either forged or rolled. 2.1.2 Methods for Disassembling Shaft-Type Components Disassembly is part of the repair process; when cleaning equipment, disassembly should be performed first. However, after disassembly, assembly accuracy tends to decrease. A Case Study Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Mechatronic Systems 56

Phenomenon After dismantling and cleaning the equipment components, it is impossible to restore them to their original mating precision. Cause Analysis The disassembly and cleaning work did not meet the required standards; additionally, the removed parts were poorly stored, resulting in moisture damage or physical injury—and in some cases, individual parts were even lost and replaced with substitutes. Hazardousness Hazardousness refers to the decline in mechanical equipment performance, potentially leading to complete failure and rendering the equipment unusable. Prevention and Control Measures

(1) The work area for disassembly and cleaning must be kept clean; dusty environments or outdoor locations are prohibited. If it is necessary to carry out the work outdoors, dust-control measures must be implemented. (2) Before disassembly, you must familiarize yourself with the drawings. Proceed step-by-step according to the diagrams, and mark the mating components clearly, ensuring that the markings are consistent, unambiguous, and easily visible. If the components already have existing marks, verify them thoroughly before proceeding with disassembly. When disassembling identical yet numerous components, provide a schematic diagram and mark them according to the numbers shown on the diagram. (3) Removed parts must be stored properly and protected from moisture, damage, or loss.

(4) For components that need to be heated before removal, the heating temperature should be maintained according to the design specifications or the equipment manufacturer’s instructions. (5) Machine parts are typically cleaned with kerosene, but precision components or rolling bearings must be washed again with gasoline after being thoroughly cleaned with kerosene. (6) All debris such as sediment, sand, or dirty oil inside oil holes and oil passages must be thoroughly removed, and then sealed with wooden plugs—never use cotton yarn or cloth scraps as substitutes for the plugs. (7) After cleaning, mechanical equipment components that cannot be assembled immediately should be properly stored to prevent dust from entering. (8) When assembling equipment components, first inspect the surface shapes and dimensional accuracy of parts relevant to the assembly. Only proceed with assembly after confirming they meet the required specifications.

Removal Method (1) Striking and Disengaging. Striking involves using the force of a hammer to create relative movement between mating parts, allowing them to separate and achieve disassembly. This is a straightforward method suitable for simpler structures or when dealing with robust, non-critical components. When striking, proceed with caution—improper technique could easily damage the parts. Common tools used for this method include steel hammers, copper hammers, wooden mallets, punches, as well as copper, aluminum, and wooden shims. When removing rolling bearings by striking, always tap symmetrically from both sides; never concentrate the blows on just one side, as this could lead to cracking of the bearing raceway. (2) Press and pull disassembly. Press and pull methods are superior to impact disassembly because they apply force more evenly, allowing precise control over both the magnitude and direction of the force. As a result, these techniques reduce the risk of part misalignment or damage. This method is particularly suitable for dismantling larger components or parts with significant interference fits. Commonly used tools for this process include press benches and pull molds. (3) Hot disassembly. Hot disassembly leverages the thermal expansion properties of metals to separate parts, preventing issues like parts getting stuck or damaged—something that can occur with methods like impact or press disassembly. This technique is commonly used when the interference fit is significant (exceeding 0.1 mm), the components are large in size, or traditional disassembly methods prove impractical. In summary, choose the appropriate removal method based on how the parts fit together. If it’s a transition fit, you can use a tapping method. Remove the part; if it’s a press-fit assembly, you can use either press-off or heat-based disassembly methods. After removal, place the parts on a wooden board or a low surface. Chapter 2: Troubleshooting and Repair of Commonly Used Components 57 On the platform; smaller parts such as screws, nuts, washers, pins, and others can be placed in dedicated boxes. Long, slender components like spindles and lead screws can be hung vertically to prevent bending or deformation. Disassembly of spindle components: The relative positions of parts such as the housing and spindle are ensured using an error-compensation method. To prevent improper disassembly that could compromise assembly accuracy, make sure to mark the circumferential positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and the spindle itself during disassembly. After removal, arrange the bearings and inner/outer washers separately into their respective groups—never mix them up. Additionally, keep the workbench and surrounding area thoroughly clean during disassembly, and immediately immerse removed parts in oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them precisely according to the original markings. 2.1.3 Cleaning, Inspection, and Repair After Shaft Removal

Cleaning After Shaft Removal Cleaning the disassembled mechanical parts is a crucial step in maintenance work. The cleaning method and the quality of removal directly impact the accuracy of parts inspection. Certainty, the quality of equipment repair, maintenance costs, and service life will all be significantly impacted. Part cleaning involves removing oil stains, scale, carbon deposits, rust layers, and old paint coatings. The tools required for cleaning include wrenches, circlip pliers, cleaning solutions, grease, a hairdryer, cloths, needles, and a container specifically designed for soaking the shaft. Here’s a simple cleaning procedure: ① Remove the shaft from its position; ② Immerse and scrub the shaft in the cleaning solution; ③ Rinse the thoroughly cleaned shaft to remove any remaining residue; ④ Use a hairdryer to dry the shaft completely (drying prevents rusting); ⑤ Apply lubricating grease to protect against dust, water, and ensure smooth operation; ⑥ Once greased, reattach the side cover before proceeding with installation. 2. Inspection of the Spindle The main forms of spindle damage include journal wear, surface scratches, and the resulting roundness errors, concentricity errors, and bending deformation. Including cone hole dam age, keyway cracks, and thread failures. Common checks for the coaxiality of each spindle journal are shown in Figure 2.2. 1—Spindle; 2—Plug; 3—Steel ball; 4—Support plate; 5—V-sha ped frame; 6—Inspection flat plate Figure 2.2: Common Methods for Checking the Coaxiality of Each Journal on the Main Shaft The spindle 1 is placed on two V-shaped supports 5 mount ed on the inspection plate 6. The rear end of the spindle is fitted with a plug 2, which features a steel ball 3 positioned at the center hole and resting against the support plate  4. At each journal of the spindle, a dial indicator tip is brought into contact with the journal surface. By rotating the spindle, the difference in movement indicated by the dial  gauge pointer directly reflects the coaxial error. Additionally, the circular runout error at the shoulder end face can also be measured using the dial indicator positioned at the  end face. Generally, coaxial error should be kept within 0.015, and the face runout error should be less than 0.01 mm. As for the spindle taper bore... The radial runout error of  the spindle centerline relative to the bearing journal can be checked by inserting a tapered shank gauge into the properly positioned spindle taper bore. Then, touch the dial indic ator probe to two points on the tapered shank gauge—one near the spindle end and the other 300 mm away—and rotate the spindle while observing the dial indicator readings. The indic ator can be used to measure the radial circular runout of the tapered hole's centerline relative to the spindle bearing journal. A Practical Guide to Fault Diagnosis and Maintenanc e in Mechatronic Systems 58

3. Spindle Maintenance Under normal circumstances, the primary failure modes of spindles are bending deformation caused by external loads, as well as we ar on the mating surfaces. If a spindle becomes deformed, the repair method should be determined based on the extent of the deformation and the spindle's precision requirements. Fo r ordinary-precision spindles that have undergone bending deformation, straightening is an effective repair technique. However, for high-precision spindles, straightening often fai ls to restore their original accuracy, making it necessary to replace the spindle with a new one. After the spindle journal wears down, it usually needs to be restored to its origi nal dimensions. Commonly used methods include brush plating and chrome plating. The process for repairing the spindle using brush plating involves: first, inserting plugs into the  holes at both ends of the spindle; then, drilling a center hole in the plugs; next, precisely aligning the spindle on a grinding machine, using the unworn portions of the front and  rear journals as reference points; followed by grinding down the worn journal areas by 0.05 to 0.15 mm; finally, applying brush plating to the targeted outer cylindrical surfaces,  ensuring that the single-sided coating thickness is at least 0.1 mm. After brushing, the ground surfaces are carefully lapped to meet the required specifications. Additionally, th e spindle's Morse taper bore is also prone to wear, and during maintenance, its surface accuracy is often restored through grinding. If the spindle has undergone multiple rounds of  grinding, it can eventually be repaired by installing a sleeve. 2.2 Assembly Requirements for Interference-Fit Fasteners

An interference fit involves fitting a larger component (t he shaft) into a smaller one (the hole). This type of connection can withstand significant axial forces, torque, and dynamic loads, while also providing high alignment accuracy and  wide-ranging applications. For instance, it’s commonly used to join gears, couplings, flywheels, sprockets, pulleys, and other components to their respective shafts, as well as in  the assembly of bearings with their housing sleeves. In an interference fit, since the shaft is larger in size than the hole, assembly must be carried out using methods such as applying pressure or employing thermal expansion/contraction techniques. Interference fits are primarily used for tight connections between holes and shafts where relative motion is not permitted—such as in the secure attachment of gear rims to wheel hubs in large gears. An interference fit is a type of fixed joint that not only demands precise positioning and reliable clamping but also ensures that the assembly process does not compromise the strength or accuracy of the components, while allowing for easy and rapid installation. The mating surfaces in interference connections can take various forms, including cylindrical, conical, and other specialized shapes. The assembly technical requirements for interference fit connections are as follows: (1) Accurate interference fit must be ensured to meet the design requirements after assembly. (2) The mating surface should have a low surface roughness. (3) Before assembly, ensure that the mating surfaces are clean, and make sure these surfaces are properly lubricated with oil. (4) The pressing process should be continuous, with a speed that is not too fast (typically 2.4 mm/s), and the pressing stroke must be accurately controlled. (5) During the pressing process, ensure that the axis of the shaft aligns perfectly with the axis of the hole. Regularly check using a 90° square to prevent any tilting. (6) For slender and thin-walled components, special attention should be paid to controlling the interference fit and geometric tolerances. During assembly, it's best to press them in vertically to prevent deformation of the parts. 2.3 Maintenance and Assembly of Sliding Bearings Sliding bearings feature a simple structure, ease of manufacturing, convenient assembly and disassembly, strong load-carrying capacity, as well as excellent shock resistance and vibration-absorbing properties. It features smooth operation, stable performance, and high rotational precision, making it ideal for applications involving exceptionally high operating speeds, extremely heavy loads, stringent requirements for shaft rotational accuracy, significant shock and vibration, limited radial space dimensions, or situations requiring split-type installation (such as bearings in crankshafts), as well as environments with specialized operational conditions. The main drawbacks are high starting friction resistance and demanding lubrication and maintenance requirements. Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of General-Purpose Components

Below, we'll use a solid sliding bearing as an example to introduce its assembly method. (1) Press-fitting the bushing. Depending on the bushing size and the amount of interference fit, assembly is carried out either by hammering or press-fitting. For smaller dimensions and lighter interference fits, the bushing can be tapped into place using a hand hammer and a backing plate. When the bushing size and interference are larger, a hydraulic press should be used for assembly. If the interference exceeds 0.1 mm, the assembly process involves heating the housing or cooling the bushing to facilitate proper fitting. (2) Fixed bushing. After the bushing is press-fitted, it can be secured against rotation using screws, locating pins, or similar fasteners. (3) Inspection and Adjustment After Assembly. After the bushing is assembled, methods such as reaming, scraping, or honing can be used to ensure that the clearance and contact points between the bushing and the journal meet the specified requirements. 2.3.1 Failure Modes of Sliding Bearings (1) Abrasive wear. Hard particles grinding against the shaft and bearing surfaces cause abrasive wear. (2) Scratches. Hard contour peak tips on the shaft surface scrape against the bearing, resulting in scratches. (3) Galling (adhesion). Galling occurs when temperatures rise, pressure increases, or the oil film breaks down. (4) Fatigue spalling. Repeated loading causes fatigue cracks to propagate, leading to spalling. (5) Corrosion. Oxidation of the lubricant produces acidic substances that cause corrosive damage.

2.3.2 Installation and Maintenance of Sliding Bearings Sliding bearings are characterized by their reliable operation, smooth performance, quietness, strong vibration absorption due to the lubricating oil film, and ability to withstand significant impact loads. Sliding bearings can be categorized into various structural types, such as integral and split designs, as shown in Figure 2.3. Figure 2.3: Sliding Bearing Basic Requirements for Sliding Bearing Installation (1) Before installation, burrs and sharp edges on the parts of the sliding bearing should be removed, and the contact surfaces must be smooth and clean. (2) When installing the bearing housing, the bearing or bushing should be fitted onto the housing and aligned according to the center position of the bushing or shaft sleeve. All bearings on the same transmission shaft must lie on a single axis, with their coaxial error remaining within the specified tolerance range. The bottom surface of the bearing housing must also be properly aligned with the machine components. The contact surfaces should make even, tight contact, and the fixed connections must be secure. During operation, there should be no signs of loosening or shifting. (3) The contact condition between the bearing and the shaft surface can be checked using the dye-penetration method, and the number of contact points must meet the specified requirements. (4) When the shaft is rotating, no rotation of the bearing bush or shaft sleeve is permitted. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial

60 (5) When adjusting the clearance of split washers, ensure that the bearing surfaces have good contact accuracy and a proper clearance. (6) During installation, ensure that lubricating oil flows freely into the bearing and that there is an adequate reserve of oil within the bearing to form a proper oil film. Additionally, verify the quality of the sealing device to prevent oil from leaking out of the bearing, while also keeping dust from entering the bearing.

2. Installation of Integral Sliding Bearings (1) Press-fit the sleeve. When the sleeve dimensions and interference fit are relatively small, a press-fitting method can be used—installing the sleeve by applying pressure with a press or gently tapping it into place using a hardwood block. For larger dimensions and interference fits, or when installing thin-walled sleeves, the thermal expansion method is recommended: cool the sleeve in dry ice or liquid nitrogen before fitting it into the bearing housing. During the press-fitting process, ensure that the mating surfaces are clean and apply a thin layer of lubricant to prevent the sleeve from becoming skewed. (2) Sleeve positioning. After pressing the sleeve into place, its position should be secured using the fastening screws or locating pins as specified in the drawing, to prevent the sleeve from rotating along with the shaft. The method for fixing the sleeve is shown in Figure 2.4. Figure 2.4: Method of Shaft Sleeve Fixation (3) Bore the bushing hole. After the bushing is press-fitted, the interference fit on the outer wall may cause the inner bore to shrink or deform. Therefore, reaming or scraping should be performed to ensure that the contact points between the bushing and the journal meet the specified standards. 3. Diagnosis and Maintenance of Sliding Bearings 1) The contact angle of the plain bearing bush does not meet the requirements. (1) Phenomenon: The contact angle between the bearing bush and the journal does not meet the standard requirements. (2) Cause analysis: Failure to follow the operational guidelines strictly during scraping, careless work practices, and weak foundational skills in the relevant techniques. (3) Harmfulness. If the contact angle between the bearing bush and the journal is too large, it becomes difficult for a lubricating oil film to form, resulting in inadequate lubrication. As a result, bearing wear is accelerated. If the contact angle is too small, it increases the pressure on the bearing, which in turn leads to rapid wear of the bearing as well. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: The contact angle between the bearing bush and the journal should be appropriately sized, typically maintained between 60° and 90°. For high-speed, low-load applications, The bearing contact angle can be set at 60°, while for low-speed, heavy-duty bearings, a contact angle of 90° is recommended. Babbitt metal scraping should be performed only after the equipment has been precisely leveled. The scraping process involves two key areas: first, scraping the contact surface between the babbitt backing (babbitt back) and the bearing housing; and second, scraping the contact area between the babbitt lining and the journal. The scraping and lapping of the bearing shell with the bearing housing should also not be overlooked. Specific requirements are as follows: the contact area between the lower bearing shell and the bearing seat must be at least 50% of the total surface area, while the contact area between the upper bearing shell and the bearing cap should be no less than 40%. Additionally, the contact points between the bearing shells and both the bearing housing and bearing cap should ideally consist of 1 to 2 points per cm². If the contact area is too small or the number of contact points is insufficient, it will cause the bearing bush to... Increased pressure per unit area accelerates the wear of the bearing bushing. When scraping the bearing bushing, all components on the shaft should be fully assembled. Typically, scraping begins with the lower half of the bushing before moving to the upper half. During the scraping process, a thin layer of red lead oil can be applied to the journal, and the journal is gently inserted into the bushing. Then, the shaft is rotated—first in one direction, then in the opposite—to ensure even contact across both halves of the bushing. This allows the bushing and journal to rub against each other. Afterward, the shaft is carefully lifted, and based on the condition of the scraped surface, it’s determined whether the contact angle and contact points meet the specified requirements. If they don’t, further adjustments using additional steps are necessary. Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Commonly Used Components

61 Scraping with a scraper. During scraping and lapping, within the 60°–90° contact angle range, the contact points should be dense in the middle, gradually becoming sparser toward the sides—this should not occur. The contact surface should have a clear boundary between the contacting and non-contacting areas. The scraping method for the upper bearing shell is identical to that used for the lower shell. When applying color to the shells, first securely install the upper shell, remove the shims from the shell opening, and then tighten the bearing cap firmly with screws—ensuring that the upper shell makes proper contact with the journal. 2) Insufficient contact points between the journal and bearing bushing (1) Phenomenon: The contact points between the bearing bush and the journal do not meet the requirements of the general construction and acceptance standards. (2) Cause analysis: The procedure and method used for scraping the bearing were inappropriate, and the operator was careless and inattentive, neglecting quality control during the process. (3) Hazardousness. Due to the contact points between the bearing bush and the journal not meeting the specified standards, this can cause the bearing bush to overheat during equipment operation, disrupting normal functioning. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: When scraping and lapping the bearing shells, follow the prescribed process procedures. After rotating the journal shaft back and forth once inside the bearing shell, evenly remove any black spots that appear using a scraper—each time you scrape, rotate the tool to a new direction, ensuring the resulting scratches form intersecting angles of 60° to 90°. At the contact and non-contact areas, there should be no obvious boundary; when touching the bearing surface with your hand, it should feel exceptionally smooth.

3) Bearing overheating (1) Phenomenon: During equipment trial operation, bearing temperatures gradually increased, exceeding the specified requirements. (2) Cause analysis: Excessive or insufficient lubricating oil inside the bearing, or even complete absence of oil; impure lubricant can also lead to bearing overheating; and improper bearing assembly (such as misalignment, skewing, or lack of clearance). (3) Hazardous Effects: The materials used for bearings typically have lower strength and hardness compared to the materials used for shafts (e.g., in sliding bearings). When bearings overheat, this can lead to wear of the bearing alloy—under severe conditions, the alloy may even melt, causing the machinery to come to a halt. For rolling bearings, overheating also accelerates wear, significantly reducing their service life. (4) Prevention and Control Measures. First, thoroughly clean the lubrication system, then add the appropriate lubricant—selected according to the specified grade and quantity—as per the design requirements.
Seek the appropriate lubricant. For bearings that have been improperly assembled, readjust them until they meet the design and specification requirements.

4) Shaft Heating (1) Phenomenon: The transmission shaft heats up during operation. (2) Cause analysis. On one hand, the oil-seal pad or rubber ring on the shaft is too tight, causing heat generation due to friction during rotation. On the other hand, the clearance between the bearing cap and the shaft varies unevenly around the circumference, leading to shaft abrasion and, consequently, shaft heating. (3) Hazardous Effects. When the shaft's temperature rises, it reduces the shaft's hardness, accelerates wear, and also leads to damage in other components connected to the shaft. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: Replace the spring inside the rubber ring with a looser one, or loosen the bearing cap screws. Also, check whether the clearance between the bearing cap and the shaft complies with the specifications outlined in the equipment’s technical documentation. If it does not meet the requirements, make sure to adjust it carefully. 5) Bearing oil leakage (1) Phenomenon: Lubricant oil leakage from the bearing cap area during equipment operation. (2) Root cause analysis: The lubrication system is supplying excessive oil, resulting in excessively high oil pressure in the pressure lines—far exceeding the specified standards. Additionally, the return oil holes or pipes for the bearings are too small in size, while the number of oil seals is insufficient or improperly installed. As a result, oil leaks through gaps at the bearing housing due to inadequate sealing between the oil seal grooves and other components. (3) Hazardous effects: It depletes lubricating oil, fails to adequately ensure proper lubrication of the bearing itself, and leads to contamination of the equipment. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: Adjust the oil supply in the lubrication system to ensure an appropriate oil level; increase the diameter of the return oil pipe; properly repair the oil-seal groove and install the oil seals correctly; finally, tighten the bearing caps securely. 62 2.4 Installation and Adjustment of Rolling Bearings 2.4.1 Types and Fits of Rolling Bearings Structure and Features of Rolling Bearings The structure of the rolling bearing is shown in Figure 2.5. The inner ring 1 is mounted on the shaft; the outer ring 2 is fitted into the bearing housing bore; the rolling elements… The rolling element No. 3 is housed between the inner and outer rings; the cage No. 4 evenly spaces the rolling elements. Open.

Types of Rolling Bearings 1) By the direction of the load borne by the bearing or according to the nominal contact angle Category (1) Radial bearings. Radial contact bearings primarily withstand radial loads. Well, some can handle smaller axial loads; angular contact radial bearings. The bearing can simultaneously handle both radial and axial loads. (2) Thrust bearings. Thrust angular contact bearings primarily handle axial loads. The bearing can also handle smaller radial loads; axial thrust bearings, however, are designed only to withstand axial loads. 2) Classified by the shape of the rolling element Rolling bearings can be classified into ball bearings and roller bearings. 3) Classified by Whether the Working Shaft Can Be Centered Rolling bearings can be classified into self-aligning bearings and non-self-aligning bearings. 4) Classification Based on Whether Clearance Can Be Adjusted Rolling bearings can be classified into bearings with adjustable clearance and those with non-adjustable clearance. 3. Selection of Rolling Bearing Types Selection principle: Match bearing characteristics with operating conditions. 1) Type Selection (1) Load conditions. If the bearing is subjected to axial loads, thrust bearings are typically selected; if the load is purely axial, For smaller loads, thrust ball bearings are re commended; if the pure axial load is significant, thrust roller bearings should be chosen. When the bearing is subjected to pure radial loads, deep groove ball bearings, cylindrica l roller bearings, or needle roller bearings are typically used. If the bearing handles both radial and moderate axial loads simultaneously, deep groove ball bearings, angular cont act ball bearings with small contact angles, or tapered roller bearings are suitable options. For situations involving heavier axial loads, angular contact ball bearings with large r contact angles or tapered roller bearings are ideal. Alternatively, a combined design—using both radial and thrust bearings—can be employed, with each type of bearing specificall y handling either the radial or axial load. (2) Rotational speed requirements. When high speed and precise rotation are needed, ball bearings should be used as the preferred option . (3) Self-aligning capability requirement: When the shaft is long (with low rigidity) or has multiple support points and requires bearings with self-aligning features, choose self -aligning bearings. (4) Load-carrying and shock-resistant capabilities. Use roller bearings when dealing with heavy loads or impact loads. (5) Space limitations. Use roller bearing s when radial dimensions are restricted. 1—Inner race; 2—Outer race; 3—Rolling element; 4—Cage Figure 2.5: Structure of a Rolling Bearing

Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Commonly Used Components, p. 63 (6) Easy to assemble and disassemble. Choose tapered roller or cylindrical roller bearings when the i nner and outer rings are separable; opt for bearings with an internal taper bore and set-sleeve mounting when installing on long shafts. (7) Price: Ball bearings are low in price,  while roller bearings are higher. 2) Size Selection Model selection: inner diameter, outer diameter, width, selected type, preliminary model, and life verification. 4. Fit of Rolli ng Bearings The bearing fit refers to the mating between the inner ring and the journal, as well as the outer ring and the housing, influencing the bearing's radial clearance, oper ational accuracy, and service life. Rolling bearings are standard components, and the fit between the bearing bore and the shaft follows the hole basis system, while the fit betwee n the outer ring and the bearing housing uses the shaft basis system. Since the tolerance zone for the bearing inner diameter lies below the zero line, whereas in cylindrical toler ance standards, the tolerance zone for the reference hole is above the zero line, the interference fit between the inner ring and the journal is significantly tighter than the corr esponding hole-basis fits specified in cylindrical tolerance standards. Figures 2.6 and 2.7 illustrate the fit of rolling bearings and their relationship to deviations in the dimen sions of the journal or housing bore relative to the bearing’s reference surfaces (inner ring inner diameter, outer ring outer diameter). When designing, the type and size of the b earing, as well as the magnitude of the load, should guide the selection of the appropriate fit. For applications with large dimensions, heavy loads, significant vibrations, high r otational speeds, or elevated operating temperatures, a tighter fit is recommended. However, excessively tight fits can impair the bearing’s proper function and also make assembly  and disassembly more challenging. On the other hand, for components that require frequent removal or where the raceways experience movement, a looser fit should be chosen. However,  excessive looseness is detrimental to improving bearing rotational accuracy and reducing vibration. As shown in Figure 2.7, the rotating shaft typically fitted with the inner ring  of the bearing is Use interference fits N6, M6, K6, or k5, or transition fits j5 and J6; bearing housing bores that are paired with non-rotating outer rings typically employ transition fits J6 and J7, or clearance fits such as H7 and G7. Figure 2.6: Fit between the outer ring of the rolling bearing and the bearing housing, and between the inner ring of the rolling bearing and the shaft Figure 2.7: Case Studies in Mechanical and Electrical System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance—Diagnosing Failures in the Fit Between the Bearing Inner Race and Rotating Shaft, as Well as Between the Bearing and Stationary Outer Race, Tutorial 64 2.4.2 Failure Modes of Rolling Bearings

1. Load Distribution Pure axial load: Rolling elements are evenly loaded. Radial load: Uneven loading of rolling elements (loaded and unloaded zones). 2. Failure Modes of Rolling Bearings Pitting: Numerous pitting marks appear on the raceways of both the inner and outer rings, as well as on the surfaces of the rolling elements—primarily caused by improper loading, incorrect assembly (e.g., excessive interference fit or misalignment of the inner and outer rings), and inadequate lubrication. Plastic Deformation: Uneven plastic deformation pits appear on the rolling elements or raceway surfaces, primarily due to excessive static or impact loads. Other forms include abrasive wear, adhesive wear, fracture, rusting, electrochemical corrosion, and abnormal temperature rise, among others.

The main factors influencing rolling bearing failure include load conditions, lubrication, assembly practices, environmental factors, and material quality or manufacturing precision. When determining bearing dimensions, it's essential to perform the necessary calculations tailored to the primary failure modes. For rotating rolling bearings under typical operating conditions, both contact fatigue life and static strength analyses are usually required. In contrast, for oscillating or low-speed bearings, only a static strength calculation is sufficient. Meanwhile, high-speed bearings are prone to adhesive wear and scoring caused by heat generation, making these failure modes their main concerns. Therefore, in addition to conducting life calculations, it’s also crucial to verify the bearing’s limiting speed. 2.4.3 Disassembly, Cleaning, and Inspection of Rolling Bearings

When designing bearing assemblies, consider the ease of installation and removal to prevent damage to the bearing and other components during these processes. Bearing installation: Small bearings can be gently and evenly tapped into place using a copper hammer to fit the retaining rings; larger bearings should be pressed in with a hydraulic press. Bearings that are large in size and tightly fitted can be heated to expand the bore before assembly. Bearing installation and removal: Specialized tools can be used; when designing the structure, ensure ease of bearing installation and removal. 1. Disassembling Rolling Bearings Disassembling rolling bearings is an essential part of mechanical maintenance. Since rolling bearings are tightly fitted to the shaft, significant force is required to remove them. If the disassembly method is improper, not only may the bearing fail to come off, but if the fit is particularly tight—with a large interference—the process could also damage the bearing and its associated components. Here, we introduce several commonly used methods for removing bearings. (1) Heating Disassembly Method. If the bearing is tightly fitted and has a significant interference fit, the bearing must be heated to induce thermal expansion, causing elastic deformation that allows for easy removal. For instance, you can wrap the shaft near the bearing with asbestos cloth and then heat the inner race of the bearing using an acetylene-oxygen flame—this method enables disassembly while heating continues. However, it’s crucial to heat slowly, keeping the temperature around 100°C to prevent damage to the bearing. (2) If the bearing has a loose fit, you can carefully tap the fitting ring of the bearing with a wooden mallet to remove it. When tapping, make sure to work evenly around the circumference—avoid focusing on just one spot repeatedly. In some cases, a steel hammer may also be used, but in this scenario, always place a wooden block between the hammer and the bearing to ensure that the force is distributed evenly across the bearing, preventing damage. (3) Select a metal material to create a sleeve, ensuring the inner diameter of the sleeve is slightly larger than the journal diameter. During removal, support the sleeve with an appropriate object. If the fit is loose, gently tap the shaft end with a hammer to detach the bearing; if the fit is tight, apply force to the shaft end using a press or jack. Alternatively, if using the sleeve proves inconvenient, you can also substitute it with two clamping plates. Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Commonly Used Components 65 (4) Tensioner Disassembly Method. Use a tensioner to remove the shaft. Up, rotate the screw and push the shaft end to remove the bearing. By The helical pair exhibits force-amplifying characteristics, which is why conventional bearings generally... This method can be used for disassembly, as shown in Figure 2.8. (5) If the bearing cannot be pulled out using a puller, The ring can simultaneously cool the outer race of the bearing locally using dry ice, yet… Then quickly pull the outer race of the tapered roller bearing out of the gear. 2. Bearing Cleaning (1) Hot Oil Cleaning Method. For bearings hardened by soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease, immerse them in hot motor oil heated to 100–200°C. Use pliers to grip the bearing and gently scrub away any oil contamination with a brush. When heated to 100–200°C, soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease will melt, allowing it to easily flush out of the bearing’s crevices. In some cases, simply shaking the bearing repeatedly in the oil is enough to dislodge the dirt and grime from between the gaps. When cleaning the radial spherical ball bearings of old or imported electric motors, the balls, retainer, and inner ring should be carefully turned horizontally out of the outer ring before being immersed in hot oil. Similarly, when cleaning short cylindrical roller bearings, the rollers, retainer, inner ring, and outer ring must first be separated from one another. When cleaning with hot oil, the oil temperature should not exceed 20°C. If using an open flame for direct heating, be careful to prevent the oil from catching fire. The bearing should be suspended inside the oil pot—immersing it completely at the bottom could cause overheating and reduce its hardness. (2) General Cleaning Method: Place the bearing in kerosene and soak it for 5–10 minutes. While holding the inner ring with one hand, gently rotate the outer ring with the other—this will cause any soft dry grease or rust-preventive paste on the bearing to fall off. Next, transfer the bearing to a container of cleaner kerosene and use a fine, soft-bristled brush to thoroughly clean away oil stains from the raceways and between the rolling elements. Finally, rinse the bearing once more in gasoline before carefully placing it onto a clean piece of paper. When cleaning spherical ball bearings and short cylindrical roller bearings, separate the balls, retainer cage, inner ring, and outer ring for individual cleaning. For bearings already mounted on a shaft, cleaning is typically done by pouring oil directly over them or using an oil gun for targeted spraying. Start with kerosene to remove easily loosened oil deposits, followed by gasoline for tougher residues. If oil stains persist, first apply hot engine oil heated to 100–200°C via pouring or spraying, then finish with gasoline. Always remember not to scrape off hardened oil buildup or rust from the bearing surfaces using sharp tools, as this could damage the smoothness of the rolling elements and raceway grooves. After cleaning, dry the bearing thoroughly with a clean cloth. 3. Inspection of Rolling Bearings For rolling bearings, focus should be placed on inspecting the inner and outer raceways. The entire working surface must be smooth, free from defects such as cracks, micropores, dents, and peeling. Similarly, the surfaces of the rolling elements themselves should be flawless, with no cracks, micropores, or dents. Additionally, the retainer must remain intact, and all rivets should be securely fastened. If clearance is detected between the inner and outer races of the bearing, avoid replacing it immediately—instead, consider adjusting it through preloading to eliminate any increased clearance caused by wear, thereby enhancing its rotational accuracy. 2.4.4 Assembly of Rolling Bearings Rolling bearings consist of an inner ring, outer ring, rolling elements, and a cage—they are the bearing components that enable relative motion between the shaft and the bearing housing through rolling friction. Rolling bearings offer advantages such as low friction coefficients, high efficiency, compact axial dimensions, and ease of assembly and disassembly, making them widely used in various types of machinery and equipment. As standardized components mass-produced by specialized factories, rolling bearings come with predetermined inner diameters, outer diameters, and axial widths at the time of manufacture. Consequently, the inner ring of a rolling bearing serves as the reference hole, while the outer ring acts as the reference shaft. Figure 2.8: Tutorial on Diagnosing and Repairing Electromechanical System Failures in Tensioners – Bearing Disassembly Case 66

Rolling bearings are precision components, and careful attention should be paid to both the pre-installation preparations and the quality of the installation process—along with noting the following points. (1) Before installation, prepare the necessary tools and measuring instruments. Carefully inspect the surface dimensions of all parts that will be fitted with the bearing to ensure they meet the requirements specified in the drawings. Then, clean these surfaces thoroughly with gasoline or kerosene, wipe them dry, and apply a thin layer of system lubricant oil (machine oil). (2) Verify that the bearing model matches the drawing. (3) The installation method for rolling bearings should be determined based on the bearing’s design, size, and the nature of the fit between its components.

2.4.5 Clearance in Rolling Bearings and Its Adjustment The clearance in rolling bearings ensures proper operation of the rolling elements, facilitates lubrication, and accommodates thermal expansion. However, the clearance in rolling bearings must not be too large—or too small. If the clearance is excessive, it reduces the number of rolling elements simultaneously bearing the load, increasing the load on each individual element, which in turn shortens the bearing’s lifespan and compromises rotational accuracy, potentially leading to noise and vibration. On the other hand, if the clearance is too tight, it can easily cause overheating and accelerate wear, again negatively impacting the bearing’s longevity. Therefore, adjusting the clearance during bearing installation is an extremely critical task. There are three commonly used methods for adjusting rolling bearing clearance: the shim method, the screw adjustment method, and the combined adjustment method. 2.4.6 Preloading in Rolling Bearing Assembly Preloading refers to applying an axial load to the bearing during installation, inducing a slight pre-deformation between the rolling elements and the inner and outer rings, thereby enabling the bearing to operate with negative clearance. Preloading increases bearing stiffness, enhances rotational accuracy, and extends bearing life. The preload amount should be determined appropriately based on the bearing's load conditions and application requirements. Excessive preload, however, can increase bearing wear and heat generation, ultimately reducing the bearing's service life. Preloading paired angular contact bearings can enhance their operational stiffness. Common methods for controlling preload include adding metal shims, grinding down the raceways, or adjusting the widths of the inner and outer sleeves between the two bearings. 2.5 Gear Drive Maintenance and Assembly

2.5.1 Characteristics and Applications of Gear Transmission Gear transmission is one of the most commonly used methods of power transmission, relying on the meshing of gear teeth to transfer motion and power. It is characterized by its ability to ensure an accurate transmission ratio, handle a wide range of power and speed levels, achieve high transmission efficiency, maintain a compact design, and offer long service life—though gear transmissions do require relatively high precision in manufacturing and assembly. There are several types of gear transmissions, which can be classified in different ways into straight teeth, helical teeth, and herringbone gear drives. They can also be categorized into cylindrical gears, bevel gears, and rack-and-pinion gear systems, among others. 2.5.2 Failure Modes of Gear Drives and Preventive Measures

Working Conditions Power is transmitted through tooth surface contact, with the two tooth surfaces meshing together in a motion that involves both rolling and sliding. The gear surface is subjected to alternating contact compressive stress and friction forces; the tooth root, meanwhile, experiences alternating bending stress. Now, let’s move on to Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Commonly Used Mechanical Components. 67 It will experience impact during engagement. Poor installation can lead to improper tooth surface contact. 2. Failure Modes Gear failure modes include tooth fracture and surface damage failures, such as pitting, wear, and plastic deformation. 1) Tooth fracture Classified by failure mechanisms, we have: fatigue fracture—occurs when a cantilever beam is subjected to fluctuating bending stresses or stress concentrations, causing fatigue cracks to propagate from the tensile side at the tooth root until final fracture; overload fracture—resulting from excessively high impact loads or short-term, severe overloading; and wear-induced fracture, where severe tooth wear reduces the gear's static strength, ultimately leading to failure. There are two forms of fracture in terms of morphology: complete fracture and partial fracture. From a design perspective, the gear teeth should undergo calculations to assess their root bending strength. From a manufacturing standpoint, increasing the radius of the fillet at the tooth root, reducing surface roughness, applying surface hardening treatments, and minimizing machining-induced damage on the tooth flank can all help enhance the tooth's resistance to fatigue failure. Additionally, improving the stiffness of the shaft and supports—and ideally eliminating any uneven distribution of loads—can significantly reduce the likelihood of localized tooth fractures. 2) Pitting corrosion

When gears are in operation, prolonged exposure to pulsating cyclic stresses can cause tiny metal flakes to detach, resulting in the formation of shallow pits. Phenomenon: Pitting typically occurs in well-lubricated, closed gear drives. The specific locations are usually near the pitch line, where relative sliding velocities are low, making it difficult to form a lubricant film. In spur gear drives, contact stresses are also relatively high, further increasing the likelihood of pitting. To reduce pitting, the following measures can be taken: From a design perspective, the gear should undergo calculations to ensure adequate tooth surface contact strength. From a manufacturing perspective, In terms of engineering, the tooth surface hardness should be increased, and its roughness reduced; appropriate modification should be employed; lubricants with higher viscosity should be used; and dynamic loads should be minimized.

3) Gear Surface Galling Galling refers to the wear phenomenon caused by the direct contact and adhesion of metal surfaces with interlocking teeth under specific pressure, followed by the tearing off of metal from the tooth surfaces as they move relative to each other. Gluing types include hot gluing and cold gluing. Hot gluing is used for gear transmissions under heavy loads and high speeds, while cold gluing is suitable for gear transmissions involving heavy loads at low speeds. Gluing typically occurs at the top of the gears. To enhance resistance to galling, you can increase the hardness of the tooth surfaces and reduce their roughness. Alternatively, you can also use lubricants with higher viscosity (for low-speed transmissions) or those specifically designed to resist galling (for high-speed transmissions). 4) Tooth Surface Wear Tooth surface wear occurs in two forms: abrasive wear and running-in wear. Abrasive wear happens in open gear drives, while running-in wear typically refers to the running-in process under light loads. Switching to closed-gear transmission is the most effective method to prevent abrasive wear on gear surfaces. Additionally, abrasive wear can be minimized by increasing the surface hardness of the gears, reducing surface roughness, and ensuring proper lubrication. 5) Plastic Deformation of Tooth Surfaces The cause of plastic deformation on gear surfaces is the plastic flow of the softer gear material under heavy loads or frictional forces, resulting in grooves being rolled into the driving gear and protruding ridges being extruded onto the driven gear. This failure typically occurs in transmissions operating at low speeds, under heavy loads, and with frequent start-ups. Measures such as increasing the hardness of gear tooth surfaces and using high-viscosity lubricants can help prevent or reduce plastic deformation on the tooth surfaces. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial

3. Gear Inspection After gears have operated for a period of time, tooth profile errors increase due to wear on the tooth surfaces, which ultimately affects their performance. Therefore, it is essential that the gear teeth remain intact, with no signs of extrusion deformation, cracks, or broken teeth. Additionally, wear on the tooth thickness should be kept within limits—not exceeding 0.15 times the module. In production, specialized gear thickness calipers are commonly used to check for deviations in tooth thickness, effectively controlling backlash by measuring the reduction in tooth thickness. Alternatively, a universal involute micrometer can be employed to assess variations in the length of the gear’s normal chord, ensuring precise gear motion accuracy. This method is simple and practical, making it widely adopted in manufacturing processes. Furthermore, the gear’s internal bore, keyways, splines, and threads must all meet standard specifications, with no instances of scoring or damage allowed. 2.5.3 Gear Maintenance and Repair The methods for gear repair are primarily determined based on the gear's failure mode, production technology conditions, and application requirements. For small to medium module gears, if spare parts are readily available, repairs are typically avoided in favor of replacing the gear entirely with a new one. However, when replacing gears, it’s generally recommended to swap them in pairs to ensure optimal meshing performance. If spare parts aren’t sufficient, large gears can be repaired using precision finishing techniques, while smaller gears are replaced altogether. For worn-out large-module gears, dimensional restoration can be achieved through spraying, followed by fine finishing of the tooth surfaces. In cases where large-module gears suffer from broken teeth or cracks, repair methods such as tooth insertion or weld patching are employed. 2.5.4 Assembly and Adjustment of Cylindrical Gears

The basic requirements for gear transmission are that the installation position must be correct; the tooth side clearance must meet technical specifications; and the contact spot distribution should be uniform and properly positioned. Gear and shaft assemblies are mostly secured using keys. For gears subjected to axial forces, screws and retaining rings are used to prevent axial movement and ensure proper positioning on the shaft. When transmitting high torque, a transition fit with a larger interference fit is often employed to create a tight, static connection—this typically requires either press-fitting or thermal assembly methods. Here are several common types of errors that occur during the assembly of gears and shafts: 1. Loosening of the cylindrical gear shaft bore (1) Phenomenon: The gear and gear shaft are not tightly fitted together. (2) Cause analysis: The inner bore of the gear was machined incorrectly, resulting in a flared shape. (3) H azardous effects: During operation, lateral oscillation occurs, accelerating wear on both the hole and shaft. Additionally, significant vibration during operation leads to low tran smission efficiency. (4) Prevention and control measures: The internal bore of the gear should be re-machined, and the gear should be replaced if necessary.

2. Gear Runout (1) Phen omenon: The gear centerline does not coincide with the shaft centerline. (2) Cause analysis: Significant assembly dimension errors. (3) Hazardous Effects. When the equipment is run ning, radial runout occurs in the gear transmission. Additionally, the meshing tooth sections experience impacts and noise due to the continuous variation in pitch circle diameter.  If the eccentricity of the centerline exceeds a certain limit, jamming may occur, disrupting the smooth operation of the equipment. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: The gear t ransmission system must be assembled correctly, with all necessary inspections and adjustments performed. Special attention should be paid to ensuring proper alignment of the locat ing keys between the shaft and gears, as well as maintaining appropriate tightness. Any existing issues should be carefully addressed through repairs, and if needed, relevant compo nents should be replaced. Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of General-Purpose Components

3. Gear Misalignment (1) Phenomenon: The gear becomes skewed when assembled on to the shaft. (2) Cause analysis: Rough and careless assembly; excessive dimensional errors in component machining. (3) Hazardous Effects: When gears are improperly aligned during  assembly on the shaft, end-face runout will occur during equipment operation. This leads to uneven loading between meshing gear pairs, resulting in excessive wear. (4) Prevention a nd Control Measures: Reassembly and adjustment should be performed. If the inspection confirms that the issue is indeed caused by excessive machining errors in the gear shaft bore,  the gear should be replaced. 4. Poor Gear Meshing Performance (1) Phenomenon: The gear was not properly seated against the shaft shoulder during assembly. (2) Cause analysis: The  transmission shaft end is too long; the gear lacks sufficient width during machining; the gear is incorrectly assembled. (3) Harmfulness. During gear assembly, the gears were not p roperly seated against the shaft shoulders, resulting in wide contact between the meshing gears along the axial direction. Meanwhile, the remaining portion of the tooth width exper ienced poor meshing, which further increased the load on those specific teeth. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: The position of the gear on the shaft must be accurately assembl ed according to standard requirements. For components with excessive dimensional deviations, necessary adjustments should be made. 5. Abnormal gear transmission (1) Phenomenon: Abn ormal gear transmission and difficult starting. (2) Cause analysis: The gear retaining key is loose; the gear tooth profile is non-standard or damaged; excessive assembly errors in  the gears; too much oil present.

(3) Hazardous consequences: Gear wear accelerates or causes breakage, leading to malfunction. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: If the gear key becomes loose, it should be securely re-tightened. If the tooth profile exceeds the allowable tolerance or is severely damaged, it should be properly repaired. If the gear assembly is improperly aligned, adjustments must be made. And if there is excessive oil, it should be limited according to the specified guidelines.

2.5.5 Assembly and Adjustment of Bevel Gears The assembly of a bevel gear transmission mechanism is essentially similar to that of a cylindrical gear transmission mechanism, with the key difference being that the axes of the two gears intersect at the apex of a cone, forming a specified angle. Typically, the geometric position of the bevel gear axes is determined by the machining accuracy of the housing, while axial positioning relies on the back cone of the bevel gear as a reference. During assembly, the back-cone surfaces must align precisely to ensure proper gear alignment. Depending on whether the contact pattern shifts toward the tooth tip or root, the gear positions should be adjusted and repositioned along the axis accordingly. Axial positioning is usually achieved by shims placed between the bearing housings and the housing itself. Since bevel gears are designed for transmitting motion between perpendicular shafts, the machining of the two vertical bearing housing bores in the housing must strictly adhere to the specified technical requirements. 2.5.6 Assembly and Adjustment of Worm Gear Pair The worm gear mechanism is used to transmit motion and power between two perpendicular shafts, with an intersection angle of 90°. Its key transmission characteristics include: a high gear ratio, a compact design, self-locking capability, smooth operation, and low noise—but it suffers from relatively low transmission efficiency, higher friction, and significant heat generation, which limits the power it can handle, typically up to P ≤ 5 kW. The worm wheel gear ring is usually made from more expensive bronze, resulting in higher manufacturing costs, making this mechanism particularly suitable for applications like speed reduction and lifting equipment. Based on the shape of the worm, worm gear drives can be classified into cylindrical worm drives, globoidal worm drives, and bevel worm drives, with cylindrical worms being the most widely used. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial

70 1. Assembly Technical Requirements for Worm Gear Mechanisms (1) The worm shaft axis must be perpendicular to the worm wheel shaft axis, and the worm shaft axis should lie within the symmetrical plane of the worm wheel. (2) The center distance between the worm wheel and the worm must be accurate. (3) There is adequate backlash and normal contact patterns. (4) After assembly, it should rotate smoothly without any sticking or binding, and the force should be evenly distributed. 2. The Assembly Process of the Worm Gear Mechanism The worm gear mechanism consists of components such as the housing, worm wheel, and worm. The sequence of assembly is determined by the structural design of the mechanism. Typically, the worm wheel is installed first, followed by the worm, and finally, adjustments are checked and made. The process of installing the worm gear onto the shaft and the corresponding inspection method are identical to those used for installing cylindrical gears. Inspect the radial runout of both the worm gear and the worm. Runout and face runout are also the same as for cylindrical gears. The housing is the main body of the worm gear mechanism; typically, the position of the worm shaft axis is determined by the mounting holes in the housing. The axial position of the worm, however, does not affect assembly quality. To ensure that the worm axis lies within the symmetrical center plane of the worm wheel teeth, the axial position of the worm wheel can be adjusted by modifying the thickness of shims or using alternative methods. Meanwhile, the distance between the worm’s central line and the worm wheel’s central line is primarily maintained by the precision of machining processes—and fine-tuned further through shim adjustments.
