Diagnostic and Repair: A Case Study Tutorial for Mechatronic Systems 72 3.1 Components of Hydraulic Systems and Fault Diagnosis

3.1.1 Components of the Hydraulic Transmission System A hydraulic transmission system is a type of drive system that utilizes various components to form customized control circuits, enabling it to perform specific control functions. Thanks to its unique technical advantages—such as high power-to-weight ratio, stepless speed regulation, advanced automation capabilities, and effective overload protection—hydraulic transmission has found widespread application across numerous industries. In particular, the integration of computer technology, mechatronics, and optimization techniques into modern hydraulic systems and components is driving the evolution of hydraulic transmission toward higher pressure, greater speed, increased power output, enhanced efficiency, reduced noise levels, lower energy consumption, superior durability, and highly integrated designs. As shown in Figure 3.1, this is a simple hydraulic transmission system for a machine tool workbench. From Figure 3.1(a), it can be seen that the hydraulic cylinder is fixed to the machine bed, while the piston rod is connected to the workbench, enabling reciprocating motion. The hydraulic pump 3, driven by an electric motor (not shown in the figure), draws oil from the oil tank 1 through filter 2 and then delivers the fluid—via throttle valve 5 and directional control valve 6—into the left chamber of the workbench’s hydraulic cylinder, pushing the piston and, consequently, the workpiece. The workbench moves to the right, at which point the oil from the right chamber of the workbench's hydraulic cylinder flows back to the oil tank 1 via the directional control valve 6. If the handle of directional control valve 6 is moved to the left, as shown in Figure 3.1(b), the oil pressed into the left chamber of the worktable hydraulic cylinder via directional control valve 6 will be drained back to the oil tank 1 through the same valve. By switching the oil flow path using the directional control valve, the reciprocating motion of the worktable is achieved. The speed of the worktable’s movement is adjusted by throttle valve 5: when the throttle valve 5 is fully open, the worktable moves faster; conversely, when the throttle valve 5 is partially closed, the worktable moves more slowly. 1—Fuel tank; 2—Filter; 3—Hydraulic pump; 4—Relief valve; 5—Throttle valve; 6—Directional control valve

Figure 3.1: Simple Machine Tool Worktable Hydraulic Transmission System By adjusting the preload of the spring in overflow valve 4, you can set the pressure of the hydraulic fluid output by hydraulic pump 3. The hydraulic oil then pushes the hydraulic… The cylinder piston overcomes resistance to move the worktable. When the pressure exceeds the set value, overflow valve 4 opens, allowing the oil to flow back into tank 1—thus, ov erflow valve 4 serves both as a pressure regulator and an overflow device. Meanwhile, filter 2 functions to filter and purify the hydraulic oil. As shown in the example above, a hy draulic transmission system consists of five parts in total. (1) Power unit. The most common type is the hydraulic pump, which converts mechanical energy into pressure energy of th e oil fluid. Its function is to supply pressure energy to the hydraulic system, serving as the power source for the entire hydraulic system. Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintena nce of Hydraulic Systems (2) Actuating devices. Typically referring to hydraulic cylinders and hydraulic motors, these devices convert the pressure energy of oil into mechanical en ergy. Their function is to deliver force and velocity (or torque and rotational speed) under the propulsion of pressurized oil, thereby driving the working components. (3) Control  and regulating devices. These include control valves for pressure, flow, direction, and more—they are the components that manage and adjust the oil pressure, flow, or direction wit hin the hydraulic system. Different combinations of these elements create hydraulic systems with varying functions, ensuring that the actuating components perform their intended mo tion tasks effectively. (4) Auxiliary devices. These refer to any equipment other than the three types mentioned above, such as fuel tanks, filters, accumulators, oil lines, and mo re. Each of these components serves specific functions—like cooling, oil storage, oil transportation, connection, filtration, pressure measurement, and flow rate monitoring—and col lectively play a crucial role in ensuring the reliable and stable operation of the hydraulic system. (5) The transmission medium, typically hydraulic oil, serves to transmit motion  and power. As a result, it becomes clear that hydraulic transmission relies on pressurized fluid contained within a sealed volume to transfer both motion and force.

3.1.2 Analysis  of Failure Causes in the Hydraulic System Hydraulic systems can experience a wide range of failures during operation, with the primary causes rooted in issues related to design, m anufacturing, usage practices, and hydraulic oil contamination. Among hydraulic component failures, the hydraulic pump accounts for the highest failure rate—approximately 30% of al l hydraulic component malfunctions—making it essential to pay close attention to this issue. Additionally, many hydraulic system failures are also caused by improper selection of w orking fluids or inadequate maintenance practices. In fact, 70% to 80% of all hydraulic system failures are directly linked to contaminants present in the hydraulic oil, and among these oil-related failures, about 90% are attributed to impurities. Another significant cause of failure stems from natural wear, aging, and degradation that occur under normal operating conditions. Impurities pose a serious threat to hydraulic systems, as they can accelerate component wear, increase leakage, impair system performance, and shorten component lifespan—even leading to equipment damage or complete system failure. The following sections will focus on analyzing failures caused by improper design, manufacturing processes, incorrect usage practices, and hydraulic oil contamination.

Design rationale When a hydraulic system malfunctions, the first step should generally be to analyze the rationality of its design. The design's suitability directly impacts the sy stem's operational performance, which becomes particularly evident during failure analysis of hydraulic systems in imported equipment. This issue is closely tied to how production  processes are organized internationally—many foreign manufacturers rely on collaborative approaches, which can sometimes lead to hydraulic systems being designed that don’t fully a lign with the specific application conditions and requirements of the equipment. For example, the hydraulic system of a certain vertical mill hydraulic press primarily operates in  pressure-holding mode during operation due to the minimal displacement of the grinding rollers. Therefore, during the pressure-holding phase, the system must keep the hydraulic pum p unloaded to minimize heat generation, ensuring that the viscosity of the hydraulic oil doesn’t fluctuate excessively—and thus maintaining consistent cement production capacity. T he hydraulic system of the imported equipment, however, was designed with the common overflow valve–loaded unloading method, which clearly stems from an inherently flawed design ap proach. When designing a hydraulic system, it’s essential not only to ensure the hydraulic circuit can meet the actuator’s operational requirements but also to pay close attention  to the layout of hydraulic components—particularly the positioning of component outlets during the design and implementation of stackable valves. For instance, in a circuit compris ing a 3-position directional control valve, a pilot-operated check valve, and a flow-control throttle valve, the pilot-operated check valve must be directly connected to the direct ional control valve, while the latter must feature a Y-type center position function. On the other hand, in circuits using an electro-hydraulic directional control valve with an M-type center position, either an external control method should be adopted, or an internal control approach incorporating a pre-loaded check valve—both aimed at guaranteeing proper  switching of the pilot-operated valve. Secondly, pay attention to factors such as the rationality of the fuel tank design and the optimal layout of the piping system. In environmen ts with harsh operating conditions, ensure proper protection for exposed hydraulic components. For instance, in the metallurgical industry, the piston rods of hydraulic cylinders a re often left exposed, directly surrounded by airborne contaminants. During their continuous reciprocating motion—extending and retracting—the piston rods not only suffer wear from  abrasive particles and corrosion caused by corrosive gases in the atmosphere, but they may also allow contaminants to infiltrate through the clearance between the piston rod and t he guide sleeve, potentially leading to failures in the machinery's diagnostic and maintenance procedures.

74 Fluids can further accelerate wear on hydraulic cylinder components. T o mitigate this issue, designers can incorporate protective sleeves onto the piston rods during the structural design phase, safeguarding their exposed sections and thereby reducin g or preventing the aforementioned risks. Unfortunately, some engineers, seeking to simplify the process, inadvertently specify  "spray green textured paint on both the inner and outer surfaces of the oil tank " in the technical requirements of the tank’s blueprint. As a result, manufacturers naturally skip the critical step of acid phosphating the tank’s internal surface. Over time, as  the paint on the inner surface begins to peel off, it can clog the hydraulic pump’s suction filter, leading to potential system failures. Hydraulic pump cavitation or failure to achieve sufficient pressure.

2. Manufacturing Cause Equipment manufacturing and component production often proceed smoothly with no issues in the overall design—but unexpected failures still tend to arise during installation and commissioning. For instance, at one company, the valve test bench of a multifunctional hydraulic component testing station failed to perform pressure tests during debugging. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the oil passages connecting the integrated block had been improperly machined, causing the pressure and return lines to inadvertently merge. As a result, sufficient pressure couldn’t be built up. After reworking the affected areas, the issue was resolved, allowing the commissioning process to proceed smoothly and successfully complete. For instance, improper clearance between the valve body and spool of a slide valve can lead to leakage or seizing. Additionally, if the mating surfaces between the valve body and the machine housing fail to meet manufacturing tolerances for flatness, deformation may occur under tightening pressure after assembly, causing the spool to become stuck inside the valve body—resulting in restricted or complete blockage of movement. Furthermore, during manufacturing, some valve bodies may not undergo reliable stress-relief treatments. As a result, residual stresses redistribute over time during operation, leading to deformation of the valve body. This not only compromises the original fit and function but also causes the slide valve to move sluggishly or even jam completely within the valve body. Some manufacturers fail to flush the hydraulic system during final assembly, opting instead to rely on cleaning components individually as they are assembled—thus skipping the critical step of flushing the system itself. This practice often leaves behind contaminants introduced during the assembly process, which can become a significant and frequently overlooked cause of system failures. Hydraulic system flushing involves using fluid flow at specific pressure and velocity levels to thoroughly clean and rinse every circuit within the entire system. However, cleaning components before assembly cannot replace the essential step of flushing the system after it has been fully assembled. During assembly, there’s always a risk of damaging seals or scratching/abrasively affecting metal parts. Additionally, adhesives, liquid sealants, or PTFE tape used when connecting pipes and components may inadvertently get pushed into the system, introducing contaminants that compromise its performance even after assembly is complete. 3. Reason for Use

Improper use and maintenance of hydraulic systems not only increase the frequency of equipment failures but also significantly reduce the lifespan of the equipment. For instance, operating equipment under overload or over-speed conditions, exposing it to harsh environmental conditions, engaging in unsafe practices, or failing to perform timely maintenance can all accelerate the deterioration of hydraulic system performance. In even more severe cases, operator errors may lead to catastrophic accidents rather than mere malfunctions. Take, for example, a 65-meter aerial work platform used by a fire department: during a training exercise, the driver’s misoperation caused the telescopic boom to extend rapidly at an extremely low angle, resulting in the vehicle tipping over. This incident led to casualties and substantial property damage. The types of failures caused by improper use and maintenance are numerous, and many major accidents actually occur during routine operation and maintenance activities. Therefore, the first priority for organizations using hydraulic equipment should be to provide comprehensive hydraulic technology training for all relevant personnel—both operators and managers. Training should cover not only how to operate the equipment safely but also how to understand its functions, working principles, and key safety precautions. Additionally, strict adherence to operational procedures and guidelines outlined in the equipment’s manual is essential during daily use. Only through proper management, regular maintenance, and conscientious operation can hydraulic systems perform optimally, minimize breakdowns, and ensure reliable, long-term functionality. 4. Causes of Hydraulic Oil Contamination More than 75% of hydraulic system failures are caused by hydraulic oil contamination. In hydraulic systems, the oil tank is often the primary source of fluid contamination. Many tanks suffer from design and manufacturing flaws—most commonly, "closed" tank designs that are poorly engineered. For instance, seals are frequently omitted at connections and pipe joints, allowing contaminants to seep into the tank. Once contaminated, the oil circulates through the hydraulic system, accelerating wear, corrosion, and blockages in critical components—and ultimately leading to system failure. In recent years, Chapter 3 has focused extensively on diagnosing and repairing hydraulic system faults. 75 Manufacturers have conducted numerous valuable explorations and practical efforts in optimizing fuel tank structural design to minimize or eliminate contaminants from entering the tank. For instance, the now-common fully enclosed tank design features a single vent hole that remains connected to the atmosphere, while the rest of the tank is completely sealed. All connection points and pipe joints are equipped with rigorously designed sealing mechanisms. Additionally, the fuel filler cap incorporates a filtration system as part of the vent structure—this opening ensures proper communication between the tank’s liquid level and the atmosphere, maintaining optimal system operation while simultaneously preventing external contaminants from infiltrating the tank. Because the tank is entirely sealed, the pump’s suction port no longer requires a filter. Instead, all return oil from the system passes through a central return line filter before being redirected back into the tank, effectively keeping the hydraulic system’s fluid clean at all times. This innovative design not only safeguards the internal oil from external contamination but also significantly reduces suction resistance by eliminating the need for a filter at the pump’s intake. As a result, it helps prevent cavitation—a common issue that can arise when suction resistance is too high. The author encountered this problem firsthand while troubleshooting a shoe-making company’s hydraulic equipment, where the “hydraulic system pressure fluctuated intermittently.” Upon inspection, it was discovered that the oil inside the tank had already been compromised by contaminants. After layering, a clear gel-like substance was observed below 200 mm from the oil surface, while numerous granular sediments had accumulated at the bottom of the tank. Upon removing and inspecting the hydraulic pump’s filter, it became evident that it was almost completely clogged. Clearly, the system failure was caused by contamination of the hydraulic oil. By replacing the filter, changing the hydraulic oil, and thoroughly cleaning the tank, the issue was successfully resolved. Therefore, when handling hydraulic oil, treat it just like human blood—only by maintaining its proper cleanliness can you ensure that the failure rate of the hydraulic system is minimized. 3.1.3 Fault Diagnosis Steps for Hydraulic Systems

1) Verify the fault symptoms or signs Given the complexity and subtlety of hydraulic system failures, it is essential to first verify the specific symptoms or signs of the malfunction. This can be done by asking operators and maintenance personnel about recent changes in the machine’s performance, its maintenance history, any specific actions taken after the initial failure signs appeared, and the components that have already been inspected and adjusted. 2) Identify fault diagnosis parameters Hydraulic system failures are all classified as parameter-based faults, and useful fault information is extracted by measuring relevant parameters. Diagnostic parameters for hydraulic systems include system pressure, system flow rate, component temperature rise, component leakage, system vibration and noise, as well as motor speed. When selecting diagnostic parameters, the following principles should be followed: the parameters must exhibit high sensitivity, ease of measurement, and good reproducibility, while also being capable of capturing as much fault-related information as possible. 3) Analyze and determine the possible location and extent of the fault. Analyze the detected results by referring to the hydraulic system schematic, examining both the structural and system principles to ensure accurate fault diagnosis and minimize misdiagnoses. 4) Develop a rational diagnostic process and diagnostic methods Select instruments and meters for diagnostic use The diagnostic instruments and equipment include photoelectric digital tachometers, thermometers, stopwatches, pressure gauges, hydraulic testers, various types of connectors, specialized tools, and more. The selection principle is as follows: First, choose instruments that do not require any disassembly of system components; second, opt for instruments that need to be connected directly into the system; and finally, use hydraulic measuring devices. In cases where the fault is particularly complex, a hydraulic tester can also be used initially for diagnosis. It’s crucial to note that before analyzing and identifying the exact location and extent of the failure, absolutely avoid any unnecessary disassembly, dismantling, or unauthorized adjustments of hydraulic components. Doing so could inadvertently worsen the problem, introduce new issues, or even complicate the original fault further. Case Study Guide for Diagnosing and Repairing Mechanical and Electrical System Faults

76 6) Troubleshoot to ensure the equipment functions properly. Write the work report The purpose of summarizing experiences and documenting them for archiving is to improve the efficiency of troubleshooting and prevent the same failures from occurring again. 3.1.4 Fault Diagnosis Methods for Hydraulic Systems

1. Sensory Diagnostic Method Sensory diagnosis, also known as preliminary diagnosis, is one of the simplest and most convenient methods for troubleshooting hydraulic systems. This approach relies on the mnemonic "look, listen, touch, smell, read, ask." The visual inspection method can be carried out either while the hydraulic equipment is in operation or when it’s idle. (1) Look. Observe the actual operation of the hydraulic system.

First, check the speed to see if there are any changes or abnormalities in the movement of the actuator. Second, check the pressure—this refers to the magnitude and changes in pressure at each monitoring point within the hydraulic system. Third, inspect the fluid: Examine the color of the hydraulic oil to assess its level of contamination. Typically, this is done by pouring the working oil into a transparent glass bottle and letting it sit undisturbed for 1 hour before observing. If the hydraulic oil remains clear, transparent, and colorless, it indicates that the oil is free from contamination. If the oil appears cloudy and white, with clarity at the top of the bottle and turbidity at the bottom, it suggests that water has entered and contaminated the oil. Conversely, if the oil is clear at the bottom but cloudy at the top, air has likely mixed in, causing contamination. If the oil turns a mottled, unevenly cloudy reddish-brown hue, it means iron rust and sediment have contaminated the fluid. A deep red or tea-brown color signals that the oil has degraded due to high temperatures and oxidation. If the oil remains transparent but has faded in color, it suggests that an incompatible type of oil has been mixed in—but as long as the viscosity still meets specifications, the oil can still be used. Finally, check whether there’s foam on the oil’s surface, ensure the oil level stays within the prescribed markings on the dipstick, and verify that the oil’s viscosity aligns with  the required standards. Check whether the oil temperature gauge is within the optimal range of 30–50°C, and whether it exceeds the permissible limit set for the specified temperat ure. Also, perform a  "fourth check " for leaks—inspect all connection points for any signs of seepage or leakage. Five checks for vibration refer to whether the hydraulic actuator exhibits any bouncing or jerking du ring operation. Sixth, examine the product: Assess the working condition of the actuator, as well as the stability of the hydraulic system's working pressure and flow rate, based o n the quality of the products produced by the hydraulic equipment. First, check the fuel tank to ensure the fluid level meets the required specifications. Observe whether the hydra ulic pump's suction action causes fluctuations in the tank’s liquid level, potentially leading to the suction pipe and filter briefly exposing above the fluid surface. Also, inspec t the tank and return line for any presence of air bubbles. (2) Listen. Normal equipment operation produces sounds with a certain melody and rhythm, maintaining consistent stabilit y. Therefore, from a practical standpoint… By accumulating, familiarizing yourself with, and mastering these natural rhythms and tempos, you'll be able to accurately determine whet her hydraulic equipment is operating properly—and simultaneously, based on…

The patterns of pitch and rhythm variations, as well as the locations where abnormal sounds originate, c an help pinpoint the exact location of the fault and assess the extent of the damage. ① A high-pitched, screeching noise usually indicates air intake; if you hear cavitation sounds , it could mean the oil filter is clogged with contaminants. The hydraulic pump's oil suction pipe is loose, the seal is damaged or missing, or the oil level in the tank is too low . Additionally, factors such as degraded and contaminated hydraulic oil, or reduced foam-breaking performance, may also contribute to the issue. ② A  "hissing " or  "gushing " sound indicates a significant oil or gas leak at the drain port or leakage point. ③ The  "嗒嗒 " sound indicates poor engagement of the solenoid in the AC solenoid valve, possibly due to contaminants like paint flakes blocking the gap between the movable and stationary iron  cores, or perhaps because the push rod is too long. ④ Rough, heavy noise is often caused by overload in the hydraulic pump or hydraulic cylinder. ⑤ The  "chirping " or  "clucking " sound from the hydraulic pump is often caused by damaged pump bearings, severe wear on the pump shaft, or air being drawn into the system. ⑥ A sharp, short friction sound often i ndicates dry friction between two contacting surfaces—or it could also mean that the area has been strained. Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems 77 ⑦ Th e impact sound is low and muffled, often caused by loose screws inside the hydraulic cylinder or by foreign objects colliding with it. (3) Touch. Gently feel the moving parts that  are permitted to be touched, to assess their operational condition. To check for temperature rise, touch the surfaces of the hydraulic pump, oil tank, and valve components with you r hand. If it feels hot to the touch after just 2 seconds of contact, you should investigate the cause of the excessive heat. Touch for vibration—gently feel the vibration of movin g parts and pipelines. If you detect high-frequency vibrations, check to identify the underlying cause. Three times, while the workbench is moving at low speed under light load, fe el with your hand to check for any crawling motion. Check the tightness by feeling with your hands the stopper, microswitch, and tightening screws, among other components. Five-poi nt touch for wear assessment: Run your fingers over the worn components of hydraulic elements to evaluate the extent of wear, scoring, and damage. If your fingers feel smooth when  touching the surface of the worn part, it indicates abrasive wear; if you notice a sharp, snagging sensation, it suggests adhesive wear. (4) Smell. Use your sense of smell to deter mine if the fluid has developed a foul, rancid odor or if rubber components are emitting a peculiar smell due to overheating. If you detect a  "burnt " oil aroma, it could indicate that the hydraulic pump or hydraulic motor is experiencing cavitation—caused by air being drawn into the system—which generates intense heat and subs equently chars the surrounding oil. Additionally, if the hydraulic oil emits a strong, unpleasant stench or an acrid, pungent odor, this signals that the oil has become severely de graded. Pollution—this item can no longer be used. Check the work environment for any unusual odors to determine whether electrical component insulation has burned out, among other  potential issues.

(5) Review: Examine records related to fault analysis and maintenance, daily inspection and scheduled inspection cards, as well as shift handover logs and record s of repair and upkeep activities. (6) Ask. Inquire with the equipment operator to learn about the device's usual operating condition. Ask whether the hydraulic system is functioni ng properly and if the hydraulic pump shows any abnormal signs. Two questions: when to change the hydraulic oil, and whether the filter screen is clean. Was the pressure or speed c ontrol valve adjusted before the accident occurred, and what abnormal symptoms were observed? Four questions: Were the seals or hydraulic components replaced before the accident oc curred? Five questions about abnormal phenomena that occurred in the hydraulic system before and after the accident. Six frequently occurring past failures and their troubleshooting methods. 2. Parameter Measurement Method Whether a hydraulic system functions properly depends critically on whether its two main operational parameters are within the normal range. Specifically, this involves checking wh ether pressure and flow are within normal operating ranges, as well as verifying the status of critical auxiliary parameters such as system temperature and pump unit power. Under s pecific operating conditions, each component of hydraulic equipment typically maintains a stable set of values—meaning that when a hydraulic system is functioning correctly, its ke y operating parameters should remain close to their expected, condition-specific values. If the actual operating parameters of the hydraulic system deviate from these normal values  or show unusual fluctuations, it indicates that one or more components within the system may have malfunctioned. To diagnose the issue, simply measure the relevant operating param eters at designated monitoring points—such as temperature, pressure, flow rate, leakage, and power—and compare them against the system’s established normal operating values. This c omparison will help determine whether the system is running properly, identify any potential faults, and pinpoint the exact location of the problem. To reduce the workload of disas sembly and assembly, and to ensure testing under conditions as close as possible to the actual operating state of the hydraulic system, the test circuit is typically connected in p arallel with the system being tested. For complex and precision hydraulic equipment, the test instrument can also analyze non-electrical physical parameters—such as pressure, flow  rate, and temperature—obtained during testing. These physical quantities are first converted into electrical signals, which are then processed by a data management system for ampli fication, conversion, and display. As a result, the measured parameters are represented and displayed as electrical signals, allowing operators to compare them against the system’s  normal operational values and determine whether the system is functioning properly. This type of testing proves highly effective for condition monitoring and diagnostics of hydrau lic systems, enabling a comprehensive evaluation of both the entire hydraulic system and its individual components based on their key performance metrics. After identifying the app roximate location of the hydraulic system fault through systematic analysis, proceed to use a testing instrument for further inspection. Measure to narrow down the scope of the sys tem fault to the smallest possible area, allowing you to quickly pinpoint the fault's location. A Practical Guide to Diagnosing and Repairing Mechanical-Electrical System Failures  Using Parameter Measurement Techniques

78 During measurement, no need to shut down the equipment—this allows not only diagnosis of existing faults but also enables online monitoring and prediction of potential failures. Importantly, both prediction and diagnosis are quantitative, significantly enhancing the speed and accuracy of fault detection. For simpler hydraulic systems, this detection method can even bypass the need for sensors altogether, offering rapid testing with minimal error, while the compact and straightforward equipment makes it easy to implement directly in production environments. 3. Comparative Replacement Check Method This is an effective method for diagnosing hydraulic system faults when testing instruments are unavailable, and it’s sometimes best combined with the replacement method. One approach involves conducting a comparative test using two machines of identical make and performance specifications to pinpoint the issue. During the test, suspected components can be temporarily replaced with either new parts or known-good components, then retested. If the machine’s performance improves after the swap, the fault has been identified; if not, the process continues—either by repeating the same method or exploring other potential causes. Another scenario arises in today’s large and medium-sized machinery, where many hydraulic systems feature dual-pump or multi-pump, dual-circuit designs. For such systems, the compa rative replacement method becomes even more convenient. Moreover, modern systems often rely on high-pressure flexible hoses for connectivity, further simplifying the implementation  of the replacement technique. When troubleshooting a suspect component, you can replace it with a functioning part from another circuit without disassembling the original componen t—simply by swapping the corresponding hose fittings instead. For instance, while inspecting a dual-circuit system excavator, if one circuit exhibits weak performance and the hydra ulic pump is suspected of malfunctioning, the technician might proceed as follows: Afterward, manually test the suction at the oil inlet—it feels significantly weaker compared to t he hydraulic pump in the other circuit. This suggests possible severe wear, due to…

It couldn’t be repaired immediately, so we replaced the pump and conducted a test—but the issue  persisted, resulting in wasted time and no real progress. This was because someone had to manually turn the pump. The shaft speed falls far short of the actual requirements, making  it impossible to determine whether the pump is functioning properly based on the suction force at the oil inlet. At that time, however... By swapping the hydraulic pump hose fitti ngs between the two circuits, you can eliminate the possibility of a malfunction in just one step.

This method leverages the unique characteristics of hydraulic systems to systematically analyze and diagnose the issue at hand. Edit relationships, sy stem parameters, and the system's distribution structure to control the source.

In particular, for pilot-operated hydraulic systems—where the control oil circuit tends to be more intricate and thus more prone to failures—it’s especially important to conduct thorough inspections and detailed analyses. 3.1.5 Common Hydraulic System Faults and Maintenance

Hydraulic System Vibration and Noise Fault Diagnosis and Repair Vibration and noise in hydraulic systems primarily originate from two sources: mechanical vibration and noise, as well as fluid-induced vibration and noise. These vibrations and noises not only reduce equipment efficiency and production quality but can, in severe cases, lead to equipment damage, impairing the overall performance of the hydraulic system and shortening the service life of hydraulic components. Therefore, identifying the root causes of vibration and noise and implementing effective measures to mitigate their harmful effects are critical issues that must be addressed and resolved in the operation and maintenance of hydraulic systems. Causes of mechanical vibration (1) Imbalance in rotating components. When motors, hydraulic pumps, and hydraulic motors—components commonly found in hydraulic systems—operate at high speeds, any imbalance in their rotating parts generates periodic unbalanced centrifugal forces. These forces can lead to bending vibrations in the shafts, resulting in noise. Moreover, when these vibrations are transmitted through mounting bases or piping systems to the oil tank, other pipelines, or integrated blocks, they cause additional vibrations in these components, further amplifying the noise. Additionally, motors may also produce vibrations caused by ventilation (such as those from fans) as well as electromagnetic vibrations. (2) Vibration and Noise Caused by Couplings. The coupling is the primary mechanical connection component in a hydraulic system. If an inappropriate coupling is selected, it can generate significant vibrations. The drive shaft of the hydraulic pump cannot withstand radial or axial forces; therefore, it is not permitted to directly mount pulleys, gears, or sprockets onto the shaft ends. Instead, couplings are typically used to connect the drive shaft to the pump’s transmission shaft. In cases where manufacturing issues arise, the pump and… When the coupling's coaxiality significantly differs and there are assembly misalignments, the increasing centrifugal force at higher pump speeds causes the coupling to deform. This deformation, in turn, further amplifies the centrifugal force, creating a vicious cycle that ultimately leads to vibration—and consequently shortens the pump's service life. Additionally, factors such as loose coupling pins that aren’t tightened promptly, or worn-out rubber rings that aren’t replaced in time, can also contribute to vibrations and noise. (3) Piping, valves, and the oil tank. The piping itself is not a vibration source; rather, its vibrations are induced by the oscillations of other components. When the natural frequency of the piping matches the frequency of the vibration source, resonance occurs in the pipe, which can also trigger vibrations in adjacent components. Meanwhile, the oil tank itself generates vibrations as well. However, since the hydraulic pump and electric motor are directly mounted on the tank, their vibrations cause the tank to resonate, amplifying the overall vibration even further. Additionally, these vibrations may lead to turbulence within the oil tank, resulting in further oscillations of the hydraulic fluid. 2) Causes of Fluid Vibration (1) Fluid vibration caused by the inherent flow pulsation of the hydraulic pump itself. In hydraulic systems, the hydraulic pump is the primary source of vibration, accounting for approximately 75% of the total system’s vibrational noise. Therefore, reducing the vibration of the hydraulic pump is a critical measure for improving product performance. Hydraulic pump flow pulsation is an intrinsic characteristic of the pump—particularly in axial piston pumps, where multiple pistons operate simultaneously, creating distinct oil-discharge and oil-suction chambers. As a result, the pump’s instantaneous flow rate at any given moment equals the sum of the instantaneous flows from all pistons currently in the discharge chamber. In other words, the output flow of an axial piston pump is essentially the superposition of individual sinusoidal flow patterns generated by each piston. For axial piston pumps, flow pulsation is directly tied to the pump’s operational design. Inherent characteristics of plunger pumps: Hydraulic pumps with different numbers of plungers all exhibit corresponding inherent flow pulsations. These flow pulsations from the hydraulic pump inevitably lead to pressure fluctuations at the pump outlet and in the associated piping, which then propagate throughout the entire system, generating fluid noise. (2) Vibration and noise caused by directional valve shifting. In hydraulic systems, when the load inertia is relatively high, a sudden change in the direction of the directional valve causes an abrupt shift in the flow velocity of the fluid moving through the pipeline. At this instant, the conversion of the fluid's kinetic energy generates pressure surges, leading to vibration and noise. Additionally, if an electro-magnetic directional valve switches rapidly, the oil circuit may shut off abruptly— Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems

81 Hydraulic shocks can occur due to sudden changes in fluid direction or when a relief valve suddenly opens, causing the hydraulic pump to unload. These hydraulic shocks not only  lead to significant vibrations and noise but can also cause severe damage to the hydraulic system if the pressure spikes become excessively high. (3) Vibration and Noise Caused by  Cavitation. Hydraulic oil typically contains 2% to 5% air, making cavitation a common occurrence during hydraulic system operation. Once cavitation occurs, the resulting bubbles tr avel with the oil toward areas of higher pressure, where they collapse under the intense pressure, generating significant pressure fluctuations. These fluctuations lead to system v ibrations and produce noticeable noise. (4) Turbulence and Vortices. Within the fluid flow passages of a hydraulic system, changes in the cross-sectional area or flow direction cau se corresponding variations in flow velocity and pressure. When these changes occur abruptly, turbulence and vortex phenomena arise. Such turbulence and vortices significantly incr ease the interaction between the fluid and the pipe walls—or the pump and valve body surfaces—leading to vibrations and noise. 3) Measures to Reduce Vibration and Noise in Hydrauli c Systems

(1) The design incorporates low-noise motors, low-noise pumps, and components, along with elastic couplings, to reduce the pump's rotational speed. (2) Adopt an overhead  fuel tank to improve pump oil suction resistance, eliminate system air, install a pressure-relief circuit, extend the valve's directional switching time, equip the spool with a buf fered taper or grooves, and incorporate filters while increasing pipe diameters. (3) Use accumulators and rubber hoses to reduce vibrations caused by pressure pulsations. The accum ulator can absorb noise below 10 Hz, while high-frequency noise is effectively dampened by hydraulic hoses. (4) Use a vertical motor to submerge the hydraulic pump in the oil, redu cing gas noise. (5) Whenever possible, replace piping with hydraulic manifold blocks to minimize vibration. (6) Use a balanced motor rotor, and install vibration-damping pads on th e mounting surfaces of the motor, hydraulic pump, and hydraulic valves. Maintenance can be performed by replacing motor bearings or using other appropriate methods. (7) Covering th e hydraulic pump with a soundproof enclosure lined with sound-absorbing materials can effectively reduce noise. (8) Select appropriate pipe clamps, ensuring proper installation spa cing and securing strength. (9) Ensure proper concentricity when installing the hydraulic pump and motor coupling. (10) Isolate from or eliminate external vibration sources, and in crease the stiffness of connecting components to external loads. (11) At the oil outlet convergence point of the two pumps, turbulence often occurs. To mitigate this, slightly sepa rate the two pump outlets before they merge. Additionally, ensure that when the oils converge, their flow directions do not oppose each other directly—but instead form an angle les s than 90°. (12) Select an electro-hydraulic directional control valve with damping, and adjust the switching speed of the valve.

2. Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Hydraulic System Pressure Control Issues Pressure loss in hydraulic transmission systems is the most common failure, typically manifesting as no system pressure, inability to adjust pressure, pressure fluctuations, or uncontrolled unloading. 1) "System Stress-Free" Fault Diagnosis and Repair (1) During operation, the system suddenly dropped to zero pressure and became unresponsive to adjustments. This type of failure is most often caused by issues within the pressure regulation system itself. Possible reasons include: the damping orifice of the relief valve being blocked; foreign particles on the sealing surface of the relief valve; the main spool of the relief valve becoming stuck in the open position; the solenoid in the unloading directional control valve burning out, the wiring breaking, or the electrical signal failing to activate; and, in the case of proportional relief valves, the electric control signal may have been interrupted altogether. Maintenance methods: Clean or replace the overflow valve; inspect or replace the unloading directional control valve; inspect or replace the proportional overflow valve. (2) After the equipment has been shut down for a period of time and is restarted, the pressure reads zero. Possible causes for this failure include: the overflow valve being rusted in the open position; the hydraulic pump motor rotating in reverse; and issues with the hydraulic pump, as discussed in the case studies on diagnosing and repairing electromechanical system failures.

82 The oil filter is clogged, or the suction pipe has an air leak, preventing oil from being drawn up. Maintenance methods: Clean or replace the overflow valve; inspect and repair the motor wiring; check the oil filter and suction pipe. (3) After equipment components were inspected, disassembled, and replaced, the pressure dropped to zero. Possible causes of this failure include: the hydraulic pump not being securely tightened, preventing it from creating a working volume; insufficient oil in the pump, which prevents the formation of a sealing oil film; and the spool of the directional control valve being installed backward—particularly if the system uses an M-type valve with a mid-position, as reversing its installation will cause the system to lose pressure. Maintenance methods: Tighten or inspect the hydraulic pump; properly install the spool of the directional control valve. 2) Fault Diagnosis and Repair for "System Pressure Fails to Rise High and Adjustment Is Ineffective" This failure is typically caused by internal leakage, with the main reasons as follows: (1) The hydraulic pump wears out, creating clearances that prevent the system pressure from rising, while also causing the output flow to decrease. (2) Wear on the main spool and mating surfaces of the relief valve causes a drop in the control pressure of the relief valve, leading to a decrease in system pressure. (3) Wear in the hydraulic cylinder or hydraulic motor, or damage to the seals, causes the system to drop pressure or fail to maintain its original pressure—provided that The system contains multiple actuators; if the operating pressure of one actuator is abnormal while the pressures of the other actuators remain normal, it indicates that this particular actuator is faulty. (4) Gaps in valves and valve plates within the system can lead to leaks, which also cause a drop in system pressure. The repair method is as follows. (1) Inspect or replace the hydraulic pump. (2) Inspect or replace the relief valve. (3) Inspect or replace the hydraulic cylinder or hydraulic motor.

(4) Inspect or replace the relevant valves and valve plates. 3) Fault Diagnosis and Repair for "System Pressure Remains Unstable Despite Adjustment Efforts" The cause of this malfunction is typically a failed relief valve. When the main spool of the relief valve becomes stuck or corroded in the closed position, Symptoms of rising and unregulated system pressure will inevitably occur. When the pilot oil passage of the relief valve becomes blocked, the control pressure surges dramatically, causing the system pressure to rise sharply as well. Maintenance method: Clean, inspect, or replace the overflow valve.

4) Fault Diagnosis and Repair for "System Pressure Fluctuations" The cause of this failure is as follows. (1) Air has entered the hydraulic oil, and when system pressure is high, the resulting air bubbles collapse, causing fluctuations in system pressure. (2) Hydraulic pump wear causes system pressure fluctuations; improper rail installation and lubrication lead to uneven loading, which in turn results in pressure fluctuations. (3) The relief valve is worn, resulting in significant internal leakage. (4) Foreign objects have entered the relief valve, causing its internal condition to become unpredictable and leading to pressure instability. The repair method is as follows.

(1) Bleed the air out of the system. (2) Inspect or replace the hydraulic pump. (3) Reinstall the rails and apply extra lubrication. (4) Inspect or replace the relief valve. Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems

83 5) Fault Diagnosis and Repair for "Unloading Failure" For hydraulic systems that unload via a relief valve, the primary symptom of an "uncontrolled unloading" failure is non-zero unloading pressure. The causes of this issue include: excessively high preload on the relief valve's main spring, an overlong spring, or sticking of the main spool, among others. Maintenance method: Inspect or replace the overflow valve.

3. Hydraulic System Temperature Rise Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Typically, the normal operating temperature for hydraulic systems is between 40 and 60°C; exceeding 60°C can negatively impact the system. Causes of overheating failures in hydraulic systems Hydraulic systems frequently experience overheating during operation. Analysis reveals that the main causes of overheating are as follows: In various aspects.

(1) The hydraulic system design is unreasonable. ① The hydraulic system's oil tank has been designed with too small a capacity and insufficient heat dissipation area, and no coolin g device has been incorporated—or if one is present, its capacity is inadequate. ② The selected valve components are undersized, leading to excessively high oil flow velocities thr ough the valves and increased pressure losses, which in turn cause overheating. For instance, if an overflow valve is too small, or if the directional control valve in a differenti al circuit is sized solely based on the pump’s flow rate, this issue can occur. ③ In quantitative pump systems where the hydraulic pump capacity is chosen according to the fast-forward speed, most of the excess flow will typically bypass through the overflow  valve at high pressure (the system’s working pressure), resulting in heat generation during operation. ④ The system is not designed with an unloading circuit, so the hydraulic pump  does not unload when operation stops. As a result, the pump’s entire flow rate overflows under high pressure, leading to overflow losses and heat generation, which causes the temp erature to rise. ⑤ Excessive back pressure in the hydraulic system. For instance, in circuits using electro-hydraulic directional control valves, a certain level of back pressure m ust be maintained in the system even when the valve is not actuated (in the neutral position) to ensure reliable valve switching. However, if the system flow rate is high, this exc ess flow will bypass through the relief valve as control pressure, leading to overheating. ⑥ The system piping is too narrow and long, features numerous bends, and experiences freq uent cross-sectional changes, leading to significant local pressure losses as well as substantial frictional pressure losses along the pipe length, ultimately resulting in low syst em efficiency. (2) Poor manufacturing quality. Hydraulic components suffer from inadequate machining precision and assembly quality, leading to significant mechanical friction loss es between moving parts. Additionally, excessive clearance between mating components results in high internal and external leakage, causing substantial volumetric losses and rapid  temperature rise. (3) The system is severely worn. Many key components in the hydraulic system rely on clearance sealing, such as the gears in gear pumps paired with the pump housi ng and side plates, the cylinder block and swashplate in piston pumps and motors, the cylinder bore fitting tightly around the pistons, the spool and valve body in directional cont rol valves, and the slide spools and valve sleeves/valve bodies in other types of valves. Once wear increases in these hydraulic components, it can lead to internal leakage. Leakag e increases, leading to a rise in temperature, which in turn reduces the viscosity of the hydraulic oil. This, in turn, causes further internal leakage, ultimately resulting in hig her oil temperatures. One step higher. (4) Improper use of system oil. Hydraulic oil is a critical medium for maintaining the system's proper operation, and preserving its high qua lity is essential to ensuring optimal transmission performance and efficiency. If hydraulic oil with either excessively high or low viscosity is mistakenly used, it can lead to pre mature degradation of the oil, resulting in wear of moving components and subsequent overheating. (5) Improper system debugging. System pressure is regulated by a safety valve; how ever, if the safety valve is set to a pressure that’s either too high or too low, it can lead to increased system heating. For instance, if the safety valve is set too low, the hyd raulic cylinder won’t be able to overcome the external load when the load increases, causing it to stall. In this situation, the safety valve opens, allowing a large volume of oil  to flow back into the reservoir. Conversely, if the safety valve is set too high, it will cause the hydraulic oil to flow through the valve at an accelerated rate, increasing the f low and, consequently, generating more heat within the system. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial

Additionally, during manufacturing and operation, improper system adjustments—particularly when valve co mponents are not properly calibrated—can result in the valve stem failing to reach the set opening level, which in turn may cause the system temperature to rise. (6) Improper opera tion practices. These issues primarily arise when operators perform actions too quickly or forcefully, leading to hydraulic shock within the system. For instance, frequently moving  hydraulic cylinders to their limit positions while delaying the directional change can cause such shocks. Similarly, keeping valve spools partially open for extended periods may r esult in throttling, while system overloading—causing the relief valve to remain open continuously—can lead to mismatched on-off characteristics that don’t meet operational require ments. Additionally, excessive pressure drops can also contribute to system overheating. (7) Insufficient cooling in the hydraulic system. ① If the hydraulic system radiator and oi l tank are covered with dust, sludge, or other contaminants without being cleaned, an insulating layer will form, reducing the heat transfer coefficient or decreasing the heat diss ipation area, thereby affecting the overall cooling performance of the system. ② The exhaust fan speed is too low, resulting in insufficient airflow. ③ Hydraulic oil circuit blocka ge (e.g., the return line and cooler becoming clogged due to contaminants and impurities, leading to increased back pressure, and triggering the bypass valve) When opened, the hydr aulic oil flows directly to the tank without passing through the cooler, resulting in insufficient system cooling. ④ Prolonged continuous operation in an environment with excessive ly high temperatures will cause the hydraulic system to heat up; alternatively, if the operating environment differs significantly from the original equipment’s intended temperatur e range, it can also lead to inadequate cooling of the system. 2) Hydraulic System Overheating Failure Repair Methods To ensure the proper functioning of the hydraulic system, it i s essential to keep the system temperature within the normal range. If the hydraulic system overheats, first identify the underlying cause before implementing the appropriate and t argeted corrective measures. (1) Select hydraulic oil according to the instructions in the hydraulic system manual, ensuring the oil remains clean to prevent filter clogging. Addit ionally, regularly check the oil level to maintain an adequate supply of hydraulic fluid. (2) Regularly inspect and maintain wear-prone components to prevent leaks caused by severe  wear. Hydraulic pumps, electric motors, and areas with mating clearances are particularly susceptible to leakage due to wear, which can also lead to reduced volumetric efficiency  and accelerated system heating. Therefore, schedule routine inspections and promptly replace any damaged components to minimize volume losses and effectively prevent leaks. (3) Str ictly adjust the system pressure according to the instructions in the user manual, avoiding excessive pressure and ensuring that safety valves, overload valves, and other component s operate under normal conditions. (4) Regularly clean the radiator and fuel tank surfaces to keep them free of dirt and debris, ensuring efficient heat dissipation. (5) Operate an d use equipment properly—avoid making movements too fast or abrupt during operation. Whenever possible, do not leave the valve stem in a partially open position to prevent prolonge d overflow of high-pressure hydraulic oil under pressure, thereby minimizing heat generation due to throttling. (6) Regularly check the rotational speed of the power source and the  tension of the fan belt to ensure the fan maintains adequate speed and sufficient cooling capacity. (7) Ensure that the actual operating temperature of the hydraulic system matche s its designed allowable operating temperature range. (8) System overheating issues caused by unreasonable design should be addressed by improving the system through technological  innovations, modifications, or redesigns. 4. Speed Control System Fault Diagnosis and Repair The speed instability in hydraulic systems primarily manifests as creeping, inability t o adjust speed, unstable speed, and slow response. "Crawling" Fault Diagnosis and Repair Crawling is a jerky, intermittent motion phenomenon that occurs when hydraulic systems operate at low speeds—it’s one of the more common issues in hydraulic systems. The causes of this failure are outlined below. Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems 85

(1) Air has entered the oil, causing the actuator to move slowly and resulting in a delayed response. (2) The pressure is set too low, cannot be increased, and drifts downward, while the combined load—including all types of resistance—roughly balances the hydraulic pressure, causing the actuator to appear as if it’s moving but isn’t actually doing so. (3) Excessive fluctuations in system pressure and flow lead to uneven movement of the actuator components. (4) The hydraulic system is severely worn, and increased working pressure leads to a significant rise in internal leakage. While the actuator moves at its normal speed when unloaded, its speed immediately drops as soon as a load is applied. (5) The guide rail is not parallel to the hydraulic cylinder's direction of motion, or the guide rail is roughened, leading to poor lubrication and high resistance, which makes the hydraulic cylinder move with difficulty and instability. (6) Circuit malfunctions can also lead to improper operation of the actuator.
The repair method is as follows.
(1) Remove air from the hydraulic oil.

(2) Adjust the system pressure to the appropriate level. (3) Ensure that excessive fluctuations in system pressure and flow remain within a reasonable range. (4) Inspect or replace excessively worn components. (5) Inspect and maintain the guide rails and hydraulic cylinders.

(6) Inspect and repair related circuits. "Speed Not Adjustable" Fault Diagnosis and Repair "The 'speed cannot be adjusted' fault is caused by a malfunctioning throttle valve or speed control valve." Maintenance method: Inspect or replace the throttle valve or speed control valve. "Unstable Speed" Fault Diagnosis and Repair The cause of the failure is as follows. (1) After air enters the hydraulic system, the gas is compressed under high pressure. Once the load is removed and system pressure drops, the compressed gas rapidly expands, causing a sudden increase in the speed of the hydraulic actuator. (2) The throttling port of the flow control valve suffers from a low-speed stability issue, which is related to factors such as the port's structural design and hydraulic oil contamination. (3) Changes in temperature lead to variations in leakage, which in turn cause fluctuations in the flow supplied to the load—similar to how temperature changes affect system pressure.
The repair method is as follows.
(1) Bleed the air out of the system. (2) Replace with the appropriate throttle valve.
(3) Enhance system cooling. 4) "Slow Speed" Fault Diagnosis and Repair The cause of the failure is as follows.

(1) Hydraulic pump wear leads to reduced volumetric efficiency. (2) The directional control valve is worn, resulting in internal leakage. (3) The relief valve is set to a pressure that is too low, causing a large volume of oil to flow back into the tank through the relief valve. (4) Wear in the actuator components leads to internal leakage. Case Studies in Mechatronic System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance, Page 86 (5) There is an undiscovered leak in the system. (6) The throttle valve or flow control valve connected in series in the circuit is not fully open. (7) The oil passage is blocked. (8) The system is overloaded. The repair method is as follows. (1) Inspect or replace the hydraulic pump. (2) Inspect or replace the directional control valve. (3) Adjust the relief valve pressure to the appropriate value. (4) Inspect or replace excessively worn actuators. (5) Seal the leak. (6) Fully open the throttle valve or flow control valve connected in series within the circuit. (7) Clear the oil passages. (8) Reduce the system's load to a reasonable level.

5. Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Pressure Surges in Hydraulic Systems Hydraulic shock is one of the common failures. In hydraulic transmission systems, the pressure of the fluid inside the system can suddenly fluctuate at a specific moment due to rapid directional changes or the abrupt opening or closing of valve ports. 1) Causes of hydraulic shock (1) Sudden closure or opening of a valve. When a liquid flows through a pipe, if the valve is closed abruptly, the flow velocity instantly drops to zero. At this moment, the liquid's kinetic energy is converted into pressure energy, causing a sudden increase in fluid pressure and generating a pressure shock wave. Conversely, when the valve opens suddenly, a drop in pressure occurs instead. (2) Inertial forces of actuators. The inertial forces generated by high-speed hydraulic actuators can also cause hydraulic shocks within the system. For instance, when industrial robotic arms or the slewing motors of hydraulic excavator turntables brake or reverse direction—resulting in the sudden closure of the oil discharge lines—the rotating mechanisms, still moving due to inertia, continue to spin, leading to a sharp increase in pressure and triggering a hydraulic shock. (3) Components exhibit sluggish response actions. In hydraulic systems, certain components’ delayed or unresponsive behavior can also lead to hydraulic shocks. For instance, a pressure-limiting variable hydraulic pump may fail to promptly reduce its displacement when pressure rises, resulting in pressure surges. Similarly, if the relief valve cannot open quickly enough, it may cause excessive pressure overshoot, both of which can trigger pressure shocks. 2) Troubleshooting Hydraulic Shock Faults (1) Maximize the time required for valve closure and braking/reversing of moving components. If the braking/reversing time of moving parts can exceed 0.2 seconds, the resulting imp act will be significantly reduced. This can be achieved in hydraulic systems by using directional control valves with adjustable switching times. For instance, employing electro-hy draulic directional valves or valves equipped with tapered shoulder spools allows precise control over the movement speed of the main spool, thereby enabling fine-tuning of the swi tching time. (2) Properly design valve ports. Limit pipeline flow velocity and the speed of moving components to ensure smoother deceleration during braking. For instance, in machi ne tool hydraulic systems, pipeline flow velocities are typically restricted to below 4.5 m/s, while the speed of hydraulically driven moving parts should generally not exceed 10 m /min. Alternatively, reduce the fluid flow rate gradually before the spool valve fully closes—for example, by modifying the structure of the spool’s control edges, such as cutting  rectangular or V-shaped straight grooves along the edges of the spool’s land, or shaping the edges into a conical throttling surface. Compared to right-angled control edges, these  designs significantly minimize hydraulic shock. In external cylindrical grinders, a pre-braking mechanism is applied to the pilot directional control valve, followed by a rapid jum p of the main directional control valve to its mid-position, instantly supplying pressurized oil to both chambers of the worktable cylinder (with the main valve configured in a P-s hape). This approach ensures smooth and controlled movement of the worktable. 87 Smooth, impact-free stopping. The directional control valve in the closed-loop travel circuit can b e designed with an H-port configuration, ensuring that when the valve rapidly shifts to its neutral position, both chambers of the motor are interconnected and connected to the oil  tank—thereby reducing shock pressure during braking. (3) Appropriately increase the pipe diameter and minimize the pipeline length as much as possible. Enlarging the pipe diameter  not only helps reduce flow velocity but also decreases the speed of pressure shock waves. Shortening the pipeline length aims to minimize the propagation time of pressure shock wa ves; if necessary, relief valves can be installed near the shock zone, along with accumulators or other buffering devices, to achieve this goal. Accumulators not only reduce the di stance over which pressure waves travel, thereby cutting down the corresponding propagation time, but also effectively absorb the impact pressure itself. (4) Install a cushioning d evice at the end of the hydraulic cylinder. Control the oil discharge rate at the cylinder’s end (e.g., using a unidirectional throttle valve) to ensure smooth, impact-free deceler ation as the cylinder reaches its stop position. In some machine tools where high precision is not critical, it’s also possible to connect both chambers of the hydraulic cylinder d irectly.
The oil passages momentarily connect when the directional control valve returns to its neutral position.

(5) Use a flexible hose. This increases the system's elasticity, h elping to reduce pressure surges. The causes of pressure surge failures in hydraulic systems and the corresponding repair methods are shown in Table 3.2. Table 3.2 Common Hydraulic  System Shock Faults and Repair Methods
