6. Diagnosis and Rep air of Hydraulic Cylinder Crawling Faults In hydraulic systems, creep is a relatively common malfunction. It occurs during low-speed operation of hydraulic cylinders or hydraulic motors, resulting in an intermittent, uneven motion characterized by alternating jerks—where the piston rod or motor rotor suddenly jumps forward followed by brief pauses—and unstable, fluctuating movement of the pressure gauge needle. 1) Causes and Maintenance of Crawling Faults Caused by Hydraulic Cylinder Binding

(1) Cause of the failure. When a hydraulic cylinder is in motion, it must overcome not only the resistance required to move the load but also the internal friction within the cylinder itself. If the internal friction resistance becomes excessively high, it indicates that the hydraulic cylinder is experiencing binding. Because binding occurs during cylinder operation, this makes the topic particularly relevant for the "Case Studies in Diagnostics and Maintenance of Mechatronic Systems" tutorial. 88
Most prone to vibration and exhibiting crawling behavior.

(2) Fault Diagnosis and Repair. ① Improper assembly. Without applying load to the hydraulic cylinder, measure its minimum operating resistance. If the resistance is excessively high, it indicates the presence of binding. Such binding typically arises from incorrect hydraulic cylinder assembly practices. Therefore, during the assembly process, strictly follow the specified assembly procedures to ensure that the piston and piston rod move freely without being subjected to lateral forces or torsional stresses. Additionally, verify that the sealing elements maintain appropriate resistance levels and are in optimal condition. ② The reaction force from the load causes the hydraulic cylinder to become skewed. This binding phenomenon in the hydraulic cylinder, resulting from the applied load force, typically becomes noticeable only when the cylinder is pushing the load into motion. For instance, a hydraulic cylinder equipped with base mounts may experience insufficient rigidity in its feet; as a result, when the cylinder moves the load, the reaction force from the load induces flexible deformation in the foot mounts, leading to skewing of the cylinder and the onset of binding. Therefore, during installation, hydraulic cylinders must not only maintain adequate positional accuracy but also ensure sufficient structural rigidity. 2) Causes of Creep Failure Due to Seals and Maintenance Measures Hydraulic cylinders are significantly affected by seal rings when it comes to the phenomenon of creep. In most cases, the first step should be to check whether the piston rod support seals and piston seals are tightened too much. If creep occurs when the hydraulic cylinder's movement speed drops below 5 mm/s, no other solutions will work effectively. When selecting seals, care should be taken to ensure proper performance. To eliminate creeping, the seal material must have a minimal difference between its dynamic and static friction coefficients. Additionally, the sealing design itself should minimize resistance while maximizing rigidity; after being subjected to tensile forces, it should exhibit low elongation. Ideally, the sealing material would possess negative friction characteristics—meaning that as sliding speed increases, so does the resistance. For instance, seals made from leather or polytetrafluoroethylene are well-suited for low-speed applications in hydraulic cylinders. However, V-shaped seals containing only nitrile rubber are not recommended for use in low-speed scenarios. 3) Causes and Maintenance of Crawling Faults Caused by Hydraulic Component Wear

(1) Wear of internal pump components. Wear increases clearances, leading to insufficient or fluctuating flow and pressure output from the hydraulic pump. When moving parts operate at low speeds, variations in their resistance—combined with the pump's inability to adjust pressure—inevitably result in creeping motion. (2) Wear of valve components and hydraulic cylinders. As wear increases the clearance between parts, it allows communication between the high-pressure and low-pressure chambers, leading to insufficient pressure. Consequently, under varying external frictional resistance, creeping motion is bound to occur even during low-speed operation. Component wear issues are categorized into two types: normal wear and abnormal wear. Normal wear can typically be addressed by repairing or replacing the affected parts, while in cases of abnormal wear, it’s crucial to identify the root cause and implement appropriate corrective measures. 4) Causes and Maintenance of Creeping Failures Caused by Working Medium Contamination

(1) Cause of the failure. Accelerating the degradation of hydraulic oil performance. Water and air present in the oil, combined with their thermal energy, are key factors driving oil oxidation, while metall ic microparticles in the oil act as catalysts, speeding up the oxidation process. Additionally, water and suspended air bubbles in the oil significantly reduce the strength of the  oil film between moving parts, impairing lubrication, accelerating oxidative deterioration, and leading to cavitation. This, in turn, causes rapid wear and damage to hydraulic comp onents, ultimately resulting in vibrations and creep in the hydraulic system. (2) Fault Diagnosis and Troubleshooting.

① Reduce external contamination. Before assembly, all compone nts of the hydraulic system—such as pipes and reservoirs—must be thoroughly cleaned to remove residual debris and surface oxides using mechanical methods, followed by acid cleaning . After assembly, the entire hydraulic system should undergo a comprehensive cleaning process; ideally, this should be done using the same fluid that will be used during system ope ration. In particular, hydraulic servo systems require multiple cleaning cycles to ensure optimal cleanliness. Additionally, air vents on the reservoir must be fitted with air filt ers, and oil should be added via an oil filtration vehicle. Exposed components should be equipped with dust-proof seals, and regular inspections are essential to maintain system in tegrity. Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems

89 Check and replace regularly. Maintenance of the hydraulic transmission system, as well as the replacemen t and removal of hydraulic components, should be carried out in a dust-free area. ② Remove impurities generated by the system. Appropriate-precision filters should be installed at  the relevant points in the system, and filter elements must be regularly inspected, cleaned, or replaced. ③ Control the operating temperature of the hydraulic oil. Operating the hy draulic oil at too high a temperature will accelerate oxidation and degradation, leading to the formation of various byproducts that shorten its service life. Therefore, it’s impor tant to limit the oil’s maximum operating temperature. ④ Regularly inspect and replace hydraulic oil. Follow the requirements outlined in the hydraulic equipment manual and the rel evant maintenance procedures to schedule periodic inspections and oil changes. When replacing the hydraulic oil, be sure to clean the oil tank, flush the system pipelines, and thor oughly rinse the hydraulic components.

7. System Leak Fault Diagnosis and Repair System leaks are categorized into internal and external leaks, and depending on the severity of the  leak, they can manifest in various forms, such as oil film scraping, seepage, dripping, and spraying. Oil film scraping occurs between relatively moving components, like sliding o r reciprocating pairs in rotating parts. Seepage typically happens at the junctions of end covers and valve plates. Dripping is most common around pipe fittings and connections. Sp raying, on the other hand, often results from broken pipes or improperly installed seals. The underlying causes of these failures are as follows: (1) Sealing failure can occur due to poor seal quality, incorrect assembly, damage, prolonged aging and deterioration over time, or incompatibility with the working medium.

(2) Relative motion between mating parts causes increased clearance and higher internal leakage, or can lead to scoring on the contact surfaces, resulting in both internal and external leaks. (3) The oil temperature is too high. (4) System operating pressure is too high. (5) Incorrect design of sealing dimensions, poor machining accuracy, and improper assembly lead to internal and external leaks. The repair method is as follows. (1) Replace with high-quality seals. (2) Adjust the clearances of the relative moving parts to ensure they fall within the normal range. (3) Enhance cooling to maintain the oil temperature at an appropriate level. (4) Adjust the system pressure to normal pressure. (5) Redesign, manufacture, and assemble the seals.

8. Action Control Failure Diagnosis and Repair The loss of control in the hydraulic system's actuating components primarily manifests as failure to initiate or terminate movements according to the programmed sequence, along with unexpected motions and unstable operation. Unable to initiate action diagnostics and repairs according to the set procedure. The malfunction was caused by the directional control valve failing to open properly. Here's the root cause of the issue: (1) The spool of the directional control valve is stuck. (2) The spool rod of the directional control valve is bent. (3) The solenoid of the directional control valve is burned out. (4) The wire has come loose. (5) Control relay failure, resulting in abnormal transmission of electrical signals, as well as other circuit-related issues causing interruption of the electrical signal. (6) Improper operation. If certain switches and buttons are not in the correct position, they can cut off the control signal. (7) The throttle valve and flow control valve connected in series within the circuit have become stuck, preventing them from performing their normal functions. If an unexpected blockage occurs anywhere along the oil fluid path, the system will fail to start properly. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial

90 (8) For other reasons, the hydraulic power source cannot transition from the relief state to the working state, nor can it properly drive the actuator to move. (9) Occasional failures occur in the load section, resulting in situations where it cannot be pushed forward. The repair method is as follows. (1) Inspect or replace the directional control valve.

(2) Inspect or replace the reversing valve pushrod. (3) Inspect or replace the directional control valve solenoid. (4) Reconnect the loose wires. (5) Inspect or replace the faulty relay. (6) Correctly operating switches and buttons in the system. (7) Inspect or replace the throttle valve or speed control valve. (8) Identify the cause and ensure the hydraulic power source properly transitions from the relief state to the operational state. (9) Identify the cause and eliminate the fault occurring in the load section.

2) Unable to complete action fault diagnosis and repair in the set order. The malfunction was caused by the directional control valve failing to close properly. Here are the reasons for the failure: (1) The spool of the directional control valve is stuck and cannot return to its original position. (2) The directional control valve spring has broken, preventing the spool from returning to its original position. (3) The electrical signal of the directional control valve did not disappear in time. The repair method is as follows. (1) Inspect and replace the spool of the directional control valve. (2) Replace the directional control valve spring. (3) Inspect and replace the directional control valve solenoid. 3) Diagnosis and Repair of Unexpected Motion Faults The malfunction was primarily caused by a directional control valve failure and an electrical fault. The reasons for the failure are as follows: (1) The spool of the directional control valve is installed backward. (2) The directional control valve is severely worn. (3) Incorrect electrical signal from the directional control valve. The repair method is as follows. (1) Reinstall the valve core in the correct direction. (2) Replace the directional control valve. (3) Inspect and replace the directional control valve circuit. 3.2 Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Components
3.2.1 Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Gear Pumps

Structure and Working Principle of Gear Pumps The structure of the domestically produced CB-B gear pump is shown in Figure 3.4. It features a split three-plate design (the three plates refer to end cover 1, end cover 5, and Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems). 91 The structure of pump body 4. A pair of gears 3 inside the pump body are individually secured to the drive shaft 7 and the driven shaft 9 using keys, with the drive shaft 7 connected to the electric motor. Drive the rotation. 5—End Cover; 2—Screw; 3—Gear; 4—Pump Body; 6—Sealing Ring; 7—Main Shaft; 8—Positioning Pin; 9—Driven Shaft; 10—Bearing; 11—Plug Figure 3.4: Structural Diagram of the Domestically Produced CB-B Gear Pump As shown in Figure 3.5, this is a schematic diagram illustrating the working principle of a gear pump. When the two gears of the pump rotate in the direction indicated, the oil suction chamber at the bottom gradually expands as the meshing teeth progressively disengage, creating a partial vacuum. Meanwhile, oil from the reservoir flows into this expanding space. Under the action of atmospheric pressure, oil enters the suction chamber via the suction pipe, completely filling the inter-tooth spaces. As the gears rotate, the oil is carried upward into the pressurized oil chamber. Due to the gradual engagement of the meshing gears, the volume of the pressurized chamber continuously decreases, forcing the oil outward and delivering it into the pressure pipeline. Throughout the operation of the gear pump, as long as the rotational direction of the two gears remains unchanged, the positions of the suction and pressurized chambers will also stay fixed. Unchanging. The tooth contact line at the meshing point continuously separates the high- and low-pressure chambers, simultaneously performing oil distribution. As a result, gear pumps do not require a dedicated distribution mechanism—this is what sets them apart from other types of positive-displacement hydraulic pumps. Figure 3.5: Schematic Diagram of a Gear Pump Operating Principle

2. Gear Pump Disassembly, Assembly, and Usage Notes Disassembly and Assembly of Gear Pumps Proper disassembly and assembly of gear pumps are fundamental to troubleshooting and repairing gear pump failures. The steps for disassembling and assembling a gear pump are as follows: (1) Use an Allen wrench to loosen the 6 Allen screws, then use a pin extractor to remove the two pins. (2) Remove the back cover, then take out the needle roller bearing and place it in the pre-prepared kerosene. (3) Remove the pump body, and use an external cylindrical spring caliper to take out the two spring retaining rings—one on the long shaft and one on the short shaft. (4) Lay the front cover flat (using two parallel shims placed beneath it to prevent the long shaft from resting directly on the workbench surface), and refer to the mobile phone electrical system fault diagnosis and repair case study tutorial. 92 Gently tap out the long and short shafts using a hammer and copper rod, then carefully remove both gears along with the respective long and short shafts. Finally, dismantle the sealing ring, completing the entire disassembly process. (5) After all disassembled parts have been cleaned with kerosene, replace or repair any damaged or wear-prone components (such as sealing rings), then reassemble them in the reverse order of disassembly. 2) Precautions for Using Gear Pumps Gear pumps are widely used as the pressure source in hydraulic systems for vehicles and mobile equipment, thanks to their simple design, compact size, lightweight construction (mos t gear pumps feature aluminum alloy pump bodies), strong self-priming capability, excellent contamination resistance, and ease of maintenance and inspection. (1) Preparations befor e installation: Before installing the pump, fill it completely with hydraulic oil and rotate the drive gear to ensure oil reaches all mating surfaces. Verify that the pump’s rotati on direction matches that of the drive shaft. Thoroughly clean the pipelines according to relevant regulations (welded pipes must undergo pickling followed by rinsing) to remove de bris, scale, and other contaminants. (2) Drive Method: Gear pumps can be powered by either an electric motor or an internal combustion engine as the prime mover. However, the pump’ s transmission system must not impose additional axial or radial forces on the gear pump’s driving gear. The connection between the pump shaft extension and the prime mover shaft e xtension should utilize a floating coupling; flexible couplings and cross-slide couplings are recommended. The radial runout of the coupling should not exceed 0.1 mm. In cases wher e structural constraints necessitate directly inserting the splined shaft into the corresponding spline bore of the prime mover’s drive shaft for direct power transmission, the rad ial clearance between the internal splines and the splined shaft, as well as the lateral clearance of the key, must both be at least 0.15 mm to ensure proper torque transfer via fl oating action and to prevent the generation of unwanted radial internal forces. Generally, belt and drive gears are not used to directly power gear pumps. However, if structural co nstraints absolutely require it, radial support should be added, or hydraulic pump products with end covers equipped with radially supported bearings should be selected. (3) Suctio n height. The pump's suction height should be as low as possible. The pump's self-priming capability varies depending on its displacement, but generally, it should not fall below 1 6 kPa. Typically, the pump's suction height is required to be no more than 0.5 meters; however, in piping systems with longer inlet lines, the diameter of the inlet pipe should be  increased to prevent excessive flow resistance, which could lead to poor oil intake and negatively impact the pump's performance. (4) Selection and Filtration of Hydraulic Fluid. T he working fluid should be selected strictly according to the specifications provided in the pump’s product manual, as this will help extend the pump’s service life. In many cases,  early failures of gear pumps are caused by fluid contamination; therefore, it’s essential to filter the working oil. Since low-pressure gear pumps exhibit lower sensitivity to con tamination, filters with relatively lower filtration accuracy can be used. However, high-pressure gear pumps are more susceptible to contamination, so systems should incorporate fi lters with higher filtration precision. (5) Operation. Before starting the hydraulic pump, check that the pipe fittings or flange connection screws at the inlet and outlet ports ar e securely tightened and that the seals are reliable. Also, verify whether the safety valve in the system is set to the correct pressure setting. Finally, perform a jog test to con firm that the pump is rotating in the correct direction. During operation, slightly loosen the outlet connection to bleed out any air. Avoid starting the pump under load, as well a s stopping it while it’s still under load. The pump should undergo at least 10 minutes of no-load operation and a short period of loaded operation before starting work, followed by  a check of the pump's performance. Under no circumstances should the pump exhibit leaks, excessive heating, or unusual noises. If the pump is not used for an extended period, it’s  best to store it separately from the prime mover. When resuming use, allow the pump to run at no load for at least 10 minutes, followed by the routine inspection procedures outlin ed above. 3. Common Faults and Maintenance of Gear Pumps As usage time increases, the volumetric efficiency of gear pumps declines, and in severe cases, they may even fail to opera te properly. The primary cause is surface wear resulting from the relative sliding motion between rotating components like gears and drive shafts, as well as other mating parts. Th e main areas where wear occurs in gear pumps include the interaction between the drive shaft and its bushing (or needle bearings), the contact between the pump housing cavity and t he outer surfaces of the gears, and the interface between the gear end faces and the pump cover. When wear becomes significant enough to cause the pump’s key performance indicators  to fall below specifications, the pump should be disassembled to identify the specific wear locations and extent, followed by implementing appropriate repair measures. The repair methods for the main components of the seal ring gear pump  are as follows. (1) Measures to address gear surface wear. Gear oil pumps typically rotate in one direction only, causing wear to occur on just one side of the gear teeth. To rest ore performance, you can remove burrs from the worn gear teeth using an oilstone, thoroughly clean the gears, and then reposition them so that the previously non-meshing tooth surf aces now engage properly with each other. This simple adjustment effectively revives the pump’s operational efficiency. (2) End-face Repair: The gear end faces wear down due to rel ative rotation against the bearing housing or front/rear covers. In mild cases, this results in scoring, which can be removed and polished using a grinding method. However, if the  wear is severe, the gears should be resurfaced on a surface grinder. Note:  Both gears must be ground simultaneously on the surface grinder to ensure that the thickness difference between them remains within 0.005 mm. Additionally, it’s crucial to maintai n both the perpendicularity of the end faces to the gear bore axis and the parallelism of the two end faces—both within 0.005 mm. After grinding, use an oilstone to round off any s harp edges, but  never chamfer  them. The goal is simply to eliminate burrs and flash, leaving the surfaces smooth and free of imperfections. (3) Repair of pump shafts (long and short shafts). The wear typically  occurs on the outer surface of the shaft where it contacts the needle roller bearings (in gear pumps using a needle roller bearing design with a fixed end clearance) or on the out er surface that mates with the floating bushing (in gear pumps featuring a floating bushing design offering automatic end-clearance compensation). When the pump shaft shows minor w ear, polishing can be used for repair, accompanied by replacing the needle roller bearings or bushings. However, if the wear is severe and the clearance exceeds acceptable limits s ignificantly, not only should the needle roller bearings or bushings be replaced, but the drive shaft itself must also undergo either chrome plating or buildup welding to increase  its diameter—followed by grinding back to the standard size—or, alternatively, the shaft may need to be re-machined entirely to replace it with a new one. (4) Bearing Race Repair.  Wear on the bearing race typically occurs at the inner bore where it contacts the gear. If the end faces are worn or exhibit burrs and scoring, the four bearing races can be placed  on a surface grinder, using the end face that does not contact the gear as a reference. Grind the scored end faces flat in a single operation, ensuring the final precision remains  within a tolerance of 0.01 mm. Generally, bearing races experience minimal wear; however, if wear is severe, they can be lapped, or the bore diameter can be slightly enlarged foll owed by the reselection of appropriate needle rollers. Alternatively, the bearing races may need to be replaced entirely. (5) Pump body maintenance. Pump body wear typically occurs  in the suction chamber. For symmetrical gear pumps, simply flipping the pump body 180° will convert the suction chamber into a pressure chamber, restoring its operational capabili ty. In the case of asymmetrical pump designs, repair can be achieved through electroplating with a bronze alloy or by brush plating; alternatively, a copper sleeve insertion method  can also be used for restoration. Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems, p. 95 3.2.2 Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Vane Pumps

Structure and Working Principle of Vane Pumps As shown in Figure 3.6, this is a diagram illustrating the structure and operating principle of the YB1 vane pump. It primarily consists of a drive shaft, stator, rotor, and... It consists of components such as the vanes, pump body, and pump cover. The stator, rotor, vanes, and distribution plate can first be assembled into a single integrated unit before being installed inside the front and rear covers. The inner surface of the stator is approximately elliptical, with the rotor mounted concentrically inside the stator. Two suction zones and two pressure zones are arranged symmetrically, ensuring that the suction and pressure areas experience balanced hydraulic forces. As the rotor rotates, the vanes extend outward due to centrifugal force and the hydraulic pressure at their roots, maintaining close contact with the inner surface of the stator. This creates sealed working chambers between the vanes, the outer cylindrical surface of the rotor, the inner surface of the stator, and the front and rear distribution plates. With each full rotation of the rotor, the system completes two cycles of oil suction and delivery. (a) Structural diagram

(b) Exterior view 1—Pump cover; 2—Pump body; 3—Rotor; 4—Stator; 5—Vanes; 6—Drive shaft Figure 3.6: Structure and Operating Principle of the YB1 Vane Pump Disassembly, Assembly, and Usage Notes for Vane Pumps Disassembly and Assembly of Vane Pumps (1) Loosen the set screws and disassemble the left and right pump bodies. (2) Remove the drive shaft and disassemble the pump core assembly. (3) Loosen the set screws, remove the left and right distribution plates, extract the rotor and vanes, and then proceed to disassemble the remaining components. (4) Cleaning, inspection.

2) Precautions for Using Vane Pumps The main advantages of vane pumps include uniform flow, smooth operation, low noise levels, and a compact design. Vane pumps are widely used in hydraulic systems, particularly in fixed-installation hydraulic equipment and marine applications. Double-acting high-pressure variable-displacement vane pumps are also suitable for mobile machinery. Typically, the hydraulic systems in metal-cutting machine tools operate at relatively low power levels (below 20 kW) and moderate pressures (commonly around 7 MPa), while demanding stable pump output flow, minimal noise, and extended service life. By combining a low-pressure, high-flow pump with a high-pressure, low-flow pump to form a tandem vane pump, operators can achieve three distinct flow rates through simple on-off switching—making it ideal for machining equipment that requires rapid reciprocating motions combined with significantly varying working feed speeds. Moreover, the new generation of high-performance double-acting variable-displacement vane pumps is not only well-suited for stationary hydraulic systems but can also replace external gear pumps in hydraulic systems for mobile machinery. Terms of use are outlined below.

(1) Preparations before installation: Thoroughly clean the pipes according to relevant regulations (welded pipes must undergo pickling followed by rinsing) to remove dirt, oxide scale, and other contaminants. Mechatronic System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial

96 (2) Drive Method: The vane pump can be powered by either an electric motor or an internal combustion engine as the prime mover. However, the pump’s transmission system must not impose additional axial or radial forces on the vane pump’s drive shaft. The coaxial alignment between the pump’s drive shaft and the prime mover’s output shaft should be maintained within 0.1 mm, and flexible couplings are recommended whenever possible to prevent the pump shaft from being subjected to bending moments and axial loads. Additionally, the rotation direction of the drive shaft must comply with the product specifications. (3) Oil suction height. Typically, the pump's oil suction height should not exceed 0.5 meters. In piping systems with longer suction lines, the diameter of the suction pipe should be increased to prevent excessive flow resistance, which could lead to poor oil intake and negatively impact the pump's performance. (4) Selection and Filtration of Hydraulic Fluid. The working fluid should be selected strictly according to the pump’s product specifications to ensure a longer service life for the pump. A wear-resistant hydraulic oil with a viscosity range of 17–38 mm²/s is most suitable (24 mm²/s is recommended). The hydraulic fluid should be kept clean, with system filtration accuracy no lower than 0.025 mm. Additionally, a filter with a filtration rating of 0.070 to 0.15 mm should be installed separately at the oil suction port to prevent the intake of dirt and impurities. The flow capacity of the suction filter must be at least twice the pump's rated flow rate. (5) If the pump operates at a lower speed, the pump's suction inlet should be positioned upward during installation to facilitate oil intake upon startup. (6) Startup. Before starting the hydraulic pump, check whether the pipe fittings or flange connection screws at the inlet and outlet ports are securely tightened and if the seals are reliable. Also, verify that the safety valve in the system is set to the correct pressure setting. Additionally, perform a jog test to confirm that the pump’s rotation direction is correct. For the first startup, it’s best to fill the pump completely with oil and manually rotate the coupling—ensure the rotational force feels smooth and effortless. When starting the pump for the first time after initial operation or after a prolonged period of inactivity, an air suction phenomenon may occur. To prevent this, install a bleed v alve at the pump’s outlet or slightly loosen the outlet connections. Connect the port to evacuate air, and perform a trial run under no-load conditions as much as possible. (7) Mai ntenance: When adjusting the displacement and pressure of the variable vane pump, first loosen the lock nut. Pay close attention to the direction in which you turn the adjustment s crew—whether increasing or decreasing the displacement and pressure—as you make these adjustments. After completing the adjustments, securely tighten the lock nut. Additionally, en sure that the set pressure of the hydraulic system’s safety valve does not exceed 1.25 times the pump’s rated pressure. Avoid operating the pump continuously at excessively high or  low temperatures; if necessary, use a heat exchanger (including both coolers and heaters) to regulate the oil temperature. Maintain the oil tank at its normal liquid level and rep lenish the oil promptly as needed. Regularly replace the hydraulic oil according to specified intervals. Routinely inspect and clean the oil filter to ensure the pump can smoothly  draw in the oil. After the pump has been running for a while, vibrations may cause the mounting screws or the flange bolts at the inlet and outlet ports to loosen. Therefore, regul arly check these connections and retighten them promptly to prevent any loosening. 3. Common Faults and Maintenance of Vane Pumps

A Case Study Tutorial on Diagnostics and Maintenance of Elect romechanical Systems 98 1) Stator Repair When a vane pump is operating, the vanes are pressed firmly against the inner surface of the stator due to the hydraulic oil pressure at the bottom and the centrifugal force acting on them, leading to wear on the stator surface. Notably, the stator surface on the suction side experiences more severe wear compared to the other side. For double-acting vane pumps, if the wear and scoring on the stator surface are relatively minor, the surface can be polished using metallographic sandpaper before reuse. However, if the wear is extensive, the stator should be reconditioned on a dedicated stator grinding machine. Alternatively, the stator can be flipped 180°, swapping the positions of the suction chamber and the oil chamber, while simultaneously creating new positioning pin holes symmetrically opposite the original ones—thus allowing the pump to continue functioning. In the case of variable pumps, where the stator surface is cylindrical, it can be clamped securely in a lathe or grinder using soft jaws for polishing and repair. Additionally, worn areas of the stator surface can also be repaired by brush plating. 2) Repair of the distribution plate and side plates The distribution plate and side plates often suffer from end-face wear and tearing. In principle, as long as the total depth of the tearing on the end face isn’t excessive (e.g., l ess than 0.8 mm), the torn grooves can be removed using a surface grinder, followed by polishing before reassembly and continued use. However, two key considerations must be kept i n mind: First, after grinding down the end face to a certain dimension, the depth of the pump body’s bore must also be reduced accordingly; otherwise, the axial assembly clearance  will increase. Therefore, it’s crucial to refer to the assembly drawing to maintain the proper relationship within the axial dimension chain. Second, after repairing the end face,  the dimensions of the unloading triangular grooves may become shorter—or even disappear entirely. If these grooves aren’t properly restored, it could negatively impact the eliminat ion of oil trapping phenomena. Thus, after grinding the distribution plate’s end face, the dimensions of the unloading triangular grooves should be carefully extended using a trian gular file or milling process. However, care must be taken not to overextend them, as this could inadvertently cause the pressure chamber and suction chamber to communicate during  operation, leading to a reduction in the pump’s output flow. Finally, ensure that the repaired distribution plate maintains proper parallelism with the rotor’s contact surface. Wit hin a tolerance of 0.01 mm, the perpendicularity between the end face and the inner bore (for the distribution plate) is also kept within 0.01 mm, while the flatness of the end fac e remains at 0.05 mm. When polishing, it’s best to avoid using metallographic sandpaper—instead, opt for chromium oxide polishing. If the distribution plate’s end face has only min or scratches, start by lightly grinding with fine oilstone, followed by finishing with chromium oxide polishing. 3) Rotor Maintenance and Repair The worn areas of the rotor are the  end faces and the blade grooves. When wear on the rotor end faces is minor, you can smooth out the roughened areas using an oilstone or repair them through grinding. If the wear i s severe, you can use a mandrel to precisely position the rotor on an external cylindrical grinder for reconditioning. After repair, it’s essential to ensure that the two end faces  remain parallel to each other. Not greater than 0.008 mm, surface roughness Ra ≤ 0.16 µm, and perpendicularity between the end face and the hole no more than 0.01 mm. Rotor end-fa ce machining After grinding, the blade width should be matched to the rotor by further grinding, ensuring that the blade width is 0.005 mm smaller than the rotor width. The blade s lots experience frequent sliding, leading to more severe wear—but the degree of wear varies significantly across individual slots. To ensure consistent clearance between each blade  and its corresponding slot, the blade slots must be precisely reworked using a specialized grinding machine, followed by individual blade matching to maintain a clearance within t he range of 0.013 to 0.018 mm. 4) Blade Maintenance

The worn areas of the blade include the top section where the blade contacts the inner surface of the stator, the two side surfa ces where the blade meets the distribution plate, and the blade itself— The surface of the rotor blade groove that experiences the most severe wear is the top area where the blade contacts the inner surface of the stator. 3.2.3 Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Cylinders

Structure and Working Principle of Hydraulic Cylinders As shown in Figure 3.7, this is a structural diagram of a double-acting single-rod hydraulic cylinder. This cylinder is commonly used in construction machinery, and its main components include the cylinder base 2, piston 8, cylinder barrel 11, piston rod 12, guide sleeve 13, and end cap 15. A notable feature of this cylinder's design is... The piston and piston rod are connected using retaining rings, making disassembly and assembly convenient; the support ring 9 on the piston is made from wear-resistant materials such as PTFE, ensuring low friction as well; the guide sleeve prevents the piston rod from tilting during axial movement, thereby protecting the seals. Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems

99 Both ends are equipped with slit-type cushioning devices, which help reduce impact and noise when the piston reaches the end of its stroke. The operating pressure for this type of cylinder is 12–15 MPa. 1—Screw; 2—Cylinder Base; 3—Spring Retaining Ring; 4—Stop Ring; 5—Retaining Clip (consisting of 2 semicircles); 6—Seal Ring; 7—Retaining Collar; 8—Piston; 9—Support Ring; 10—Seal Between Piston and Piston Rod; 11—Cylinder Barrel. 12—Piston rod; 13—Guide sleeve; 14—Sealing ring between the guide sleeve and cylinder barrel; 15—End cap Figure 3.7: Structural Diagram of a Double-Acting Single-Rod Hydraulic Cylinder 2. Hydraulic Cylinder Disassembly, Assembly, and Precautions

Hydraulic Cylinder Disassembly and Assembly (1) Use a wrench to loosen the lock nut on the ear pivot, then pull the piston rod out of the ear pivot. (2) Use a wrench to loosen and remove the cylinder head. (3) The piston rod, along with the piston and guide sleeve, is withdrawn together. (4) Use an external cylindrical spring caliper to remove the spring clip from the piston rod, then take off the retaining ring and keyway before carefully extracting the piston. (5) Check if the sealing ring is still usable; replace it promptly if it’s no longer functional. (6) After all removed parts have been cleaned with kerosene, replace the damaged and wear-prone components (such as sealing rings), then reassemble them in the reverse order of disassembly. 2) Precautions for Disassembling and Assembling Hydraulic Cylinders The following points should be noted when removing the hydraulic cylinder from the equipment: (1) Before disassembling the hydraulic cylinder, the hydraulic circuit must be depressurized; otherwise, when loosening the fittings connected to the cylinder, the High-pressure oil in the pipeline will quickly spray out. When relieving pressure from the hydraulic circuit, first loosen the handwheel or adjusting screw at the relief valve to allow the pressurized oil to drain, and then disconnect the power supply or energy source to stop the hydraulic system from operating. (2) During disassembly, care should be taken to prevent damage to the piston rod’s end threads, oil port threads, piston rod surface, and cylinder liner inner wall, among other components. To avoid bending or deformation of slender parts like the piston rod, ensure they are evenly supported using wooden blocks when placing them. The following points should be noted when dismantling hydraulic cylinders: (1) The disassembly of hydraulic cylinders must be carried out in a clean, dust-free environment to prevent contamination by surrounding dust, debris, and other contaminants. After disassembly, all parts should be protected against dust (e.g., covered with plastic sheeting; cotton cloths or any other industrial fabrics are strictly prohibited). (2) Drain the oil from both chambers of the cylinder before disassembly. (3) Disassembly must be carried out in a specific sequence. Since different hydraulic cylinder designs vary, the disassembly order may also differ slightly. Generally, you should first remove the cylinder cap and finish with the piston and piston rod. When removing the cylinder cap, use specialized tools for internal key-type connections (such as retaining keys or spring clips)—never use a flat chisel. For flange-type end caps, always use screws to gently push them out; hammering or prying forcefully is strictly prohibited. If the piston and piston rod cannot be easily removed, do not attempt to force them out—first identify the underlying issue before proceeding with disassembly. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Repair Case Study Tutorial

100 (4) After disassembly, carefully inspect to determine which parts can be reused and which require repair. 3. Common Hydraulic Cylinder Faults and Troubleshooting To address issues where the hydraulic cylinder fails to operate properly, follow the sequence below. (1) Clearly identify the nature of faults occurring when the hydraulic cylinder starts up. For example, issues such as incorrect movement speed, improper output force, lack of motion, unstable movement, incorrect motion direction, wrong action sequence, or creeping. Regardless of which specific fault arises, it can ultimately be traced back to fundamental problems—such as flow rate, pressure, directional control, positioning, or load conditions. (2) List the components that could potentially affect the occurrence of the failure. For instance, if the cylinder speed is too slow, it may be due to insufficient flow. In this case, you should first identify the components affecting the flow to the cylinder, then analyze whether the issue stems from a blocked or restricted flow valve, internal leakage in the cylinder itself, excessive leakage from the pressure control valve, or other factors. Conduct targeted inspection and testing, and proceed with repairing or replacing any unsuitable components as needed. (3) If all components are functioning properly and the hydraulic parameters in each oil section are also generally normal, further inspection should focus on factors specific to the hydraulic cylinder itself. The main parts of the hydraulic cylinder can be repaired as follows. (1) Cylinder Barrel  Repair. Common damages to cylinder barrels include internal surface scratches and wear. There are several methods available for repairing cylinder barrel damage, such as high-power  honing technology, surface bonding techniques, electro-brushing plating, arc spraying (for large-diameter hydraulic cylinders), arc welding buildup techniques (also suitable for l arge-diameter hydraulic cylinders), brazing (using soft metallic materials), and bushing methods. Note that no single repair method is universally effective—instead, the most appro priate technique should be selected based on the specific circumstances. The following sections will introduce high-power honing and surface bonding technologies in detail. ① High-Performance Honing Technology. This repair method is ideal for cylinder bores that exhibit minor deformation and shallow scoring, capable of restoring cylinders with dimensional to lerances up to 2.5 times larger than the original specifications. A high-power honing machine is used to grind areas where dimensional or shape tolerances have been exceeded, ensur ing precise restoration. The cylinder barrel meets the requirements for overall dimensions, shape tolerances, and surface roughness. ② Surface Coating Technology. When the inner su rface of the cylinder bore is heavily worn and exhibits deep scoring, surface coating technology can be employed. This method is quick, effective, and remarkably cost-efficient. To  repair the damage, first clean the inner surface of the cylinder with acetone solution, then allow it to dry completely. Next, apply a layer of repair compound (such as Loctite 60 2 or TG205 adhesive) onto the scored areas. Use a specially designed tool to smooth out the compound evenly, ensuring the adhesive fully bonds with the cylinder surface. After the  cylinder walls have been bonded together, apply a layer of repair compound (keeping the thickness about 2 mm higher than the cylinder barrel). Then, firmly scrape the compound back  and forth to smooth it out evenly, ensuring it slightly protrudes above the inner surface of the cylinder. Aim for an even, polished finish as much as possible. Once cured, lightl y sand the inner surface with fine-grit sandpaper to achieve a consistent cylinder bore diameter. (2) Piston rod maintenance. To prevent rust and enhance wear resistance, piston ro ds typically undergo hard chrome plating on their surfaces. Common forms of damage include wear, scratches, coating peeling, and bending. As piston rods are precision-machined comp onents, it’s best to avoid repairing them using buildup welding, since this process can cause deformation and may even damage other intact working surfaces. For example, consider t he  "Case Studies in Mechanical and Electrical System Fault Diagnosis and Repair " tutorial. 104 If the piston rod is bent, simply straighten it to meet the required specifications. If the piston rod shows signs of wear, scoring, or chrome coating peeling off, you can remove the existing coating, re-apply chrome plating, and then proceed with surface finishing. For localized damage such as scoring, electrobrush plating technology can also be used for effective repair. 3.2.4 Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Motors

Structure and Working Principle of Hydraulic Motors As shown in Figure 3.8, the typical structure of a double-acting vane motor features the following key characteristics: The vanes are positioned radially, with symmetrical chamfers on both sides of their tips to accommodate both forward and reverse rotation requirements. At the base of each vane, a dovetail spring is installed, ensuring that the vane tip maintains constant, close contact with the inner surface of the stator—this prevents the high- and low-pressure chambers from communicating during motor startup (before centrifugal force has fully developed). Additionally, the motor housing contains a shuttle valve (consisting of two series-connected check valves), which ensures that, whenever the oil flow direction at the motor’s inlet and outlet ports changes due to switching between forward and reverse rotation, the base of each vane remains continuously supplied with high-pressure oil, thereby maintaining optimal contact between the vanes and the stator’s inner surface. 1—Casing; 2—Rotor; 3—Stator; 4—Distribution Plate; 5—Drive Shaft; 6—Front Cover; 7—Yan-style spring; 8—Leaf spring; 9—Check valve

Figure 3.8: Typical Structure of a Double-Acting Vane Motor The vane motor boasts advantages such as a compact structure, small size, low inertia, minimal noise, reduced pulsation, long service life, and excellent low-speed performance. However, due to its relatively low output torque and limited resistance to contamination, it is primarily used in hydraulic systems of stationary machinery that require high speed but low torque—such as rotary tables in rubber and plastic processing equipment, light industrial machinery, and metal-cutting machine tools. It’s also commonly found in clamping and conveying mechanisms of automated production lines and machine tools, as well as in various hydraulic servo systems where low inertia is critical. That said, vane motors are not suitable for use in mobile machinery operating under harsh environmental conditions. 2. Common Faults and Maintenance of Hydraulic Motors

Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Check Valves Ordinary check valve (1) The structure and operating principle of a conventional check valve. The tubular straight-through check valve, as shown in Figure 3.9, allows hydraulic flu id to flow in only one direction, preventing reverse flow. The check valve consists of basic components such as a valve element (either a conical or ball valve), a valve body, and  a spring. When hydraulic oil acts against the compression spring, When fluid enters, oil pressure lifts the valve core, allowing oil to flow freely. Conversely, when hydraulic oil  flows in from the opposite end, the oil pressure and spring force push the valve core tightly against the valve seat, preventing any fluid passage. All check valves feature a taper ed valve design, which effectively ensures excellent reverse-sealing performance. The typical opening pressure for a check valve ranges from 0.035 to 0.05 MPa. Additionally, check  valves can also function as backpressure valves—simply by replacing the standard soft spring with a suitable harder one, the valve transforms into a pressure control device. When u sed as a backpressure valve, it is commonly installed in the return line of a hydraulic system to generate a backpressure of 0.2 to 0.6 MPa. 1—Valve body; 2—Spool; 3—Spring; 4, 5—R etaining rings

Figure 3.9: Tubular Straight-Through Check Valve (2) Disassembly and assembly of the check valve. Disassembling and reassembling the check valve is relatively simple : just unscrew the bolts and remove the valve core along with the spring. When reinstalling, make sure the clearance between the valve core and the valve body falls within the rang e of 0.008 to 0.015 mm. If the valve core is already rusted, worn, or clogged with debris, it will need to be replaced. Clean and polish the outer cylindrical surface of the valve  core using metallographic sandpaper. Additionally, verify that the sealing elements are functioning reliably and that the spring force is appropriately adjusted. In hydraulic syste ms, check valves are widely used—commonly installed at the ports of hydraulic pumps to prevent hydraulic oil from flowing backward. They’re also employed to isolate individual oil  circuits, ensuring that one circuit doesn’t interfere with another. Additionally, they can serve as backpressure valves or bypass valves. When selecting a check valve, in addition  to choosing the appropriate opening pressure based on your needs, you should also pay special attention to ensuring that the flow rate passing through the check valve during operat ion matches the rated flow. This is crucial because if the actual flow rate through the check valve is significantly lower than the rated flow, it can lead to malfunctions in the h ydraulic system—refer to Chapter 3 for fault diagnosis and repair procedures. 107 Sometimes vibrations occur—specifically, the lower the flow rate, the higher the opening pressure  tends to be. Additionally, the more air present in the fluid, the more likely vibrations become. During installation, ensure you clearly identify the correct inlet and outlet direc tions; improper installation could disrupt the system's normal operation. This is especially critical when installing a check valve at the pump’s outlet—reversing the valve’s inlet  and outlet connections might lead to damage of the hydraulic pump or even cause the motor to overheat and fail. 2) Hydraulically Operated Check Valve The structure and operating principle of the hydraulically controlled check valve are shown in Figure 3.10. 1—Control piston; 2—Valve body; 3—Spool; 4—Relief spool; 5—Spring seat; 6—Spring Figure 3.10: Structure and Operating Principle of the Hydraulically Controlled Check Valve Hydraulic-controlled check valves come in two types: a relief type with a relief spool, and a simple type without one. Figure 3.10(a) shows the simple-type hydraulic… A one-way control valve works by directly pushing the valve spool upward as the control piston moves. This mechanism causes a sudden release of oil pressure within the high-pressure closed circuit, resulting in significant impact pressure and accompanied by loud pressure-relief noise. Figure 3.10(b) presents a case study on fault diagnosis and maintenance of unloading-type electromechanical systems. 108 The hydraulically controlled check valve works as follows: When the control piston moves upward, it first lifts the unloading spool, relieving the pressure in the main oil circuit chamber. Once this pressure is released, the main spool is pushed open, allowing fluid to flow in the reverse direction. This action reduces the control pressure while simultaneously minimizing hydraulic shock and pressure-relief noise. The applications of the hydraulically controlled check valve are as follows: Using two hydraulically controlled check valves to create a "hydraulic lock," the hydraulic cylinder is locked in place, preventing it from moving and holding it securely at any desired position; as Pressure-holding valve ensures the system maintains a specific pressure over the designated time period; as a filling valve, it uses the cylinder's negative pressure to open and draw in fluid from the oil. Absorbs oil from the tank and fills the hydraulic cylinder; acting as a support valve for the vertical hydraulic cylinder, it connects the hydraulically controlled check valve to the lower chamber of the vertical cylinder. Preventing the plunger (or piston) from descending due to system leakage also enables fluid flow in both forward and reverse directions. Here are the precautions for using a hydraulically controlled check valve: Ensure that the control pressure is sufficiently high to allow the hydraulically controlled check valve to open reliably in the reverse direction. Select the appropriate structural  design of the hydraulically controlled check valve based on its role within the system, its installation location, and the magnitude of flow resistance (backpressure) in the oil o utlet chamber when fluid flows in the reverse direction. Use either two hydraulically controlled check valves or a single bidirectional hydraulically controlled check valve to crea te a circuit that locks the hydraulic cylinder in place. During operation, the system flow rate must match the rated flow capacity of the hydraulically controlled check valve. Addi tionally, clearly identify the correct flow directions for the main ports, as well as the control and drain ports, to avoid improper installation. Solenoid directional control valve The structure and operating principle of the solenoid directional control valve are illustrated in Figure 3.11. The solenoid directional control  valve uses the thrust generated by the electromagnetic coil's attraction to move the spool, thereby controlling the flow path—opening or closing it—and changing the direction of fl uid flow. As shown in Figure 3.11(a), this is the structural diagram of a 2/3-way solenoid directional control valve. When the solenoid is de-energized, the spool is pushed by a sp ring toward the left end (its normal position), connecting port P to port A. When energized, the solenoid causes the iron core to push the valve spool toward the right end via a pu shrod, connecting port P to port B while closing port A. Disconnected. As shown in Figure 3.11(b), this is the structural diagram of a three-position, four-way solenoid directional  control valve. When both solenoids are de-energized, the spool remains in the neutral position. The ports P, A, B, and T are completely isolated from each other. When the solenoid  on the left side is energized, the pushrod moves the spool toward the right end, connecting port P to port B and port A to port T. Conversely, when the solenoid on the right side  is activated, the spool shifts to the left end, establishing a connection between port P and port A. B entrance Connected to the T-port. Due to the limitations of the electromagnet ic solenoid's rated suction force, the spool diameter of the solenoid directional control valve cannot be made too large; its nominal diameter is— Generally no more than 10 mm, sui table for applications with low flow rates. For higher flow rates, hydraulic or electro-hydraulic directional control valves should be used. Electromagnetic… Valves can be classifi ed into two types based on their power supply: AC and DC. AC solenoids offer greater holding force, better starting performance, and shorter switching times. (For 0.01–0.03 s), but  the impact force during switching is significant, and if the spool gets stuck and cannot be pulled in, the electromagnetic coil is prone to burning out. DC electromagnet Reversal  is relatively slow (typically 0.05–0.08 s), resulting in low reversal impact force and extended service life. However, this design offers weak suction force during startup, requiri ng a DC power supply. Additionally, electromagnetic directional control valves can be classified into dry-type and wet-type, depending on whether the armature working chamber conta ins hydraulic fluid. The dry type does not allow pressurized oil to flow. Into the magnetic circuit, coil, and other components; in the wet type, pressurized oil is allowed to flow  into the electromagnetic core's hollow sleeve. In the dry type, measures are taken to prevent pressurized oil from entering the electromagnet. In this system, the valve's backflow  pressure must not be too high. The wet-type design offers low noise, excellent cooling and lubrication, minimal temperature rise, and a long service life, making it widely applica ble. 1—Electromagnet; 2—Pushrod; 3—Sealing Ring; 4—Spring Seat; 5—Support Spring; 6—Valve Core; 7—Valve Body;

8—Back cover; 9—Reset spring seat; 10—Spring; 11—Stopper Figure 3.11: Structure and Operating Principle of the Solenoid Directional Control Valve – A Case Study Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Mechatronic Systems 110 The disassembly and assembly steps for the solenoid directional control valve are as follows. (1) First, disconnect the machine tool's power supply and remove the electrical components (terminals) from the solenoid directional control valve. (2) Use a Phillips screwdriver to remove the solenoid directional control valve, and then detach the side baffles. (3) After removing the springs from both ends, take out the spool of the solenoid directional control valve. 2) Electro-hydraulic directional control valve The structure and appearance of the electro-hydraulic directional control valve are shown in Figure 3.12. 1. 7—Check valve; 2. 6—Throttle valve; 3. 5—Solenoid; 4—Pilot valve spool; 8—Main valve spool Figure 3.12: Structure and Appearance of the Electro-Hydraulic Directional Control Valve The electro-hydraulic directional control valve is composed of a solenoid-operated directional valve and a hydraulically actuated directional valve combined together. The solenoid valve is responsible for switching the flow direction in the control oil circuits connected to both ends of the hydraulically actuated valve, thereby changing the working position of the valve spool—this component is referred to as the pilot valve. Meanwhile, the hydraulically actuated directional valve controls the reversing of the actuator elements within the system and is thus called the main valve. This operating mechanism allows a small electromagnetic force to manage the high-flow switching of the main oil circuit, making it ideal for hydraulic systems requiring large flow rates. As shown in Figure 3.12(a), the structure of the electro-hydraulic directional valve features a three-position, four-way Y-type solenoid valve at the top as the pilot valve, while the main valve below is a three-position, four-way O-type hydraulically actuated directional valve. The centering method for the spool of the three-position, four-way electro-hydraulic directional valve can be either spring-centered or hydraulically centered. When using spring-centering, the pilot valve should be a Y-type, three-position, four-way solenoid directional valve to ensure that, when the main spool is in the neutral position, the control oil chambers on both sides remain continuously connected to the reservoir, maintaining zero pressure. This setup allows the main spool to stay perfectly centered solely under the influence of the spring force. On the other hand, if hydraulic centering is employed, the pilot valve must be a P-type, three-position, four-way solenoid directional valve to guarantee that, in the neutral position, both control oil chambers of the main spool are always pressurized. Additionally, the electro-hydraulic directional valve offers two options for controlling the oil supply to its control circuit: internal oil supply and external oil supply. In the case of internal oil supply, the control circuit draws pressure oil directly from the main oil line via port P—this is known as internal control. For external oil supply, an independent oil source is typically required, which is referred to as external control. Similarly, the return path for the control circuit can also follow either an internal return (internal leakage) or an external return (external leakage), as illustrated in Figure 3.12(b).

The disassembly and assembly steps for the electro-hydraulic directional control valve are as follows. (1) Use an Allen wrench to separate the valve body on both sides, remove the springs and spring washers from each side, loosen the screws to take out the small springs and ball bearings on both sides, and finally extract the small flow control valves from each side. (2) Remove the main spool, then use an Allen wrench to loosen the solenoid directional control valve, separating it from the hydraulic directional control valve. (3) Clean all disassembled parts with kerosene, replace any damaged or worn components (such as sealing rings), and then reassemble in the reverse order. When assembling the directional control valve, in addition to checking whether the sealing elements are reliable and ensuring the spring force is appropriate, pay special attention to Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems. 111 Check the clearance fit. Improper clearance fit is a major cause of mechanical failure in directional control valves. When the spool diameter is less than 20 mm, the clearance should be between 0.008 and 0.015 mm; for spools larger than 20 mm, the clearance should range from 0.015 to 0.025 mm. For solenoid-operated directional control valves, also ensure to inspect the proper functioning of the solenoid. Additionally, for hydraulically controlled valves, pay close attention to the connections and flow paths of the control oil circuit to prevent electrical or hydraulic system failures during operation. Here are the precautions for using a directional control valve:

(1) Control method. The control method should align with the system's requirements, while also taking into account ease of operation and the system's self-… Automation level. (2) T he pressure and flow rate of the directional control valve must meet the following requirements. ① The system's working pressure and flow rate should be kept below the valve's rate d pressure and rated flow rate; otherwise, abnormal operation may occur. ② When the system flow exceeds the rated flow of the solenoid directional control valve, an electro-hydraul ic directional control valve and a hydraulically operated directional control valve should be selected. ③ Spool function. Different spool functions can meet the varying requirement s of the system. Although some spool functions may be identical, their transition characteristics differ, which can also affect the operation of the actuating elements. Therefore,  proper selection is essential. ④ Directional accuracy and smoothness. When both ports A and B of the working chamber are blocked, reversing can easily cause impact; however, direct ional precision… High precision; conversely, when both port A and port B are connected to port T, the actuator is less likely to brake during the directional change, resulting in l ower switching accuracy but minimal hydraulic shock. ⑤ Starting smoothness. Different center functions exhibit varying start-up performance; when the valve is in the neutral positi on, if one chamber of the hydraulic cylinder is connected to the oil tank… When connected, the startup becomes less smooth because there’s no fluid to provide cushioning. ⑥ Connect ion method: The most widely used connection method for hydraulic valves is plate mounting. Structure and Working Principle of a Direct-Acting Relief Valve A direct-acting relief valve is a type of relief valve that controls the opening and closing of the spool by directly balancing the oil pressure from the main oil circuit acting on the spool against the spring force also acting on it. Direct-acting relief valves come in three basic spool designs: slide valve, conical valve, and ball valve. Figure 3.13(a) shows the structural diagram of a direct-acting relief valve with a slide valve spool configuration. The valve primarily consists of a screw plug 1, a spool 2, and a valve body. Upper cover, 4. Locking nut, 5. Pressure-adjusting spring, 6. Adjustment nut, 7. Adjustment rod, and more components make up the assembly. The overflow valve can be configured with either internal or external oil drainage. As shown in Figure 3.13(a), when port L is blocked, the oil at the upper end of the spool flows through port E directly to port T—this is known as internal drainage. In internal drainage, the back pressure at the return port T acts directly on the upper surface of the spool, while the spring balances the pressure difference between the inlet and outlet. On the other hand, if port E is blocked and port L is opened instead, allowing the oil to flow directly back to the reservoir via a dedicated oil line, this configuration is referred to as external drainage. 1—Screw plug; 2—Valve core; 3—Valve body; 4—Upper cover; 5—Lock nut;

6—Pressure regulating spring; 7—Adjustment nut; 8—Adjustment rod Figure 3.13: Structural and Appearance Diagram of a Direct-Acting Relief Valve Main Applications of the Relief Valve (1) Pressure regulation and stabilization. For example, in a hydraulic power unit equipped with a fixed-displacement pump, this is used to adjust the pump's outlet pressure and maintain it at a constant level. (2) Pressure limiting. When used as a safety valve, the relief valve remains closed during normal system operation and only opens to relieve excess pressure when the system pressure exceeds its set pressure, thereby providing overload protection for the system. Characteristics of the relief valve: The valve is connected in parallel with the load, the overflow port is routed back to the oil tank, and it uses imported pressure negative feedback. 3. Disassembly and Assembly of the Relief Valve

1) Valve body disassembly (1) Clamp the valve body in a vise with the threaded plug facing upward (note: ensure the vise jaws do not damage the mating surfaces). (2) Use a wrench to remove and install the threaded plug (be careful not to let the spring pop out), then take out the main valve core and the spring. 2) Assembly of the relief valve (1) Carefully clean all removed parts with kerosene, replace any damaged or worn components (such as sealing rings), and then reassemble in the reverse order of disassembly. System Fault Diagnosis and Repair Case Studies Tutorial

Assembly sequence. (2) The main spool should move freely within the valve body without any sticking or obstruction, and its clearance typically ranges between 0.015 and 0.025 mm. (3) The main spool, pilot spool, and their respective valve bodies should have a reliable seal. (4) A pressure adjustment test should be conducted after assembly. When assembling the relief valve, pay special attention to ensuring that the spool moves smoothly. After disassembly, use metallographic sandpaper to carefully polish the outer cylindrical surface of the spool, removing rust, burrs, and other imperfections. Also, thoroughly clean the damping holes in the slide valve to prevent clogging. Make sure the slide valve can move freely, and verify that the spring is neither too soft nor too stiff—cracks or bends are strictly prohibited. Finally, install a screw plug at the pilot-controlled port, tightening it securely to prevent leaks, and ensure that sealing gaskets and paper washers at all joints are properly positioned. Lastly, double-check that all connecting screws are tightly fastened. 4. Precautions for Using Relief Valves (1) The type of relief valve should be selected based on the system's operating conditions and requirements. Generally, direct-acting relief valves respond more quickly and are ide ally suited for use as safety valves, while pilot-operated relief valves offer superior opening and closing characteristics, making them ideal for applications requiring pressure r egulation or constant-pressure control. Whenever possible, choose relief valves with excellent opening and closing performance to enhance both the speed-load characteristics of the  actuating elements and the overall efficiency of the circuit. (2) The specifications of the relief valve should be selected appropriately based on the system's pressure and flow r ate. For relief valves used as remote pressure regulators, their through-flow typically ranges from 0.5% to 1% of the flow rate passing through the main relief valve (the primary v alve) connected to the remote control port. (3) The set pressure of the relief valve should be determined and adjusted based on its intended use and function within the system. Whe n used as a safety valve, its set pressure must not exceed the system's maximum operating pressure. (4) When adjusting the voltage, ensure you rotate the adjustment mechanism in th e correct direction. After completing the adjustment, securely tighten the lock nut. (5) If it is necessary to remotely adjust system pressure, relieve the load, or implement multi -stage pressure control via the remote port of the pilot-operated relief valve. If necessary, unscrew the screw plug on the remote control port and connect it to the control oil ci rcuit; otherwise, seal the remote control port tightly. (6) If it is necessary to change the pressure adjustment range of the relief valve, this can be achieved by modifying the st iffness of the adjusting spring. However, it should also be noted that altering the spring stiffness may affect the valve's opening and closing characteristics. (7) When the relief  valve is used as an unloading valve, its return port should be connected directly to the oil tank to minimize back pressure. (8) The voltage, current, and wiring configuration of  the solenoid relief valve must be correct. (9) The valve installation and connection must be correct, the interface seals must be tight, and the external oil drain port must be dir ectly connected to the oil tank. 5. Structure and Working Principle of a Direct-Acting Pressure Reducing Valve As shown in Figure 3.14, the inlet pressure ( P_1 ) is reduced to ( P_2 ). When the spool is in its original position, the inlet and outlet remain fully open, keeping the valve in its normally open state. The control pressure for this valve is derived directly from the outlet. When the outlet pressure ( P_2 ) rises to the setpoint value, the spool reaches its critical point of upward movement. If ( P_2 ) continues to increase beyond this point, the spool moves further upward, partially closing the valve port. This action increases the fluid resistance, leading to a greater pressure drop across the valve and, consequently, a reduction in the outlet pressure. Conversely, if the outlet pressure ( P_2 ) decreases, the spool moves downward, reopening the valve port and reducing the fluid resistance. As a result, the pressure drop across the valve diminishes, allowing the outlet pressure to recover. In this process, if friction forces, the weight of the spool, and steady-state hydrodynamic forces are neglected, the spool is balanced solely by the downward hydrodynamic force (equal to the outlet pressure) acting on its lower surface and the upward spring force (approximately equal to the setpoint pressure). This balance ensures that the outlet pressure remains stable under normal operating conditions. Originally, the set pressure remained unchanged. The pressure relief valve is primarily used to reduce and stabilize the oil pressure in a specific branch of the system, commonly employed in troubleshooting and maintenance case studies for electromechanical systems such as clamping, control, and lubrication applications. 116 In the oil circuit. Characteristics of the pressure relief valve: The valve is connected in series with the load, and the adjustment spring chamber features an external oil drain. The system uses negative feedback based on outlet pressure.

2. Disassembly and Assembly of the Pressure Reducing Valve (Sequence Valve) (1) The slide valve should move smoothly, preventing any sticking or jamming. (2) The damping holes should be kept clear and unobstructed. (3) The spring should be of appropriate firmness—neither broken nor bent. (4) The valve body and spool must be thoroughly cleaned, and the leakage passages must remain unobstructed. (5) Seals must show no signs of aging or damage to ensure proper sealing performance; tighten all components securely. The screw at the joint.

Selection and Usage Precautions for Pressure Relief Valves (1) The type of pressure-reducing valve should be selected based on the system's operating conditions and requirements, and note The trend in the opening and closing characteristics of a pressure-reducing valve is opposite to that of a relief valve (as the flow rate through the pressure-reducing valve changes). (When increased, the outlet pressure decreases slightly.) Additionally, note that the relief valve has a higher oil leakage compared to other valves—oil continuously flows out from the pilot valve (sometimes as much as 1 L/min or more), which can affect the selection of the hydraulic pump capacity. (2) The specifications of the pressure-reducing valve should be selected appropriately based on the system's pressure and flow rate. (3) The outlet pressure should be determined and adjusted based on the deceleration valve's intended use and function within the system. It is crucial to consider the relationship between the deceleration valve's set pressure and the load pressure of the actuating element. (4) When adjusting the voltage regulator, ensure you rotate it in the correct direction. After adjustment is complete, securely tighten the lock nut. (5) If multi-stage pressure reduction control of the system is required via the remote port of the pilot-operated relief valve, the screw plug on the remote port should be removed and connected to the control oil circuit; otherwise, the remote port will remain tightly sealed. (6) The valve installation and connections must be correct, with tight sealing at all interfaces. Additionally, the relief port of the pressure-reducing valve must be routed directly back to the oil tank. 4. 3.2.8 Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Sequence Valves

Structure and Working Principle of a Direct-Acting Sequence Valve As shown in Figure 3.15, this is a schematic diagram illustrating the working principle of a direct-acting sequenc e valve. The primary oil pressure P1 is introduced into the lower chamber of the small piston 6 through channels in the valve body 4 and the lower end cap 7. During operation, the  pressurized fluid delivered by the pump first overcomes the load on cylinder I, initiating its movement. As the load on cylinder I increases, so does P1. When P1 rises to a point w here the hydraulic force acting on the bottom of the small spool exceeds the spring force, the valve spool moves upward, fully opening the valve port. This connects P1 (which corre sponds to cylinder I) with P2 (which corresponds to cylinder II), thereby driving cylinder II to move. The control cylinders I and II operate sequentially. The illustrated state re presents the internally controlled configuration; however, if you rotate the lower end cap by 90°, remove the screw plug K, and connect it to an external oil source, the system swi tches to externally controlled mode. In this case, the drain port L must be routed directly back to the oil tank separately. In externally controlled valves, whether the valve port  opens or remains closed is independent of the primary pressure P1—it depends solely on the magnitude of the external control pressure. 1—Adjustment screw; 2—Pressure adjustment spring; 3—Upper end cap; 4—Valve body; 5—Spool; 6—Small piston; 7—Lower end cap

Figure 3.15: Schematic Diagram of the Operation Principle  of a Direct-Acting Sequence Valve As shown in Figure 3.16, this is the structural and external view of a direct-acting sequence valve. Since it uses control oil pressure to overco me the spool spring force, directly pushing the spool to move and thereby increasing the spring stiffness—and consequently widening the adjustment deviation—it is suitable only for  applications where the pressure is below 8 MPa. The small piston positioned at the lower end of the main spool in the figure serves precisely to reduce the spring stiffness. Never theless, 118
The spring stiffness is still relatively high.

Figure 3.16: Structural and Appearance Diagram of a Direct-Acting Sequence Valve A sequence valve uses hydraulic pressur e as a control signal to open or close oil circuits. Sequence valves are available in both direct-acting and pilot-operated types; depending on the source of the control pressure,  they can also be classified as internally controlled or externally controlled. By adjusting the control method, the relief mechanism, and the connection configuration of the second ary oil circuit, sequence valves can also function as backpressure valves, unloading valves, and balance valves, among other applications. Precautions for Using Sequence Valves (1) The control method of the sequence valve—whether internal or external—should be selected based on the system's operating characteristics and requirements. (2) The selected sequence valve should not have an opening pressure that is too low, as this could lead to unintended actuator movements due to leakage. (3) The oil-bleed method for sequence valves is typically external, so the bleed port must be connected directly back to the reservoir. Additionally, ensure that the bleed circuit does not experience excessive backpressure, as this could interfere with the proper operation of the sequence valve. (4) A sequence valve with excessively poor opening and closing characteristics can lead to excessively high primary pressure when the flow rate is too high, thereby reducing system efficiency. (5) The flow rate through the sequence valve should not significantly exceed the rated flow rate, as this could lead to vibration or other unstable phenomena.
