3.2.9 Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Pressure Relays

Structure and Working Principle of Pressure Relays As shown in Figure 3.17, a pressure relay is a hydraulic-electrical conversion component that uses fluid pressure to open or close electrical contacts. It generates an electrical signal when the oil pressure reaches the set pressure level, triggering the operation of electrical components and enabling automatic control of the hydraulic system—or serving as a safety protection mechanism. The pressure relay consists of two main parts: a pressure-to-displacement conversion element and a microswitch. Based on their structure and operating principles, pressure relays can be classified into four types: plunger-type, spring-tube type, diaphragm-type, and bellows-type, with the plunger-type being the most widely used. Figure 3.17 illustrates the structure and appearance of a plunger-type pressure relay. When the oil pressure reaches the specified level, When the relay's set pressure is reached, the oil pressure acting on plunger 1 pushes rod 2, closing microswitch 4 and triggering a signal. Electrical signal. In the diagram, L represents the oil drain port; by adjusting the spring's preload, you can set the pressure relay's actuation pressure. 1—Plunger; 2—Pushrod; 3—Adjustment Screw; 4—Microswitch Figure 3.17: Structural and Appearance Diagram of the Plunger-Type Pressure Relay

Features such as locking, etc. 2. Precautions for Using Pressure Relays (1) Select a pressure relay with an appropriate structural design based on the specific application and system pressure. To ensure sensitive operation of the pressure relay, avoid using a high-pressure relay in low-pressure systems. (2) To compensate for the pressure pulsations of the hydraulic pump, it is recommended to use a miniature flexible hose (inner diameter 2 mm, length at least 1 m) for the connection tubing of the pressure switch. (3) Wire the microswitch in the pressure relay according to the required power supply type and specific instructions. (4) After pressure adjustment is complete, the setting should be locked or secured to prevent changes in the set pressure due to vibration. 3. Common Faults and Maintenance of Pressure Relays

3.2.10 Fault Diagnosis and Repair of the One-Way Throttle Valve

1. Structure and Working Principle of a Check Flow Control Valve As shown in Figure 3.18, this is a structural and appearance diagram of a unidirectional throttle valve. In the figure, the valve spool is divided into an upper spool and a lower spool. Oil flows in from P1, passes through the valve port, and exits at P2—this represents forward flow, with the throttling principle identical to that of a conventional throttle valve. Meanwhile, oil flows from P2 When entering and flowing out from P1 in the reverse direction, the pressurized oil pushes the lower spool downward, causing it to act as a one-way valve and allowing fluid to flow freely in the reverse direction. Application scenarios: Since the throttle valve lacks pressure and temperature compensation devices, it cannot counteract speed fluctuations in the actuator caused by changes in load or oil viscosity. Therefore, it is typically suitable only for hydraulic systems with relatively stable loads and where high speed stability is not critical. Additionally, the throttle valve can also be used for cushioning actuator movements or limiting flow rates in multi-cylinder circuits designed to prevent interference among cylinders. Steps for Disassembling and Assembling the Throttle Valve (1) Use an Allen wrench to unscrew and remove the bottom cover, then take out the spring and valve core—make sure none of the seals are lost. (2) Use an Allen wrench to unscrew and  remove the top cover. (3) Reassemble the valve in the reverse order of disassembly. Make sure to thoroughly clean the throttling ports on the valve body. When pushing the valve sp ool upward by hand, it should move smoothly without any resistance or obstruction. When assembling the flow control valve, in addition to ensuring proper clearance between the valv e body and spool, selecting the right spring stiffness, verifying reliable sealing, and checking that connections are securely tightened, special attention must be paid to cleaning  the valve body and spool. The throttling port of the needle valve must remain free of contaminants to prevent blockage. 3. Precautions for Using the Throttle Valve

(1) For some pr oducts, the inlet and outlet of the standard throttling valve can be connected interchangeably, while others do not allow this. When installing and using, ensure proper connection  to the system according to the product manual's instructions. (2) The throttling valve should not operate at a very small opening, as this could lead to clogging and cause the actu ator to creep. (3) When installing the travel throttle valve and the check throttle valve, secure them with screws to the machined base surface along the travel stopper path. Above , the installation direction can be determined as needed; however, the angle of the stopper should be fabricated according to the product manual and must not be too steep. (4) The  throttling opening should be adjusted according to the speed of the actuator, and once adjusted, it must be locked in place. 4. External leakage primarily occurs at the adjustment handle area, process screw plugs, and valve mounting surfaces. External leakage, internal leakage The primary cause of internal leakage is the excessive clearance between the throttle valve spool and the valve body bore. Large-scale, severe wear during operation, along with grooves caused by the valve core rubbing against the valve body bore. Additionally,

There's also excessive oil temperature, among other issues. Ensure the tolerance between the valve core and valve bore to guarantee the flow control valve. The clearance between the valve core and the valve body bore—if there is severe wear. If the valve core and valve body bore are damaged with grooves, electricity can be used. Brush plating or re-machining the valve core for grinding 3.2.11 Fault Diagnosis and Repair of the Speed Control Valve

Structure and Working Principle of the Speed Control Valve As shown in Figure 3.19, this is a diagram illustrating the structure and appearance of the flow control valve. The inlet pressure P1 is reduced to Pm by the pressure-reducing valve, after which Pm splits into three paths: the first path flows through hole f into chamber d, the second path flows through hole e into chamber c, and the third path passes through the orifice of the throttle valve to generate… The pressure drop is reduced to P2. Pressure oil (P2) flows into the hydraulic cylinder from the outlet on one side, while on the other side it enters cavity b via port a. Adjust… The speed control valve maintains a constant pressure difference across its throttling port thanks to the automatic compensation provided by the reducing valve. If the inlet pressure P1 of the speed control valve has already been set and held constant by the relief valve, then when changes in the load cause the outlet pressure P2 to rise, the reducing valve responds by adjusting itself— As the pressure in chamber B increases, the spool moves downward, increasing the opening h of the relief valve port, which reduces the pressure drop and, in turn, causes Pm to rise—thereby ensuring… P = Pm - P2 remains constant; when the load change causes P2 to decrease, the fluid pressure in cavity b drops, prompting the spool of the relief valve to move upward and increasing the valve opening height h. Reducing the pressure drop increases Pm while still ensuring that P remains constant. As shown in Figure 3.19, this illustrates the structure where pressure reduction occurs before throttling. Speed control valves can also be designed with throttling preceding pressure reduction—both configurations operate on essentially the same principle. Some speed control valves are internally equipped with a check valve: when fluid flows in the forward direction, the valve functions as a speed regulator; however, in the reverse flow direction, it does not provide speed control, allowing fluid to pass freely. These are referred to as unidirectional speed control valves. The application of a flow control valve is similar to that of a throttle valve, primarily used in throttle-speed control circuits, but it can also be employed in volumetric-throttle-speed control circuits. Selection and Usage Notes for Speed Control Valves (1) When installing the flow control valve, the inlet and outlet must not be connected in reverse; otherwise, the pressure compensation device will fail to function. (2) When selecting a flow control valve, ensure that its minimum stable flow rate is lower than the minimum flow required by the actuator. (3) When the system requires exceptionally high speed stability of its actuators, or when used for micro-feed applications, a temperature-compensated variable-speed valve should be selected. (4) To ensure the proper operation of the flow control valve, the working pressure differential across the valve should exceed the valve’s minimum pressure differential, Pmin. Typically, the Pmin for high-pressure valves is 1 MPa, while the minimum pressure differential for low-pressure valves is 0.5 MPa. Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems 123

Figure 3.19: Structure and Appearance Diagram of the Flow Control Valve (5) Lock securely after completing the flow adjustment. (6) When operating near the minimum stable flow rate, it is recommended to install a pipeline filter on the inlet side of the flow control valve to prevent clogging and ensure stable flow performance. 3.3 Case Study: Troubleshooting the Stoppage of a CNC Lathe Tailst ock Sleeve A certain two-coordinate continuous-control horizontal CNC lathe, featuring chuck clamping and releasing, as well as high- and low-pressure switching for the chuck clamp ing force, The loosening and clamping of the turret, the forward and reverse rotation of the turret tool holder, and the extension and retraction of the tailstock sleeve are all driven by the hydraulic system. This hydraulic system is powered by a variable vane pump, and the operation of each solenoid in the corresponding electromagnetic valves is controlled by the PLC integrated into the CNC system. The hydraulic system principle of the CNC lathe is illustrated in Figure 3.20. 1—Fuel tank; 2—Filter; 3—Hydraulic pump; 4—Check valve; 5, 6, 13—Relief valves; 7, 8, 12—Directional control valves; 9, 10, 15—unidirectional flow control valves; 11—three-position four-way directional control valve; 14—Y-shaped two-position four-way directional control valve; 16, 17, 18—pressure gauges Figure 3.20: Principle of the CNC Lathe Hydraulic System Chapter 3: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Hydraulic Systems
1. Fault phenomenon The tailstock sleeve suddenly stopped operating during work. 2. Fault Analysis

As shown in Figure 3.20, the working principle of the tailstock sleeve in the CNC lathe hydraulic system is as follows. (1) When solenoid 5YA is de-energized and solenoid 6YA is energized, the sleeve extends. At this time, the oil inlet path is as follows: Tank 1 → Filter 2 → Hydraulic Pump 3 → Check Valve 4 → Pressure Reducing Valve 13 → Directional Control Valve 14 (left position) → Rodless Chamber of the Hydraulic Cylinder. The oil return path is: Rod Side of the Hydraulic Cylinder → Flow Control Check Valve 15 → Directional Control Valve 14 (left position) → Tank 1. The working preload during sleeve extension is adjusted via Pressure Reducing Valve 13 and displayed by Pressure Gauge 16, while the extension speed is controlled by Flow Control Valve 15. (2) When solenoid 5YA is energized and 6YA is de-energized, the sleeve retracts. At this time, the oil flow path is as follows: Tank 1 → Filter 2 → Hydraulic Pump 3 → Check Valve 4 → Pressure Reducing Valve 13 → Directional Control Valve 14 (in right position) → Flow Control Check Valve 15 → Rod Side Chamber of the Hydraulic Cylinder. Return The oil circuit is as follows: hydraulic cylinder rodless chamber → directional control valve 14 (right position) → reservoir 1. The working principle of the tailstock sleeve reveals that the possible causes of the failure include insufficient pressure, leakage, failure of the hydraulic pump to deliver oil or inadequate flow, scoring, wear, or damage to the seals on the hydraulic cylinder piston, as well as hydraulic valve malfunction—such as a disconnected or stuck valve. 3. Troubleshooting

Based on the above-mentioned failure causes, systematically eliminate them one by one using the logical diagnostic method described earlier. (1) Check the movement of the chuck and the turret. If the movement is normal, rule out a hydraulic pump malfunction and proceed to the next set of inspections. If the movement is abnormal, inspect the system’s pipes, fittings, and components for leaks. If the oil tank appears fine, further check whether the filter or suction pipe is clogged, verify that the oil viscosity isn’t too high, and ensure the pump isn’t improperly adjusted or damaged. (2) Check system pipes, fittings, and components for leaks.

(3) Check the fuel tank level to ensure it’s above the minimum mark, verify that the filter and suction pipe are not exposed above the oil surface, and confirm the return line is positioned higher than the oil level to prevent air from entering the tank. (4) Manually operate the directional control valve 14. If the spool cannot be pushed, it indicates that the directional control valve is malfunctioning. If the valve successfully switches positions and the hydraulic cylinder moves, it means there’s a fault in the solenoid valve’s electrical wiring. If the hydraulic cylinder still fails to move, proceed to the next step of inspection. (5) Manually adjust the one-way flow control valve 15 by increasing its opening. If the hydraulic cylinder moves, it indicates that the one-way flow control valve is blocked; otherwise, loosen the valve knob completely and proceed with further inspection. (6) Adjust the pressure relief valve 13. If the hydraulic cylinder moves, it indicates that the relief valve is either blocked or improperly adjusted; otherwise, turn the relief valve knob to its loosest setting and continue troubleshooting. (7) Check the pump station pressure. Ensure that directional control valve 14 is in the neutral position, then verify whether the pressure gauge 17 at the pump outlet reads the set value. If not, perform the following checks: Confirm that the pressure gauge switch is turned on and that the gauge itself is not damaged; inspect whether the hydraulic pump’s pressure adjustment spring is too loose; check if the suction oil filter is partially clogged or insufficient in capacity, and if the suction line is partially blocked; finally, examine whether the pump is damaged or experiencing severe internal leakage. Afterward, actuate the directional control valve to reverse its position. If the hydraulic cylinder moves as expected and its speed meets operational requirements, the issue has been resolved. However, if the cylinder’s speed still fails to meet specifications, the hydraulic pump will need repair. If, even after adjusting the pump pressure higher, the cylinder still doesn’t move, proceed to the next step of troubleshooting. (8) Switch the directional control valve 14 to the right position and observe the reading on pressure gauge 16. If the reading differs significantly from that on pressure gauge 17, it indicates that the right-side pipeline or the one-way flow control valve 15 is blocked; if the readings are similar, it means there is no blockage. (9) If the fault still cannot be eliminated after completing the above steps, the issue might lie in the hydraulic cylinder. First, avoid rushing to disassemble—refer instead to the tutorial on diagnosing and repairing electromechanical system faults.

126 Remove the hydraulic cylinder, switch the directional control valve to the left or right position, and after starting the hydraulic pump for a while, carefully feel along the entire cylinder wall to check for any locally heated areas. If you notice localized heating, it indicates that the seal at the piston inside the hydraulic cylinder has failed—replace the sealing element immediately. If no local heating is detected, proceed to the next step of inspection. Next, disconnect the pipe fitting at the opposite end of the hydraulic cylinder and connect it to a three-way fitting. Attach a pressure gauge and a shut-off valve to the other two ends of the three-way fitting, respectively. Then, shift the directional control valve 14 to the left position and note the reading on pressure gauge 16. If the reading from gauge 16 differs significantly from the reading on pressure gauge 17, it suggests that the pipeline is blocked. However, if the readings are nearly identical, it means there’s no blockage. There's a blockage. If the pipeline is clear of obstructions, proceed to the next step.

(10) Disassemble, break down, and inspect the hydraulic cylinder. After a series of inspections, the cause and location of the fault can be identified, ultimately allowing the issue to be resolved. Learning Objectives Understanding the steps and methods for diagnosing pneumatic system failures enables one to perform the process in a standardized and efficient manner. Perform maintenance and upkeep on the pneumatic system, mastering the common failure characteristics and repair methods for air sources, pressure valves, and solenoid directional control valves. Additionally, be able to analyze and diagnose issues based on the pneumatic system's schematic diagram. Troubleshooting. A Tutorial on Diagnosing and Repairing Electromechanical System Faults with Case Studies 128 4.1 Pneumatic System Fault Diagnosis Techniques and Methods Steps for Diagnosing Pneumatic System Faults (1) Familiar with performance and materials.
(2) On-site investigation and situation assessment. (3) Inductive analysis. (4) Troubleshoot.

(5) Summarize the lessons learned. 2. Methods for Diagnosing Pneumatic System Faults 1) Empirical method The method of diagnosing the location and identifying the cause of a fault—primarily relying on practical experience and using simple instruments—is known as the empirical approach . This approach can be likened to Traditional Chinese Medicine's four-step diagnostic process for patients:  "observation, auscultation and olfaction, inquiry, and palpation. " (1) Observation. For example, check whether the movement speed of the actuator shows any abnormal changes; verify if the pressure readings on the gauges at each measurement point  meet the specified requirements and remain stable without significant fluctuations; ensure that the lubricating oil quality and drip rate are within acceptable limits; confirm whe ther condensate is draining properly; inspect if the air exhausted from the directional control valve’s vent port is clean; monitor whether the indicator lights on the solenoid val ves are functioning correctly; examine whether any fastening screws or pipe fittings have become loose; check for kinks or crushing in the pipelines; and look for any noticeable vi brations—or assess whether there have been any changes in the quality of the processed products. (2) Listening. This includes both auditory and olfactory observations. For example,  check whether there are any unusual sounds when the cylinder or directional control valve changes direction; listen for air leaks from various points while the system is stopped b ut not yet depressurized, noting the volume of the leak sound and how it varies daily; also, determine if the solenoid coils or sealing rings emit a distinct odor due to overheatin g. (3) Inquiry: This involves reviewing the technical documentation of the pneumatic system to gain insights into its operating procedures, performance requirements, and key techni cal parameters; examining product catalogs to understand the function, structure, capabilities, and performance characteristics of each component; consulting maintenance and inspec tion records to assess the status of routine upkeep activities; and speaking directly with on-site operators to gather firsthand information about equipment operation, identify ear ly warning signs preceding potential failures, and learn about the conditions under which malfunctions occur. Additionally, it includes understanding previously encountered faults  and the methods used to resolve them. (4) Check: Feel and assess the temperature of externally moving components, as well as any temperature rise around the electromagnetic coil. I f the surface feels hot after touching it for 2 seconds, investigate the cause immediately. Also, check for vibrations in cylinders, pipes, etc., whether the cylinder exhibits any  creeping motion, and look for air leaks at all connections and component interfaces. The empirical method is simple and easy to apply, but due to differences in individual percepti on, practical experience, and judgment abilities, diagnosing faults can have certain limitations. 2) Reasoning and Analysis Method Inference analysis is a method that systematicall y dissects system failures by logically reasoning from surface symptoms, progressively narrowing down from the overall picture to specific components, ultimately pinpointing the ro ot cause of the issue. The principles of the reasoning analysis method are as follows. (1) Analyze step by step—starting from the easy to the difficult, from simple to complex, and moving from surface-level issues to underlying problems—to eliminate the fault.
(2) First, identify the factors with the highest failure rates.

(3) Prioritize checking the components that were replaced before the failure occurred. Many failures manifest themselves as poor performance of the actuating elements. For instance, in a pneumatic system controlled by solenoid valves, Chapter 4 focuses on fault diagnosis and maintenance of pneumatic transmission systems.

129 The root cause of the failure in the sequential control system, where the cylinder fails to actuate, is essentially insufficient pressure inside the cylinder, lack of pressure altogether, or inadequate thrust generated to move the load. Several potential reasons could lead to this issue, as outlined below. (1) The solenoid valve is malfunctioning. (2) There’s an issue with the control circuit—specifically, the control signal isn’t being transmitted. This could be due to a faulty limit switch that fails to send a signal, a counter receiving no signal, a relay malfunctioning, or perhaps the sensors used on the cylinder aren’t properly installed in their intended positions. (3) Cylinder malfunctions, such as dust entering the gap between the piston rod and the end cap guide sleeve, which can damage the cylinder barrel; piston seizure due to sticking in the cylinder bore; sealing failure; or the cylinder’s upper throttle valve remaining closed. (4) Pipeline failures, such as insufficient pressure regulation by the pressure-reducing valve, air leaks in the gas lines, and excessive pressure loss in the pipelines. (5) Insufficient air supply from the gas source.

4.2 Maintenance of Pneumatic Systems Maintenance of pneumatic systems can be divided into daily maintenance and periodic maintenance. The former refers to the maintenance tasks that must be performed every day, while the latter includes maintenance activities conducted weekly, monthly, or quarterly. All maintenance work should be documented for easy reference during future troubleshooting and repairs. Routine Maintenance The primary tasks of routine maintenance include maintaining the condensate drainage system, lubrication system, and air compressor system. Maintenance of the Condensate Drain System Condensation in compressed air can cause rusting of pipes and components. To prevent condensation from entering the compressed air system, it’s essential to promptly drain any accumulated moisture from all parts of the system. The condensate drainage system encompasses the entire pneumatic system—from air compressors and aftercoolers, through air receivers and piping networks, all the way to individual air filters, dryers, and automatic drains. At the end of each workday, condensate should be drained from all points to prevent freezing when nighttime temperatures drop below 0°C. Additionally, as pipe temperatures continue to fall overnight, more condensate may form; therefore, it’s also essential to drain accumulated water before starting up equipment each morning. Regularly inspect automatic drains and dryers to ensure they’re functioning properly, and make sure to clean air filters and automatic drains on a routine basis. 2) Maintenance of the Lubrication System

In pneumatic systems, all surfaces with relative motion—from control components to actuator elements—require lubrication. Insufficient lubrication can increase frictional resistance, leading to poor operation of pneumatic components and causing leaks due to wear on sealing surfaces. When the pneumatic device is running, check whether the oil mist lubricator's oil drip rate meets the requirements and whether the oil color appears normal. If you notice that the oil level in the reservoir hasn’t decreased, adjust the drip rate promptly; if adjustment doesn’t resolve the issue, the lubricator may need servicing or replacement. 3) Maintenance of the Air Compressor System Daily maintenance for the air compressor includes checking for unusual noises and abnormal heating, ensuring the lubricant level is normal, and verifying that there is sufficient cooling water supplied to the water-cooled aftercooler in the compressor system. 2. Regular Maintenance The main components of regular maintenance are leak checks and lubricator maintenance. (1) Inspect all system leak points. Compressed air loss due to leaks can lead to significant financial losses. This section is a tutorial on diagnosing and repairing mechanical system failures.

130 Inspections should be conducted at least once a month, and any areas found to have leaks must be repaired immediately. Leak checks should be performed during the workshop’s daytime  downtime—such as during breaks—or after working hours. At these times, pneumatic equipment is no longer in operation, resulting in reduced noise levels inside the workshop. Howeve r, some air pressure still remains in the pipelines, allowing you to pinpoint leak locations simply by listening for the characteristic hissing sound. Additionally, when checking f or leaks, applying soapy water or similar solutions at each inspection point can enhance detection sensitivity, making it easier to spot even minor leaks compared to relying solely  on auditory cues. (2) By inspecting the exhaust port of the directional control valve, determine whether the lubricating oil is at the proper level and check for any presence of c ondensation in the air. If lubrication is inadequate, verify that the oil mist generator is dispensing oil properly and confirm that its installation location is correct. If signif icant amounts of condensation are being discharged, inspect whether the condensate drainage system is appropriately designed and ensure that the filter is installed in the correct  position.

(3) Check whether the safety valve and emergency safety switch operate reliably. During regular maintenance, it is essential to verify their operational reliability to en sure both equipment and personal safety. (4) Observe whether the directional control valve operates reliably. Check if the spool or seals are worn (for example, if there’s still le akage even when the valve’s exhaust port is closed, it often indicates an early stage of wear), and replace the component if necessary. Alternatively, you can repeatedly cycle the  solenoid valve and assess its performance by listening to the switching sound—this will help determine if it’s functioning properly. (5) Repeatedly switch the directional control v alve to observe the cylinder's movement and determine whether the piston seals are functioning properly. Inspect the exposed portion of the piston rod for scratches, corrosion, or  uneven wear. Assess the contact between the piston rod and the guide bushing/seal ring inside the end cap, as well as the quality of compressed air treatment. Also, check if the cy linder is subjected to any lateral loads. Finally, verify whether there are any leaks at the cylinder head joint.

(6) Regularly inspect the secure installation of travel valves, li mit switches, and travel stops to prevent operational malfunctions. (7) When refilling the oil mist lubricator, pay attention to the decreasing level in the oil reservoir cup. If y ou notice that the oil consumption is too low, you must readjust the oil drip rate. If, after adjustment, the drip rate remains insufficient or no oil is dripping at all, check whe ther the selected lubricator model is appropriate, verify if the inlet and outlet ports are installed backward, and inspect whether the oil passages are blocked. Be sure to record  the findings in the weekly inspection checklist. Monthly or quarterly maintenance checks should be more thorough than daily and weekly inspections, but are limited to areas that ca n be externally inspected. Quarterly maintenance tasks are outlined in Table 4.1.
Table 4.1: Quarterly Maintenance Tasks for the Pneumatic System

And when the system pressure is zero, can you observe the pressure gauge pointer returning to t he zero mark? Check whether the readings of all pressure gauges are within the specified range. The safety valve activates when the pressure exceeds the set pressure—observe whethe r the safety valve begins to overflow. Check whether the pressure switch can properly turn on and off at the highest and lowest set pressure points. Check the exhaust port of the d irectional control valve for oil mist spray volume, whether condensation water is discharged, and if there are any air leaks.

Check the temperature rise of the solenoid coil and en sure the valve's switching action is functioning properly. The speed control valve adjusts the throttle valve opening to determine whether speed control can be achieved for the cyl inder or flow control for other components connected to the cylinder. Check whether the cylinder movement is smooth, and if there are any noticeable changes in speed or cycle time.  Also, verify that the mounting screws, nuts, and tie rods are securely tightened. Check whether the cylinder mounting bracket is loose or shows any abnormal deformation, verify if  the piston rod connection is secure, inspect the piston rod area for air leaks, and examine the surface of the piston rod. No rust, scratches, or uneven wear; check if there are a ny impact marks on the ends, verify for abnormalities during the stroke, and ensure the magnetic switch action position remains aligned. Is the mesh of the air compressor's inlet f ilter clogged? Does the condenser pressure change? Check for any variations in the temperature at the condensate drain outlet. 4.3 Air Source Fault Analysis and Troubleshooting 4.3.1 Fault Analysis and Troubleshooting of Air Compressors

Structure and Working Principle of Air Compressors The most commonly used air compressor in pneumatic transmission systems is the reciprocating piston-type air compressor, whose structure and operating principle are as follows: Figure 4.1 is shown here. It consists of exhaust valve 1, cylinder 2, piston 3, piston rod 4, crosshead 5, slide block 6, and connecting rod 7.

• Crank Consists of the intake valve, 9. Spring, 10, and more components. As the piston moves to the right, the pressure in the left chamber of the cylinder drops below atmospheric pressure, causing the intake valve to open. Air then enters the cylinder under atmospheric pressure—this process is known as the intake stroke. When the piston moves to the left… When moving, the intake valve closes as the gas inside the cylinder is compressed, squeezing the air within—this process is known as the compression phase. Once the pressure inside the cylinder rises slightly above the pressure in the delivery pipe, the exhaust valve opens, allowing the compressed air to flow into the delivery line; this stage is called the exhaust process. The reciprocating motion of the piston is driven by an electric motor (or internal combustion engine), which rotates a crankshaft. This motion is then transmitted via the connecting rod, crosshead, and piston rod. 1—Exhaust valve; 2—Cylinder; 3—Piston; 4—Piston rod; 5—Crosshead; 6—Guide rail; 7—Connecting rod; 8—Crank; 9—Intake valve; 10—Spring

1. Structure and Operating Principle of Air Dryers The air dryer functions to absorb and remove oil, moisture, and impurities from compressed air. After passing through the aftercooler, oil-water separator, and air receiver tank—where the compressed air undergoes initial purification—it becomes suitable for general pneumatic applications. However, if the air is intended for use in precision pneumatic devices, pneumatic instruments, or similar equipment, the compressed air must undergo further drying treatment. As shown in Figure 4.2, this is a diagram illustrating the structure and operating principle of an unheated regenerative adsorption dryer. This type of dryer has two beds filled with… The containers 1 and 2, acting as adsorbents, work by drawing moisture from the adsorbent material as air flows from the bottom to the top of container 1, releasing it into the atmosphere. These two containers periodically swap functions (every 5–10 minutes), enabling the adsorbent to alternate between adsorption and regeneration cycles. This continuous process ensures a steady supply of dry air. Figure 4.2: Diagram of the Structure and Operating Principle of a Non-Heated Regenerative Adsorption Dryer

Structure and Working Principle of Air Filters An air filter, also known as a water-removal and air-filter unit, primarily serves to remove solid impurities, water droplets, oil contaminants, and other pollutants from compressed air. As shown in Figure 4.3, this is a diagram illustrating the structure and operating principle of the air filter. The air filter consists of a cyclone blade 1 and a filter element. 1—Whirlwind Leaf; 2—Filter Cartridge; 3—Water Reservoir Cup; 4—Water Stopper; 5—Manual Drain Valve Figure 4.3: Structure and Operating Principle of an Air Filter – Case Studies in Mechatronic System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance, Page 134 Consisting of a water cup, 3. a water stopper, 4. a manual drain valve, and more. Compressed air enters through the inlet and is directed into the cyclone blades, which feature numerous small notches angled at a specific angle. These notches cause the air to rotate violently in a tangential, reverse direction, effectively trapping Larger water droplets, oil droplets, and dust particles mixed within the gas experience greater centrifugal force, causing them to collide with the inner wall of the water collection cup and separate from the gas. These contaminants then settle at the bottom of the cup. Next, the gas passes through a central filter element, which further removes even finer impurities, resulting in clean air that is eventually discharged through the outlet port. A deflector plate is installed to prevent gas turbulence from swirling up the accumulated wastewater in the water collection cup, thereby avoiding disruption of the filtration process. To ensure the air filter operates efficiently, it’s essential to promptly drain the collected wastewater from the cup using the manual drain valve. In situations where manual drainage is inconvenient, an automatic drain-type water separator and air filter can be used instead. 2. Common Air Filter Faults and Repair Methods

4.4 Fault Analysis and Troubleshooting of Pressure Valves 4.4.1 Fault Analysis and Troubleshooting of the Pressure Regulator

Structure and Operating Principle of the Pressure Regulator As shown in Figure 4.5, this is a diagram illustrating the structure and operating principle of the QTY-type direct-acting pressure reducing valve. When the valve is in operation, compressed air enters from the left end, passes through the throttling port 10 for pressure reduction, and then exits from the valve outlet. By adjusting the handle 1 and compressing springs 2 and 3, the diaphragm 5 is pushed downward, causing the valve stem 8 to move the spool assembly downward as well. This action opens the throttling port 10, allowing compressed air to flow through while undergoing throttling, thereby reducing the output air pressure below the input pressure—thus achieving the pressure-reducing function. Meanwhile, a portion of the outgoing airflow enters the diaphragm chamber 6 via the damping hole 7, generating an upward force beneath the diaphragm 5. This upward force continuously acts to reduce the opening of the throttling port, helping to lower the output pressure. Once the force acting on the diaphragm balances with the spring force, the output pressure of the pressure reducing valve stabilizes at a certain level. Within a certain range, the smaller the opening of valve port 10, the stronger the throttling effect—and the greater the pressure drop. 1—Handle; 2 and 3—Pressure-adjusting springs; 4—Relief port; 5—Diaphragm; 6—Diaphragm chamber; 7—Damping orifice; 8—Valve stem; 9—Reset spring; 10—Valve port; 11—Vent hole Figure 4.5: Structural and Operational Diagram of the QTY-Type Direct-Acting Pressure Reducing Valve When the input pressure fluctuates—for instance, if the input pressure rises momentarily—the output pressure downstream of valve port 10 also increases accordingly, causing the pressure inside diaphragm chamber 6 to rise as well. This disrupts the original force balance, prompting diaphragm 5 to move upward. As a result, a small amount of gas is released through relief port 4 and vent hole 11. Simultaneously, thanks to the action of reset spring 9, the output pressure begins to decrease until… Until a new balance is established, the output pressure after rebalancing essentially returns to its original value. Conversely, if the output pressure drops momentarily, diaphragm 5 moves downward, increasing the opening of the air inlet and reducing the throttling effect, which in turn causes the output pressure to rise back to nearly its original level. By adjusting handle 1, regulating springs 2 and 3 return to their free state, causing the output pressure to drop to zero. Under the action of reset spring 9, the valve core closes the air inlet port, thereby putting the pressure-reducing valve into a shut-off state with no airflow output. 2. Structure and Working Principle of Safety Valves The function of the safety valve is to vent to the atmosphere when the pressure in the pneumatic system rises to the set value, thereby maintaining the system pressure at that predetermined level. Figure 4.6 illustrates the structure and operating principle of a direct-acting relief valve. When the gas pressure in the system remains within the set range, the force acting on piston 3 is less than the force exerted by spring 2, keeping the piston in the closed position (see Figure 4.6(a)). However, once the system… When the pressure rises and the force acting on the piston exceeds the spring's preset pressure, the piston moves upward, opening the valve to release air (see Figure 4.6(b)). The valve remains open until the system pressure drops below the set range, at which point the piston closes again. The magnitude of the opening pressure depends on It relates to the spring's preload amount.

Structure and Working Principle of the Cylinder As shown in Figure 4.9, this is a diagram illustrating the structure and working principle of a standard single-piston rod-type double-acting cylinder. The cylinder is divided into two chambers by the piston—namely, the rodless chamber and the rod-end chamber. When compressed air enters the rodless chamber, it exerts a force on the right-hand face of the piston. Chapter 4: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Pneumatic Transmission Systems 141 It utilizes various counteracting forces to push the piston forward: as air from the rod-side chamber is exhausted into the atmosphere, the piston rod extends outward. Conversely, when compressed air enters the rod-side chamber, the force exerted by the compressed air against the left face of the piston overcomes these counteracting forces, driving the piston to move to the right. At this point, air from the rodless chamber is expelled into the atmosphere, causing the piston rod to retract. By alternately supplying and exhausting air into the rodless and rod-side chambers, the piston rod is made to extend and retract repeatedly, enabling the cylinder to perform reciprocating motion. 1—Rear cylinder head; 2—Sealing ring; 3—Buffer sealing ring; 4—Piston seal; 5—Piston; 6—Buffer plunger; 7—Piston rod;

Operating Principle As shown in Figure 4.11, this is the pneumatic system diagram of the material-handling trolley (hereafter referred to as "the trolley") for a company's large-scale critical 35MN extrusion press. The trolley's operational sequence is outlined in Table 4.12. Figure 4.11: Pneumatic System Diagram of the Material-Collecting Cart

Table 4.12: Car Movement Program Action 1YA 2YA 3YA 4YA Cart enters material receiving area +--- Follow-along Shear--++ Car unloading and material removal - +-- 1YA energizes, and the cart moves to the material-handling position. When 1YA de-energizes, the cart stops and waits for the extruded material to arrive. Once the material is in place, the hydraulic shear mounted on the cart begins cutting the material. At this point, the designer’s original intention was to energize 3YA and 4YA, causing valves 2 and 3 to shift their positions. After entering the free intake-exhaust state, this allows the material-squeezing process to continue uninterrupted while the carriage is shearing the material. This approach significantly enhances both the yield of the squeezed product and the overall final product quality—truly a key feature of the pneumatic system design for this extruder's receiving carriage: follow-along shearing. However, during debugging, it was discovered that the carriage did not operate as expected throughout the follow-along shearing process. Case Study on Diagnosis and Maintenance of Electromechanical System Failures
144 2. Fault Symptoms and Analysis

1) Fault Symptoms (1) Valve 3 does not change direction after being energized during follow-up shearing. (2) Valve 2, although energized to reverse direction during follow-up shearing, operates unreliably. Since the system appeared simple, it wasn’t given much attention during initial debugging—instead, it was handled as usual, with the assumption that the issue stemmed from contamination of the new components or system elements. Despite multiple disassemblies for inspection and cleaning, the fault remained unresolved. A straightforward test conducted on Valve 2 and Valve 3 revealed that these valves themselves were functioning properly. However, even after reinstalling them, the problem persisted. After a thorough analysis of each step in the cart’s operational sequence, along with a detailed examination of how Valves 2 and 3 operate, we concluded that this malfunction was caused by an inherently flawed design and component selection. 2) Analysis of the operating principles of Valve 2 and Valve 3

The valves 2 and 3 used in this system are 80200-series, two-position, three-way solenoid directional control valves (base model from Germany's Haileon company). These are two-stage valves, consisting of a miniature, direct-acting, two-position, three-way solenoid valve paired with a pneumatically controlled main valve. The operational pressure requirements for this valve are… Ranging from 0.2 to 1.0 MPa, the minimum working pressure is 0.2 MPa; below this value, the main spool cannot ensure reliable directional control and reset.

3) Pressure Analysis in the Two Chambers of the Car Cylinder Valve 1's 1YA is energized, causing the rodless chamber of the carriage cylinder to receive air while the rod-side chamber exhausts. Once the carriage reaches the material-handling position, 1YA de-energizes, and valve 1 returns to its original position. At this point, since the rodless chamber was still pressurized before valve 1 reset—due to its prior state of being vented—the chamber retains a residual pressure (the exact magnitude of which depends on the system). (Unspecified), the rod-side chamber is nearly at zero pressure because the valve was venting before resetting. From the analysis of how valves 2 and 3 operate, as well as the pressure dynamics within the carriage cylinder chambers, it becomes clear that during follower shearing, although valve 3 is energized, it cannot shift its main spool due to the lack of sufficient residual pressure in its rod-side chamber—pressure necessary to actuate valve 2. Meanwhile, valve 2 might still be able to shift, thanks to some residual pressure present in its capless chamber; however, since this pressure level is unpredictable, even if valve 3 is energized, its shifting action remains unreliable. 3. Problem Solving
From the analysis above, it is inappropriate to select this type of two-stage, pneumatically controlled main valve for the vehicle's pneumatic system. Yes, there are two solutions:

Switch to direct-acting components Simply replace the original valves 2 and 3 with 23ZVD-L15 (normally closed type). However, since the original valves 2 and 3 operate on DC 24 V, while the new valve requires AC 220 V, an intermediate relay will need to be added. Improve the car's pneumatic system Replace valves 2 and 3 with a K35K2-15 air-controlled slide valve, using one of the existing valves (either valve 2 or valve 3) as its pilot control valve—note that the original normally closed type must be modified into a normally open configuration. The specific system diagram is shown in Figure 4.12. Although this approach requires modifications to the piping system, it effectively achieves the desired functionality. It’s slightly more complex, but when analyzed in terms of the effectiveness and reliability of follower-driven shearing, it outperforms Method 1. Additionally, two unidirectional flow control valves have been added to fine-tune the carriage speed. Currently, most of the solenoid directional control valves offered by pneumatic component manufacturers—both domestically and internationally—are two-stage designs, featuring a pilot stage followed by a main stage. To ensure proper operation, there is typically a working pressure range. When selecting equipment or addressing issues on-site, it’s essential to conduct a comprehensive analysis that takes into account the specific characteristics of the production process and the performance of the components. Diagnosis and Repair: Chapter 5 – Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of the Electrical System

147 Electrical equipment can experience a wide variety of failures during operation, leading to equipment shutdowns that disrupt production—and in severe cases, even result in personal injuries or equipment accidents. The causes of these failures include, in addition to the natural aging of electrical components, a significant number of issues arising from neglecting routine maintenance and upkeep of the equipment. This often allows minor problems to escalate into major incidents. Additionally, some failures occur due to improper handling techniques employed by electrical technicians when addressing faults, reliance on makeshift solutions due to missing parts, or misjudgments and inaccurate measurements that inadvertently widen the scope of the problem. Therefore, to ensure the reliable operation of electrical equipment, minimize downtime caused by repairs, and ultimately enhance equipment utilization and overall productivity, it is crucial to prioritize regular maintenance and proper care of electrical systems. Furthermore, it’s essential to maintain an adequate stock of key electrical components and frequently replaced parts tailored to the specific needs of each facility’s equipment and production processes. 5.1 Causes and Types of Electrical Faults Electrical equipment failures are inevitable. Even with effective measures such as daily maintenance, routine inspections, and periodic calibration and repairs, it remains impossible to guarantee the long-term, flawless operation of electrical devices without ever encountering an electrical fault. Causes of Electrical Faults Electrical faults primarily arise from the following two factors. (1) Natural Failures. During operation, electrical equipment is often subjected to numerous adverse factors. For example, mechanical vibrations during equipment operation; the thermal effects of overcurrents accelerating insulation degradation and deterioration of electrical components; arcing that causes damage; natural wear and tear from prolonged use; environmental influences such as temperature and humidity; corrosion from harmful substances; inherent quality issues within the components themselves; and even the equipment's natural lifespan—all these can lead to various types of failures that disrupt normal functioning. Therefore, strengthening routine maintenance, upkeep, and periodic inspections can help ensure that electrical equipment remains trouble-free—or experiences far fewer failures—for an extended period. However, it’s crucial not to mistakenly assume that equipment failures are inevitable and thus overlook the importance of consistent daily maintenance and regular overhaul work. (2) Human-induced failures. During operation, electrical equipment can experience accidents—or even pose risks to personal safety—due to unintended mechanical forces causing damage, improper handling, or inadequate installation practices. Types of Electrical Faults Due to the diverse structures of electrical equipment and the wide variety of electrical components, the factors that lead to electrical failures are equally numerous. Consequently, the faults that occur in electrical devices are bound to be just as varied and complex. Classified by Failure Phenomenon Fault phenomena can be broadly categorized into the following two main types. (1) Faults with obvious external characteristics that are easy to detect. For example, significant heating, smoking, emitting a burnt odor, or sparking in motors or electrical equipment. These types of failures typically result from motor or equipment winding overloads, insulation breakdown, short circuits, or ground faults. When addressing these issues, in addition to replacing or repairing the faulty components, it’s essential to identify and eliminate the root causes that led to the problems in the first place. (2) Failures with No Visible Symptoms. This type of failure is a major issue in control circuits, often caused by improper adjustment of electrical components, mechanical malfunctions, poor or loose contact at contacts and crimped wire terminals, as well as the damage of small parts or even broken wires. The more complex the circuit, the higher the likelihood of encountering these kinds of faults. Although minor, they occur frequently—and because they lack obvious external signs, pinpointing the exact fault location can often take considerable time. In some cases, it may even require consulting specialized tutorials on diagnosing and repairing electromechanical system failures. 148

Various measuring instruments and tools are essential for pinpointing the fault location. Once the fault is identified, it often requires only a simple adjustment or repair to immediately restore the equipment to normal operation. Therefore, the ability to quickly locate the fault is critical in minimizing downtime when addressing this type of issue. Classified by Fault Location Classified by the location of the fault, the main types include power supply failures, wiring faults, and component failures. (1) Power failure. The power supply primarily refers to the energy source that provides power to electrical equipment and control circuits—it is essential for electrical devices. The foundation for the operation of control circuits. Variations in power supply parameters can lead to failures in electrical control systems, and power supply issues typically ac count for about 20% of all faults in control circuits. When a power supply failure occurs, the control system may exhibit the following symptoms: even after an electrical switch is  turned off, voltage remains present at the terminals of connected devices, or the equipment casing becomes energized; certain system functions become intermittent or erratic, lead ing to repeated blown fuses; the faulty control system fails to respond, with no indicators lighting up at all; or some circuits operate normally while others fail to function prop erly. Given the wide variety of power sources, each with its own unique characteristics, and considering that different electrical devices may display varying fault behaviors under  the same power parameters, diagnosing and locating power supply issues can be particularly challenging. (2) Circuit Faults. Both wire faults and faulty connections in the wiring s ystem fall under the category of circuit faults. Wire faults typically occur when the insulation layer deteriorates or becomes damaged, leading to wire breakage. On the other hand,  faulty connections are usually caused by loose, oxidized, or moldy connections. When a circuit fault occurs, the control circuit may exhibit issues such as poor contact, intermitt ent power supply, or severe overheating. (3) Component Failure. In an electrical control circuit, dozens—or even more—different types of components are used, and each component can  fail in its own unique way.

5.2 Maintenance and保养 of Electrical Equipment (1) The doors, covers, locks, and oil-resistant seals around the door frames of electrical cabinets must  all be in good condition. Doors and covers should close tightly, ensuring no water droplets, oil stains, or metal shavings enter the cabinet—this prevents damage to electrical equi pment and avoids potential accidents. (2) The flexible conduits connecting electrical equipment components—whether they are wires, cables, or protective conductors—must not be corr oded by coolant, oil stains, or similar substances. Additionally, there should be no loosening or fraying of the conduit ends at connections. During inspections, if any such issues  are detected, they should be promptly repaired to prevent insulation damage that could lead to short-circuit failures. (3) The button stations of electrical equipment, buttons on  control panels, handles of master control switches, signal lights, and instrument covers must all be kept clean and in good condition. (4) Maintenance and保养 cycle for electrical eq uipment. Electrical components housed within electrical cabinets are typically not frequently monitored by opening the doors; instead, they rely primarily on regular maintenance an d保养. The frequency of this maintenance should be determined based on factors such as the equipment’s design, usage patterns, and environmental conditions. As a general guideline, e lectrical equipment maintenance can often be carried out concurrently with the first- and second-level maintenance tasks performed on the associated mechanical equipment. For examp le, the first-level maintenance of metal cutting machine tools is typically performed once every quarter, with operation times ranging from 6 to 12 hours depending on the complexit y of the machine. During this maintenance, the following tasks can be carried out on the electrical components inside the machine tool's control cabinet: ① Clean out any accumulated dust or foreign objects from the cabinet;

② Repair or replace electrical components that are about to fail; ③ Organize and tidy up the internal wiring to ensure it looks neat and professional—especially for temporary measures taken during emergency repairs, these should ideally be resto red to their original, proper configuration; ④ Tighten the movable parts of fuses to ensure good contact; ⑤ Secure all wiring terminal screws and pressure screws on electrical components, ensuring that every wire connection is firm and reliable to minimize contact resistance; ⑥ Perform a powered-up test run to verify that the operational sequence of the electrical components is accurate and dependable. Chapter 5: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Electrical Systems

When maintaining and servicing electrical components, pay special attention to checking contactors and relay c ontacts that experience frequent operation and carry high currents. To withstand the mechanical stress and electrical arcing caused by frequent circuit switching, most contactors a nd relays have contacts made from silver or silver alloys. A natural layer of silver oxide or silver sulfide forms on their surfaces, but this does not affect conductivity—indeed,  under the influence of electric arcs, it can even revert back to pure silver. Therefore, avoid wiping or removing this protective layer unnecessarily. Even if the surface of these silver-based contacts develops scorch marks or becomes uneven, it typically won’t compromise their ability to maintain good electrical contact, so there’s no need to file or smooth them down. However, copper contacts should be promptly resurfaced if they show signs of burning or roughness. When inspecting contactors and relays that produce noticeable noise, first identify the root cause and address it before continuing operation. If the issue persists despite repairs, the component should be replaced with a new one. Verify the thermal relay to ensure it operates correctly. The verification results should match the thermal relay's operational characteristics. Verify the time relay and check whether its delay time meets the specified requirements. If the error exceeds the allowable tolerance, adjust or repair it promptly to ensure it once again complies with the required standards. 5.3 Maintenance and Fault Diagnosis of Electrical Equipment

Methods for Overhauling Electrical Equipment When it comes to electrical faults in equipment, repairs aren’t particularly challenging—but pinpointing the exact cause of the problem can be extremely difficult. That’s why quickly identifying the root cause and location of the fault is crucial, making it essential to gather accurate, firsthand information right from the start. On-site investigations and visual inspections are the primary methods and approaches for obtaining this vital initial data, and the process can be vividly summarized in four key steps: "Observe, Ask, Listen, and Test." Hope

After a failure occurs, it often leaves behind certain signs of the malfunction; when inspecting, you can start with the following aspects. (1) Inspect for visual changes, such as activation of the fuse indicator device, peeling of insulation from the winding surface, oil leakage from the transformer tank, loose or detached wiring terminals, and malfunctions in various signaling devices. (2) Observe color changes. Some electrical equipment exhibits color shifts when temperatures rise—for example, after a short-circuit fault occurs in a transformer winding, the transformer oil heats up and changes from its original bright yellow to black or darker shades. Similarly, the color of generator stator slot wedges may turn black and darken due to overheating. 2) Question

Ask the operator about the circumstances before and after the failure occurred. Typically, the questions include: Did the fault happen before startup, right after startup, or during operation? Did the equipment stop automatically during operation, or was it stopped by the operator after detecting an abnormal condition? At the time of the failure, what specific operating procedure was the equipment performing, and which button was pressed or which switch was toggled? Were there any unusual signs—such as noises, odors, smoke, or sparks—immediately before or after the malfunction? Has a similar issue occurred previously, and if so, how was it resolved? Often, these inquiries can yield valuable insights, helping to analyze the root cause of the failure based on how the electrical equipment is designed and operates.

3) Listen Elect rical equipment produces different sounds during normal operation versus when a fault occurs, allowing you to identify the nature of the problem by listening. For instance, when a  motor is running properly, the sound should be smooth and steady, without any extraneous noises or unusual tones. However, if you hear a loud  "buzzing " sound, it indicates that the load current is too high. If the  "buzzing " is particularly intense, it suggests the motor is operating under a single-phase condition. A  "gurgling " noise might signal that the bearing clearance is abnormal or that the ball bearings are damaged. And if there’s a severe grinding or scraping sound, it points to a potential mech anical failure in the rotating machinery system. 150

Sub-surface pitting and broken, dislodged rotor bars; if a  "hissing " sound is present, it indicates the bearings are lacking lubrication. 4) Cut The so-called  "cut " refers to inspecting the electrical system using the following method. (1) Use your hands to feel the temperature of the faulty motor, transformer, and coils of certain electrica l components in the area being inspected. Typically, temperatures will rise noticeably when a fault occurs, allowing you to determine whether a problem exists simply by touch. (2)  Perform a power-off check on the circuit. Before inspection, disconnect the main power supply, then systematically identify the fault location based on areas where failures may occ ur. ① Remove dust and dirt to eliminate the risk of electrical leakage. ② Check the connection status of each component's wires and the condition of the terminals for rust. ③ Inspe ct the condition of elastic components and electrical contact parts for wear, natural wear, and fatigue wear. ④ Check moving parts for rust, dirt, dried-up grease, and mechanical d amage. For previously inspected electrical systems, it’s also necessary to verify that the replaced components match the original circuit requirements in terms of model and specifi cations, confirm the correct wire gauge for connections, ensure proper wiring methods without errors, and check whether any other wires or components have shifted, been reconnected  incorrectly, or sustained damage. After completing these checks, any identified faults should be promptly addressed—this will eliminate potential issues such as leakage currents,  poor contact, and short circuits, thereby restoring the system to its original functionality. (3) Perform a power-on check of the circuit. If the power-off check fails to identify  the fault, proceed with a power-on inspection of the equipment. ① Check the power supply. Use a multimeter to verify that the power voltage is within the normal range, and ensure t here are no phase failures or significant imbalances. ② Check the circuits. The inspection sequence is as follows: first inspect the control circuit, then the main circuit; next, e xamine the auxiliary system, followed by the main drive system; start with the AC system, then move on to the DC system; finally, check the switching circuit before inspecting the  adjustment system. Control. Alternatively, follow the circuit's operational sequence: first, turn off all switches and remove all fuses. Then, starting from the back and moving for ward, sequentially insert the fuses for each section being checked, close the switches, and observe whether each electrical component operates as expected. Continue this process st ep by step until the faulty component or area is identified. ③ During power-on checks, the fault range can also be determined by examining the control knobs and adjustable componen ts of the circuit. Since the circuit is divided into distinct sections—each interconnected yet functionally independent—faults can be roughly pinpointed based on whether the adjust able parts are functioning properly, whether their adjustment ranges have shifted, whether the control components are operating normally, and whether the interlocking relationships  between these components remain intact. Once the general fault area is identified, further narrowing down the issue is achieved by systematically testing critical points, ultimate ly leading to the discovery of the faulty component. 2. Using Instruments for Electrical Circuit Fault Diagnosis The method of identifying faults using instruments and meters is ca lled the detection method, with the multimeter being one of the most commonly used tools. By measuring parameters such as voltage, resistance, and current with a multimeter, you ca n determine whether a circuit is conducting or broken—and pinpoint the exact location of the fault—based on how these measured values change. Resistance Measurement Method The principle diagram of a certain electrical resistance step-measurement method is shown in Figure 5.1. The circuit fault manifests as the contactor KM1 coil failing to energize when the start button SB2 is pressed. (1) Hierarchical Measurement Method. First, disconnect the power supply, then turn the multimeter's selector switch to the resistance " " range. Press and hold SB2 while measuring the resistance between points 1 and 6. If the resistance reads infinity, it indicates an open circuit. Next, measure the resistance between each pair of points: 1-2, 1-3, 1-4, and 1-5. If you notice a sudden increase in resistance between any specific pair of points, it means that either the contact at that point or the connecting wire has become faulty. 151 Poor contact or open circuit. Different electrical components and wires have varying resistance values, so the resistance thresholds used to determine whether a circuit or component is faulty also differ accordingly. For instance, when measuring across the terminals of a fuse holder, a resistance value below 0.5 ohms indicates normal operation, while a reading above 10 kΩ suggests an open circuit with no continuity. A resistance in the range of several ohms or higher typically points to poor contact. However, these criteria may not apply universally to other components or wires. Before proceeding with further checks, use a multimeter to measure the voltage between terminals 1 and 6. If the voltage is normal, press and hold the start button SB2 without releasing it.
