Figure 5.5: Local Short-Circuit Method When using the short-circuit method to check for faults, keep the following points in mind. (1) The short-circuit method involves using insulated wires while working on live circuits, so it’s crucial to prioritize safety and avoid electric shock accidents. (2) The short-circuit method is only suitable for detecting open-circuit faults in wires and contacts with extremely low voltage drops. As for components with higher voltage drops, For open-circuit faults such as those in resistors, coils, or windings, the shorting method should not be used, as this could lead to a short-circuit fault instead. (3) The short-circuit method can only be used when it is ensured that no accidents will occur in the electrical equipment or mechanical components. 5.4 Troubleshooting and Repair of Electrical Faults
Poor insulation

(1) Insulation failure caused by contaminants seeping into the wire connections. The recommended method is to gently wipe the affected area with anhydrous alcohol or another highly volatile, non-corrosive organic solvent while the power is off—simply until the stain is completely removed. When cleaning, keep three key points in mind: First, ensure the solvent has minimal water content; otherwise, excessive moisture could lead to equipment rusting, slow drying times, and degraded performance of insulating materials due to water absorption. Second, take strict fire safety precautions—no open flames or sparks are permitted at the work site. Finally, choose a solvent that won’t damage the original insulation layers, warning labels, or the glossy finish on plastic casings. (2) Insulation failure caused by aging.

This failure was caused by the insulation layer operating continuously under high temperatures and corrosive conditions. After insulation aging occurs, it is often accompanied by a practical guide to diagnosing and repairing electrical and mechanical system failures. 154 Phenomena such as brittleness, cracking, flaking, and whitening may occur. If you encounter any of these issues, immediately replace the wire or component to prevent more extensive damage. At the same time, it’s crucial to identify the root cause of insulation aging and eliminate any factors that might be accelerating it. For instance, if overheating of the wire is responsible for insulation degradation, not only should the underlying issue be promptly addressed, but also ensure that the insulating tape wrapped around the wire connections meets the required standards. Typically, 3 to 5 layers of insulating tape are ideal—avoiding excessive thickness, as this can trap heat at the connection points, leading to oxidation and poor electrical contact. When wrapping, make sure the tape isn’t too loose or uneven; instead, apply it tightly to provide effective protection against water and moisture. Additionally, any exposed wire cores must be properly repaired and crimped securely—no loose ends, burrs, or sharp edges should remain, as these could puncture the insulating tape, potentially causing electrical leakage. (3) Insulation damage caused by external forces. At this point, the entire wire should be replaced. If external forces cannot be easily avoided, appropriate protective measures should be taken for the wire—such as covering it with an insulating sleeve, using braided wire, or coiling the wire into a spiral shape. If immediate replacement of the wire is not possible, as an emergency measure… Alternatively, you can also use insulating tape to bandage the injured area, but this should only be done if the working environment permits. 2. Wire Connection Fault When encountering poor wire contact, first remove the oxide layer and any dirt from the wire ends, then clean the oxide buildup on the fixed connection points before re-establishing the connection. Be sure to keep the following points in mind during the process. (1) To prevent direct contact between two different metals, such as copper and aluminum, a copper-aluminum transition plate can be used. (2) For situations where the wire is too thin or the fixed section has excessive space, resulting in insufficient clamping pressure, you can fold the wire back and forth several times to create multiple strands, or bend the wire’s tip into a loop before tightening it securely. If necessary, you may also add an additional washer. (3) When the wire is difficult to connect to the fixed part, you can tin the wire and also tin the fixed part—this usually ensures good electrical contact. (4) For long-term, high-current operation under special conditions, to enhance the conductivity of the connection points, wires can be directly soldered together using tin solder. Additionally, employing larger mounting hardware (to facilitate heat dissipation), applying a thin layer of petroleum jelly (to prevent exposure to air), and increasing the clamping force on the wires can all help improve the electrical performance of the connections. (5) When connecting wires, all joints must be made directly on the terminal blocks; splicing wires by stripping and joining them in the middle of the conductor is strictly prohibited. Typically, no more than two wires should be connected to each terminal block. When bending wires into an arc shape, they should be wrapped clockwise around the terminal post to prevent the wires from loosening as the nut is tightened. (6) Low-voltage connections require higher reliability than high-voltage connections. Since low-voltage systems have lower voltages, it’s less likely for even tiny air gaps or microscopic impurities between wires to cause breakdown. Therefore, silver-plated connectors and wire soldering are typically used. (7) For faults in fine wire connections—such as the coil in a multimeter's test lead—the coil should generally be replaced. A high-voltage arc method is recommended to melt and weld broken ends together; however, manual connections often result in limited lifespan due to insufficient mechanical strength and inadequate insulation performance. 5.5 Common Faults and Maintenance of Low-Voltage Electrical Appliances The electrical control systems of机电 equipment typically use low-voltage electrical devices as their system components and electric motors as the power source. Consequently, electrical faults in机电 equipment primarily occur in these two types of devices. Additionally, in highly automated机电 equipment such as CNC machine tools, failures in programmable controllers also serve as a major cause of equipment downtime. This section will introduce repair and diagnostic methods for these types of failures. Low-voltage electrical equipment refers to devices used in low-voltage (1200 V and below) power networks, capable of responding to operational signals and external field conditions. Chapter 5: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Electrical Systems

155 The device in question is an electrical component designed to automatically or manually alter the state or parameters of a circuit, enabling functions such as controlling, protecting, measuring, indicating, regulating, and converting circuits or controlled objects. It serves as the most fundamental element in constructing low-voltage control circuits. Commonly used low-voltage electrical appliances include protective low-voltage control devices, such as fuses and residual current devices; control devices like contactors, relays, solenoid valves, and electromagnetic brakes; and master command devices, including universal transfer switches, push buttons, and limit switches. 5.5.1 Contactor A contactor is an electrical device used to automatically switch large-current circuits on or off. It can frequently connect or disconnect AC and DC circuits and enables remote control. Depending on the type of circuit being controlled, contactors are broadly classified into two main categories: AC contactors and DC contactors. AC Contactor An AC contactor is an electrical device that uses electromagnetic attraction combined with spring force to operate the closing and opening of its contacts. In control circuits for机电 equipment, it’s commonly used to connect or disconnect the power supply to motors and control circuits. The contactor primarily consists of an electromagnetic system and a contact system. The contact system includes main contacts and auxiliary contacts, while the electromagnetic system comprises components such as an electromagnetic coil, moving iron core, stationary iron core, and a return spring. The basic operation of electromagnetic attraction works as follows: When the electromagnetic coil is de-energized, the spring’s reaction force—or the moving iron core’s own weight—keeps the main contacts open. However, once the electromagnetic coil is connected to its rated voltage, the electromagnetic force overcomes the spring’s resistance, pulling the moving iron core toward the stationary iron core. This movement closes the main contacts, simultaneously actuating the auxiliary contacts as well. Following the principle of tackling easier tasks first, inspect the coil before checking the power supply and mechanical components to avoid unnecessary disassembly. Also, assess the contactor.

Whether it's normal should be determined according to the following work steps. (1) Electrical inspection: The two terminals of the contactor coil should remain conductive. When measured with a resistance range, they should show a resistance between roughly 10 and several tens of ohms. If the resistance exceeds 2 ohms, check the coil circuit for poor connections or open wires. Phenomenon: When the resistance value is too low—such as in a small contactor measuring just a few ohms or even fractions of an ohm—it’s advisable to check for short-circuiting. (2) Mechanical component inspection: When manually or with other tools pushing the armature, the movement should be smooth and free, with no sticking or jamming. After the contacts engage, applying additional force should still allow for a defined travel distance. Once the hand is released, the contacts must quickly return to their original position, and the contact action must occur in perfect synchronization. (3) Power-on inspection: When the coil is supplied with the rated voltage, the contactor should operate reliably; there should be no noticeable noise after it pulls in, and it should reset quickly when power is cut off.

Common faults and repair methods for AC contactors are described below. (1) Coil Failure. Coil failures can be categorized into overheating burnout and coil breakage. There are several reasons for coil burnout: for instance, if the supply voltage is too high—exceeding 110% of the rated voltage—or too low—dropping below 85% of the rated value—it can lead to contactor coil damage. This occurs because the contactor armature fails to engage properly, resulting in a reduced impedance in the coil circuit and causing excessive current flow. Additionally, discrepancies between the actual power supply frequency and the rated value, mechanical obstructions preventing the armature from closing, or uneven mating surfaces on the iron core that widen the air gap during engagement can all contribute to this issue. Environmental factors, such as poor ventilation, excessive humidity, or abnormally high ambient temperatures, may also trigger coil burnout. Coil breakage typically results from overheating and subsequent burnout, though it can occasionally be caused by external physical damage. Different countermeasures should be taken depending on the specific fault cause. If the issue is due to a faulty coil, simply replace it with an identical model. If the iron core is contaminated or its pole surfaces are uneven, clean the pole surfaces as needed or replace the iron core altogether.

(2) Contactor contact welding. ① Frequent device startups, where the main contacts are repeatedly subjected to inrush currents, or prolonged passage of currents exceeding the rated value through the contacts, can both lead to contact overheating or welding. In the former case, proper operating procedures should be followed to avoid frequent starts, or alternatively, a suitable electromechanical system fault diagnosis and repair case study guide should be consulted. 156 Contactor with adjustable operating frequency and duty cycle. For the latter, reduce the load on the driven equipment to ensure it operates at its rated capacity, or reselect a sui table contactor based on the equipment's actual working current. If the controlled device is a three-phase motor, verify that the three-phase contacts are synchronized. If they’re  out of sync, the motor will briefly run on a single phase during startup, causing excessive inrush current—so adjustments should be made accordingly. ② There is a short-circuit poi nt on the load side. When the contactor pulls in, the short-circuit current flows through the main contacts, causing them to weld together. In this case, you should inspect the loc ation of the short-circuit point and eliminate the fault. ③ Contact pressure is abnormal. Unreliable contactor engagement or vibrations can result in insufficient contact pressure,  causing the contacts to fail to properly connect. Increased contact resistance leads to severe heating of the contacts. To check the contact pressure during adjustments, you can u se the paper-strip method: Place a strip of paper slightly wider than the contacts between them. When the AC contactor is closed, if the paper can be easily pulled out, it indicate s that the contact pressure is insufficient; however, if the paper tears, it means the pressure is too high. ④ Severe oxidation and burn damage on the contact surfaces increase con tact resistance, leading to welding of the contacts. If the oxide layer consists of silver oxide, it doesn’t necessarily need to be removed; however, if it’s copper oxide, gently s crape it off using a small knife. For any dirt or grime, clean the surface thoroughly by wiping with a cloth dampened with gasoline or carbon tetrachloride. If the contacts are sco rched or have burrs, carefully reshape the surface using a small knife or a specialized file—but avoid making the surface overly smooth, as excessive smoothness can actually reduce  the contact area between the mating surfaces. Additionally, never use sandpaper to refine the contact surfaces, as this could cause abrasive particles (like diamond grit) to becom e embedded, compromising the contacts’ ability to make proper electrical contact. If the contacts have already fused together, it’s crucial to identify the underlying cause and rep lace the contacts entirely during repairs. (3) The contactor fails to pull in after being energized, or it pulls in but then immediately releases. When an AC contactor fails to eng age after power is applied, first check whether the electromagnetic coil is receiving its rated voltage across its terminals. If no voltage is detected, the fault likely lies withi n the control circuit—inspect and address the issue accordingly based on the specific circuit configuration. If voltage is present but falls below the coil’s rated value, the elect romagnetic force generated by the energized coil won’t be strong enough to overcome the spring’s opposing force; in this case, either replace the electromagnetic coil or modify the  circuit connections. However, if the coil is receiving its rated voltage, further investigation may be needed to identify any underlying problems. The issue could be an open circu it in the electromagnetic coil itself, which can be checked using the resistance setting on a multimeter. If the wiring screws are loose, they should be tightened; if the electroma gnetic coil is broken, it needs to be replaced. Additionally, mechanical mechanisms in the contactor's moving parts, as well as issues like stuck or jammed moving contacts, rusted  pivots, or skewed shafts, could all potentially occur. This results in the contactor coil failing to pull in after being energized, or pulling in improperly. For the former issue,  the mechanical linkage mechanism can be repaired, the arc-extinguishing shield adjusted, and the position of the contacts relative to the shield fine-tuned to eliminate any frictio n between them. In the latter case, a thorough inspection and disassembly are required—clean the pivot shaft and supporting rods, and replace any worn or damaged components as nece ssary. The contactor briefly pulls in and then immediately releases, usually due to poor contact in the auxiliary contacts of the contactor's self-locking circuit, which causes the  circuit's self-locking function to fail. (4) Abnormal contactor engagement. Abnormal contactor engagement refers to issues such as excessively slow contactor operation, incomplete  closure of the contacts, loose core attraction, and unusual noises emanating from the core—none of which are normal. When a contactor fails to engage properly, you can check for t he underlying causes in the following areas and take appropriate corrective actions based on your findings. ① If the control circuit's supply voltage drops below 85% of its rated v alue, the electromagnetic force generated when the solenoid coil is energized will be insufficient to quickly pull the moving iron core toward the stationary iron core, resulting i n slow or incomplete contactor engagement. In this case, you should check the power supply voltage of the control circuit and adjust it to the rated operating voltage as needed. ②  Improper spring pressure can lead to abnormal contactor operation. If the spring's reaction force is too strong, it may cause the contactor to engage excessively slowly. Additional ly, if the spring pressure on the contacts—or the release pressure—is set too high—this can prevent the contacts from closing fully. In such cases, simply adjusting the spring pres sure accordingly, or replacing the spring if necessary, will resolve these issues. ③ The core pole surfaces have expanded outward and become uneven over time due to frequent, prolo nged collisions along the lamination thickness direction, or the short-circuit rings may have broken, causing the core to emit unusual noises. Chapter 5: Fault Diagnosis and Repair  of Electrical Systems 157 (5) After the contactor coil is de-energized, the iron core fails to release. This malfunction poses significant risks, potentially leading to uncontroll ed equipment operation and even causing equipment damage—thus requiring strict preventive measures. The possible causes are outlined below. ① The contactor core pole face was defor med due to impact, causing the gap on the contact surface of the central magnetic pole in the  "mountain " -shaped core to gradually disappear. Failure causes significant residual magnetism in the iron core after the coil is de-energized, leading to the moving iron core sticking firml y to the stationary iron core and preventing the AC contactor from releasing even when power is cut off. To address this issue, you can file and carefully reshape the contact surfa ces of the iron cores, ensuring that the gap between the central magnetic pole and the surrounding areas remains no larger than 0.15 to 0.2 mm. Next, precisely grind the  "mountain "-shaped contact surface on a surface grinder until it’s smooth, while also adjusting the central magnetic pole to sit 0.15 to 0.2 mm lower than the two side magnetic poles. This a pproach effectively prevents the occurrence of this type of malfunction. ② Excessive oil stains and dust buildup on the core pole faces, or insufficient spring pressure in the movi ng contact, can also prevent the AC contactor coil from releasing after power is cut off. For the former issue, simply removing the oil stains will suffice; for the latter, adjust  the spring pressure—and if necessary, replace the spring with a new one. ③ Contactor contact welding can also cause the iron core to fail to release after the AC contactor coil is  de-energized; refer to the methods mentioned earlier for troubleshooting. ④ This type of failure can also occur if installation does not meet requirements, or if the anti-rust oil on the new contactor core surface has not been removed. If the issue stems from improper installation, simply reinstall it correctly; but if anti-rust oil remains stuck to the core surface, simply wipe it clean. 2. DC Contactor DC contactors can be classified according to their application into general industrial DC contactors, traction DC contactors, and high-inductance DC contactors. General industrial DC contactors are commonly used in machine tools and other electromechanical equipment to control various types of DC motors. The common faults of DC contactors are essentially the same as those of AC contactors, so fault analysis can be conducted by referring to the AC contactor failure scenarios described above. 5.5.2 Relay The primary function of a relay is to control, protect, regulate, and transmit signals within electrical circuits or devices. However, its contact capacity is relatively small—typically 5 A or less—meaning relays are not suitable for interrupting heavy loads. This is precisely why relays differ from contactors. The main differences among these devices. Depending on the type of input signal, relays can be classified into temperature relays that operate based on temperature signals, current relays triggered by current signals, pressure relays activated by pressure signals, and speed relays that respond to velocity signals. Various types, including time relays. Below are introduced common methods for diagnosing and repairing these relays.

1. Thermal Relay Electric motors frequently encounter overload conditions during actual operation. If the overload current is not excessive and the duration of the overload is relatively short—such  that the temperature rise in the motor windings remains within permissible limits—then this type of overload is considered acceptable. However, if the overload current is too high  or lasts for an extended period, it can cause the winding temperature to exceed safe levels, leading to insulation damage, reduced motor lifespan, and, in severe cases, even burni ng out the motor windings altogether. To fully utilize the motor's overload capacity while ensuring smooth starting and reliable operation—and to prevent winding overheating and su bsequent burnout—thermal relays are typically employed as overload protection devices for electric motors. The commonly used thermal relay is of the bimetallic strip type, consisti ng primarily of a bimetallic strip, resistance wire (the heating element), and contacts. During operation, the heating element is connected in series with the motor's main circuit,  while the normally closed contacts are串联ed with the contactor coil in the control circuit. When the motor becomes overloaded, the normally closed contacts of the thermal relay ope n, cutting off the motor's control circuit and simultaneously disconnecting the main power supply. To restart the motor, a specific amount of time must elapse—allowing the bimetall ic strip to cool down—before pressing the manual reset button to restore the contacts to their original position. Common faults in thermal relays and their corresponding repair met hods are described below. (1) The thermal relay is not properly connected to the main circuit or control circuit. ① A blown heating element or a desoldered connection at the heatin g element's input/output terminals can cause the thermal relay to fail to conduct when connected to the main circuit. This issue is addressed in the tutorial on diagnosing and repa iring mechanical-electrical system faults. 158 You can use a multimeter to perform continuity tests, or you can open the cover of the thermal relay for a visual inspection—but neve r remove the heating element at will. If the heating element is burned out, it must be replaced with one of the same specifications; and if any wire ends have become detached from  soldering, they should be resoldered securely. ② The setting current adjustment cam (or adjusting screw) has been turned to an improper position, causing the normally closed contac t to open; alternatively, the normally closed contact may have burned out, resulting in an open control circuit when the thermal relay is connected. For the first issue, you can op en the cover of the thermal relay, inspect the cam mechanism responsible for its operation, and adjust it to the correct position. In the second case, you’ll need to replace the co ntact along with the associated spring. ③ The wiring screws in the main or control circuit of the thermal relay were not tightened properly; over time, they loosened, resulting in  an open circuit in either the main or control circuit. Simply check and tighten the wiring screws to resolve the issue. (2) Thermal relay malfunction. Thermal relay malfunction ref ers to the phenomenon where the relay trips even though the motor is not overloaded. ① Since the motor protected by the thermal relay is frequently started, the heating element is  repeatedly subjected to the impact of inrush current. Alternatively, if the motor takes too long to start, the heating element may carry the starting current for an extended period . Both scenarios can lead to false tripping of the thermal relay. For the first case, motor startups should be limited or a semiconductor thermistor temperature relay could be used  instead. In the second scenario, measures can be implemented in the control circuit—such as short-circuiting the thermal relay during startup—to allow the motor to run normally af ter the initial start-up phase. ② An error (tending to be lower) in the thermal relay’s current adjustment scale can lead to false tripping. In this case, follow the steps below fo r proper adjustment: First, turn the current-adjustment cam toward the higher-current setting, then restart the equipment. After the equipment has been running normally for about 1  hour, slowly adjust the current-adjustment cam back toward the lower-current setting until the thermal relay trips. Finally, gently rotate the adjustment cam further toward the hi gher-current side to fine-tune the setting. ③ When the motor load increases dramatically, it can cause excessive current to flow through the heating element. Alternatively, if the  adjusting components of the thermal relay become loose, the set current of the heating element may drop too low, leading to false tripping of the thermal relay. For the first issue , the root cause—such as an overloading motor—should be identified and resolved. For the second scenario, simply remove the cover of the thermal relay, inspect the operating mechan ism and its components, tighten any loose parts, and then readjust the settings accordingly. (3) The motor has burned out, but the thermal relay has not yet tripped. The possible r easons include the following scenarios. ① The thermal relay's adjustment scale may be inaccurate (overestimated), or its adjusting components could have become loose, leading to an excessively high set current. When the  motor operates under overload conditions, although the load current is sufficient to raise the temperature of the heating element and cause the bimetallic strip to bend, it still w on’t generate enough force to move the actuator plate or the temperature-compensating bimetallic strip. As a result, the motor overheats due to prolonged overloading and eventually  burns out. The troubleshooting method is similar to adjusting the thermal relay's scale. Error (underestimation) fault handling is the same. ② The operating mechanism becomes jamm ed, causing the guide plate to disengage; alternatively, if the thermal element is subjected to a short-circuit current, the bimetallic strip may suffer permanent deformation. As a  result, when the motor is overloaded, the relay fails to trip, potentially leading to motor burnout. To address this issue, first open the thermal relay cover, inspect the operati ng mechanism, reinsert the guide plate, and then press the reset button several times to ensure the mechanism moves smoothly. If the bimetallic strip has undergone permanent deform ation, it must be replaced. ③ After maintenance, the thermal relay was inadvertently installed with the bimetallic strip facing the wrong way; alternatively, the wrong heating elem ent for the bimetallic strip was used, causing current to flow through the heating element without enabling the bimetallic strip to push the actuating lever. As a result, the motor  overheated and eventually burned out, yet the thermal relay failed to trip. ④ Damage to the self-cooling fan, blocked air ducts leading to poor heat dissipation, and higher ambien t temperatures can all cause the motor to burn out before the thermal relay even activates. When installing a thermal relay, ensure that the cross-sectional size of the connecting  wires is appropriate. If the wires are too thin, axial heat conduction will be poor, potentially causing the thermal relay to trip prematurely. Conversely, if the connecting wires  are too thick, axial heat conduction will occur rapidly, possibly leading to a delayed response from the thermal relay. Chapter 5: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Electrical Sys tems 159 Action: For thermal relays with a rated current of 10 A, it is recommended to use a single-strand plastic-insulated copper wire with a cross-sectional area of 2.5 mm²; the  rated current For a 20 A thermal relay, it is advisable to use a single-strand plastic-insulated copper wire with a cross-sectional area of 4 mm²; for a thermal relay rated at 60  A, it is recommended to choose Use a 16 mm² multi-strand plastic-insulated copper wire.

2. Speed Relay A speed relay, also known as a reverse-connection braking relay, works in conjunction with a contactor to enable braking of an electric motor. The speed relay consists of three main components: the stator, the rotor, and the contacts. The rotor of the speed relay is a permanent magnet, directly connected to the shaft of the motor being controlled. The stator is fixed to a mounting bracket, constructed from stacked silicon steel laminations and equipped with a squirrel-cage winding. When the motor shaft rotates, the rotor spins along with it, generating a rotating magnetic field within the air gap surrounding the rotor. This induced rotating field, in turn, generates currents within the squirrel-cage winding—currents that increase in magnitude as the rotor speed rises. The magnetic field produced by these induced currents interacts with the rotating magnetic field, creating a torque on the stator that acts in the same direction as the rotor’s rotation. Consequently, the higher the rotor speed, the greater the resulting torque. When the rotor is stationary, the stator remains in a stable central position due to the gravitational force acting on the stator holder. Once the rotor starts rotating, the stator experiences a torque that causes it to turn in the same direction as the rotor. The higher the rotor speed, the greater the clockwise torque exerted on the stator, resulting in a larger rotational angle. After the stator reaches a certain angle, the normally closed contacts open, while the normally open contacts close. When the shaft speed drops close to zero (below 100 r/min), the contacts automatically reset to their original positions. Commonly used speed relays include the JY1 series and the JF20 series. The JY1 series can reliably operate at speeds up to 3600 r/min, whereas the JF20-1 model is suitable for applications with speeds ranging from 300 to 1000 r/min, and the JF20-2 model is designed for speeds between 1000 and 3600 r/min. Typically, the relay resets when the speed drops to around 120 r/min. Common faults, their underlying causes, and recommended repair methods for speed relays are summarized in Table 5.3. Inspection and Maintenance of Low-Voltage Fuses (1) Check whether the fuse indicator is functioning properly, especially after the circuit has experienced an overload or other fault—always inspect the indicator in such cases. To promptly detect single-phase operation conditions. A Case Study Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Electromechanical Systems 160

(2) Inspect the fuse for any cracks or flashover discharge marks, and clean off any accumulated dust from the exterior. (3) Check the fuses for any signs of overheating. If you notice asphalt-like material leaking from the porcelain base (as in the case of RC1A fuses), it indicates either an overload or poor contact at the connections—especially at copper-aluminum joints—as well as inadequate contact between the blade and its socket. Address these issues promptly. (4) Check whether the contact between the fuse element and the blade, between the blade and the blade holder, and between the spiral fuse element itself is good. Poor contact can lead to overheating, resulting in false tripping. (5) After the fuse element of a cartridge-type fuse blows, inspect the inner wall of the steel-paper fuse tube for signs of burning. If the inner wall is burned, arc extinction will no longer be reliable, so the fuse should be replaced promptly with a new one. (6) Verify that the load matches the rated value of the fuse. (7) Check the ambient temperature where the fuse is used; excessively high temperatures can cause false tripping. (8) When a short circuit or severe overload occurs in the circuit or load, the fuse fails to cut off the power supply. In such cases, check whether a copper wire has been blindly substituted for the fuse element. It is strictly prohibited to use copper wire as a substitute for the fuse element. (9) When a fuse melts, do not immediately put the system back into operation after replacing it with a new one. Instead, first analyze the cause of the fuse failure, identify and repair the underlying fault before resuming operation. Otherwise, there is a risk of damaging electrical equipment and even causing arc flash incidents that could injure personnel. (10) Install the fuse correctly, avoiding mechanical damage and excessive tension that could reduce the cross-sectional area of the fuse, leading to false tripping. There are 3 types of melt fracture conditions, as sh own in Figure 5.6. As shown in Figure 5.6(a), the fracture occurs near the crimping screw, with a relatively small fracture surface. Often, discoloration of the screw can be observ ed, accompanied by the formation of a black oxide layer. This is typically caused by either loose crimping, a loosened screw, or a rusted and seized screw. To address this issue, c lean the screw and washer thoroughly, replace both the screw and washer, and then reinstall the new molten material securely. As shown in Figure 5.6(b), the exposed portion of the  fuse has almost entirely undergone explosive melting, with only the screw-pressed area remaining intact. This phenomenon occurs because the short-circuiting high current generates  an enormous amount of heat in a very brief period, leading to the explosive melting of the fuse element. To address this, check the wiring, load-bearing electrical equipment, and o ther components to identify and eliminate any shorts. Waypoint. Before the fault is resolved, never blindly increase the current rating of the fuse to prevent the accident from esc alating. As shown in Figure 5.6(c), a smaller fracture forms in the middle of the melt. This is This was caused by the current flowing through the fuse element exceeding its rated  current for an extended period. Since the heat at both ends of the fuse can dissipate via the crimping screws, while the heat in the middle section accumulates more rapidly—eventua lly leading to the fuse blowing—it can be concluded that the issue stems from either an overloaded circuit or selecting a fuse with too low a rating. In response, the cause of the  overload should be identified, and an appropriately sized fuse should be chosen. Melt, reattach.

5.5.4 Control Devices Main command devices include buttons, limit switches, master controllers, and more. These devices control the operation of other electrical equipment by opening or closing circuits, effectively "issuing" commands for electrical control. By using main command devices, it’s possible to perform operations on control circuits as well as implement sequential control. Common faults and repair methods for each type of main command device are outlined below. 1. Button

Common button malfunctions and repair methods are as follows. (1) A tingling sensation is felt when pressing the start button. ① The button's protective metal casing is in contact with the energized connecting wires; simply check the internal wire connections and remove any short circuit caused by the contact with the casing. ② On metal cutting machine tools, iron chips or metal powder can get lodged between the button cap and its surrounding gaps, creating an electrical path that leads to a tingling or electric shock sensation. To eliminate this issue, regularly clean the area, or install a plastic film cover over the buttons to prevent metal debris from entering. (2) The circuit must not be disconnected when the stop button is pressed. Typically, this occurs because the normally open contact of the stop button has developed an abnormal short circuit—meaning that whether the stop button is pressed or not, the contacts remain connected, naturally preventing the circuit from breaking. This abnormal short circuit arises due to two main factors: ① metal shavings or oil The dirty short has bridged the normally open contact; simply clean it off to remove the issue. ② The bakelite in the button box is burnt and carbonized, causing a short circuit in the normally open contact. (3) When the stop button is pressed and then the start button, the controlled appliance does not operate. Typically, this is caused by a damaged reset spring in the stop button, which prevents the normally closed contact from returning to its original position after the stop button is pressed, leaving it permanently open and causing the control circuit to lose power. This issue can be resolved by simply replacing the reset spring. Additionally, oxidation of the normally open contact on the start button—leading to poor electrical contact—can also result in the same malfunction. Figure 5.6: Case Study Tutorial on Electromechanical System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Melt-Blown Systems

2. Limit Switch A limit switch, also known as a position switch or travel switch, operates its contacts not by direct manual manipulation but through the collision of moving mechanical components.  As a result, a limit switch is a switching device that converts mechanical travel signals into electrical signals, making it widely used in sequence controllers as well as automat ed systems designed for motion direction, stroke control, positioning, limit detection, and safety applications. Common faults associated with limit switches are described below. ( 1) If the limit switch is triggered, the equipment will operate uncontrollably. This type of failure poses significant risks, as it prevents the limit switch from properly controll ing travel and positioning, potentially leading to accidents such as personal injury or equipment damage. To address this issue, troubleshooting can be approached from several angl es: ① Poor contact at the switch contacts is a common cause of malfunction during normal operation. Regular inspection and cleaning of the limit switch are essential to ensure its con tacts maintain optimal connectivity. ② The limit switch or stop block itself may be improperly installed; alternatively, frequent operational impacts could have loosened and shifte d the mounting screws of the limit switch or stop block. As a result, even when the switch roller (or actuating post) comes into contact with the limit switch, it fails to effectiv ely push the contacts into their intended positions—either fully on or off. In such cases, the position of the limit switch or stop block should be adjusted, and the mounting screw s must be securely tightened. ③ The contact wire is loose—check and tighten the loose connection. (2) After the limit switch is reset, the normally closed contact fails to close. I f this fault occurs, promptly remove the limit switch and begin your inspection from the following aspects. ① If the reset spring of the normally open contact has weakened or is bl ocked by debris, replace the spring or remove the obstruction. ② The normally open contact is skewed or has come loose. Such misalignment or detachment typically occurs when the li mit switch is installed too close to the impact block, leading to excessive pushing force during collisions. Therefore, when troubleshooting this issue, be sure to adjust the insta llation position of the limit switch appropriately. (3) The lever has already tilted, but the contact point remains inactive. This issue typically occurs because the limit switch i s installed too low; to resolve this, you can either add a shim beneath the limit switch base or raise its installation position. Additionally, mechanical jamming inside the limit  switch itself can also lead to the failure. In such cases, inspect and clean the switch thoroughly, reassemble and adjust it properly, and apply a small amount of machine oil to th e moving pivot points to ensure smooth operation and eliminate any mechanical obstructions. 5.6 Sensor Fault Diagnosis

Modern mechanical manufacturing systems are characterized by  their large-scale control, high levels of automation, and strong flexibility. As the structure of these manufacturing systems becomes increasingly complex, demands for cost control  and production continuity continue to rise—making any downtime caused by various types of failures an unacceptable burden. Consequently, fault diagnosis systems have seen rapid ad vancements, with technologies now including the use of advanced sensors to capture diverse physical parameters during processes, enabling seamless signal transmission and processin g. By analyzing these processed signals, operators can monitor the operational status of production equipment and assess product quality in real time, while also predicting future  trends, diagnosing faults, and triggering timely alerts. Currently, fault analysis methods used in mechanical production systems can be applied to automated production lines, CNC machine tools, flexible manufacturing cells, and even larger systems such as computer-integrated manufacturing systems. Automated production lines are far more complex than individual pieces of equipment, making it challenging to quickly pinpoint the root cause and exact location of a problem. To enhance overall system efficiency, in addition to improving equipment reliability, it is often essential—under certain conditions—to introduce advanced fault diagnosis systems into automated production lines. 1. Errors Introduced by the Sensor Sensor-generated errors can be categorized into five basic types: insertion error, application error, characteristic error, and dynamic error. Chapter 5: Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Electrical Systems 163 Difference and environmental error. (1) Insertion error. It occurs when a sensor is inserted into the system, causing errors due to changes in the measured parameters. This kind of issue typically arises during electronic measurements, but similar problems can also occur in other types of measurements. (2) Application error. This is caused by the operator and can arise from various factors. For instance, it may occur during temperature measurements. Errors include incorrect probe placement or improper insulation between the probe and the measurement point. Additionally, some application errors arise during the purification process of air or other gases. Application errors also involve misplacement of the transmitter, which can lead to inaccurate readings due to either positive or negative pressure affecting the measurement. (3) Characteristic error. This is inherent to the device itself and represents the discrepancy between the device’s ideal, well-established transfer function characteristics and its actual performance. Such errors include DC drift values (e.g., incorrect pressure head). (4) Dynamic Error. Many sensors exhibit strong damping, which prevents them from responding quickly to changes in input parameters. For instance, a thermistor may take several seconds to react to a step change in temperature, meaning it won’t instantly jump to a new impedance or produce an abrupt shift. Instead, it gradually adjusts to the new value over time. If a sensor with inherent delay characteristics attempts to respond rapidly to a sudden temperature change, the resulting output waveform will become distorted, as it will include dynamic error. Factors contributing to dynamic error include response time, amplitude distortion, and phase distortion. (5) Environmental errors. These arise from the environment in which the sensor is used and include factors such as temperature, sway, vibration, altitude, chemical vaporization, or other influences. Such factors often affect the sensor's performance, which is why, in practical applications, they are typically categorized and addressed collectively.
2. Interference During Sensor Operation and Corresponding Mitigation Measures

1) Anti-Interference Design for Power Supply Systems The most severe threat to the normal operation of sensors comes from power grid spike pulse interference. Devices that generate these spikes include electric welders, large electri c motors, variable-frequency drives, relay contactors, and even items like electric soldering irons. Spike interference can be effectively suppressed using a combination of hardwar e and software solutions. (1) Use hardware circuits to suppress spike interference. Common methods include the following three approaches: ① Insert an interference controller in series at the AC power input of the instrument; ② Install a super-isolation transformer at the AC power input of the instrument, leveraging the principle of ferromagnetic resonance to dampen spike pulses; ③ Connect a varistor in parallel at the AC power input of the instrument, utilizing the property that its resistance decreases sharply when spike pulses arrive, thereby reducing t he voltage drawn by the instrument from the power supply and mitigating the impact of interference. (2) Suppress spike interference using software methods. For periodic interferenc e, programming-based time filtering can be employed to effectively eliminate the disturbance. (3) Employ a hardware-and-software combined watchdog technology to suppress the effect s of spike pulses. (4) Implement grouped power supply systems. For example, separate the power supply for driving electric motors from the control power supply to prevent interfere nce between devices. (5) Using a noise filter can also effectively suppress interference from the AC servo drive to other equipment. (6) Use an isolation transformer to enhance imm unity against common-mode interference. (7) Employ a power supply with high anti-interference performance, such as a high-anti-interference power supply designed using the spectrum  equalization method. 2) Anti-Interference Design for Signal Transmission Channels (1) Optoelectronic coupling isolation measures. During long-distance transmission, using optocoup lers can break the electrical connection between the control system and the input/output channels, as well as between the servo driver's input/output circuits. The primary advantag e of optoelectronic coupling is its ability to effectively suppress spike pulses and various noise interferences, significantly improving the signal-to-noise ratio during signal tr ansmission. Despite these interference noises, this technique is invaluable in fault diagnosis and maintenance case studies for electromechanical systems. 164 However, it has a lar ge voltage amplitude but very little energy, resulting in only a weak current. Meanwhile, the light-emitting diode in the input section of the optocoupler operates in a current-dri ven mode, typically requiring a forward current of 10–15 mA. Therefore, even if there are significant interference signals, they will be effectively suppressed because they cannot  provide sufficient current to overcome the system's inherent limitations. (2) Twisted-shielded cable transmission. During transmission, signals are susceptible to interference from factors such as electric fields, magnetic fields, and ground impedance. Using a grounded shielded cable can effectively reduce the impact of electric-field interference. Compared to coaxial cables, twisted-shielded cables have a narrower frequency bandwidth but offer higher wave impedance and superior immunity to common-mode noise, enabling electromagnetic induction interference across individual segments to cancel each other out. Additionally, differential signal transmission is typically employed for long-distance communication, further enhancing the system's resistance to external interference. 3) Elimination of Locally Generated Errors In low-level measurements, careful attention must be paid to the materials used—or incorporated—within the signal path. Even in simple circuits, components like solder, wires, and terminal blocks can introduce significant thermoelectric effects due to temperature differences. Since thermoelectric voltages often occur in pairs, it’s highly effective to ensure that these paired thermocouples remain at the same temperature. To achieve this, techniques such as thermal shielding, arranging heat sinks along isothermal lines, or separating high-power and low-power circuits are commonly employed—each aimed at minimizing thermal gradients. While connectors, sockets, and relays offer convenience for easily swapping electrical components or modules, they also come with drawbacks: they can introduce contact resistance, thermoelectric voltages, or both. As a result, these compromises often lead to reduced stability in low-level resolution—meaning the system becomes less precise, more prone to noise, and less reliable compared to directly connected setups. Therefore, in low-level amplification circuits, it’s crucial to avoid using switches, connectors, and similar elements whenever possible. This practice is one of the most important strategies for minimizing failures and enhancing measurement accuracy. 3. Common Transmitter Faults and Their Causes
