Figure 6.15: Diagram of PLC Output Port Status

Figure 6.16: Diagram of PLC Input Port Status Step 3: Use a multimeter to check the signal status of sensor SE5V (which functions to detect whether the pneumatic finger is closed). The voltage measured between terminals 1 and 3 was 24 V DC, indicating that the sensor’s power supply is functioning properly. Next, measure the voltage between terminals 1 and 4. 0 V, meaning the voltage at the sensor signal output is 0 V, resulting in no output signal (as shown in Figure 6.17). Figure 6.17: Detection Sensor SE5V Signal Conclusion: Based on the system's actual operation, the pneumatic finger has successfully completed the gripping action of the part. However, the SE5V sensor failed to detect this completed motion and did not send a status signal to the controller. Therefore, it is determined that the SE5V sensor has malfunctioned. 3. Solution
Turn off the main power switch and replace the sensor with one of the same model. Expanding Knowledge: Connecting Proximity Switches with PLCs

PLC Digital Input Circuit The PLC digital input circuit is divided into DC input circuits (source-type input, sink-type input, and hybrid-type input) and AC input circuits. Enter the circuit. As shown in Figure 6.18, the DC input circuit works as follows: When the external switch is closed, the PLC's internal optocoupler's LED lights up, causing the phototransistor to saturate and conduct fully. This conduction signal is then transmitted to the processor, enabling the CPU to recognize that a signal has been input on this channel. Meanwhile, when the external... When the switch is open, the LED in the optocoupler turns off, the phototransistor cuts off, and the CPU detects no signal on that channel. Chapter 6: Simulation Software for Fault Diagnosis of Electromechanical Systems and Case Studies 191

Figure 6.18 DC Input Circuit The AC input circuit is shown in Figure 6.19. As you can see, the main difference from the DC input circuit is the addition of a rectification stage. The typical input voltage for AC input is 220 V AC. After passing through resistor R to limit the current and capacitor C for isolation (which removes the DC component from the power supply), the AC signal is converted into DC via a bridge rectifier. After this step, the circuit operates on the same principle as a DC input circuit. Figure 6.19: AC Input Circuit From the analysis above, it can be seen that because the AC input circuit incorporates three additional stages—current limiting, isolation, and rectification—the delay time of the input signal is longer compared to a DC input circuit, which is its main drawback. However, since the input end operates at high voltage, the reliability of the input signal is significantly higher than in DC circuits. Typically, AC input methods are used in harsh environments characterized by oil mist, dust, or other challenging conditions where high response times are not critical. In contrast, DC input methods are preferred for cleaner environments with minimal electromagnetic interference and applications that demand faster response speeds. To illustrate this, let’s examine Mitsubishi PLC manufacturers’ definitions of sink and source configurations. 1) Open-collector input circuit The leakage-type input circuit is shown in Figure 6.20, where current flows into the PLC common terminal (COM terminal) and out from the input terminal—meaning the PLC common terminal is connected to the positive pole of an external DC power supply. 2) Source-type input circuit The circuit shown in Figure 6.18 is also a source-type input circuit. In this case, the current flows in the exact opposite direction compared to a sink-type circuit. In a source-type input circuit, current flows into the PLC's input terminal and out through the common terminal—meaning the common terminal is connected to the negative pole of the external power supply. Case Study Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Mechatronic Systems

192 Figure 6.20: Common-Collector Input Circuit 3) Hybrid Input Circuit Because this type of PLC input terminal and common terminal can both source and sink current—meaning the PLC common terminal can be connected to either the positive or negative terminal of an external power supply—it simultaneously exhibits characteristics of both source-type and sink-type input circuits. Therefore, this type of input circuit is referred to as a hybrid input circuit. Its circuit configuration is illustrated in Figure 6.21. Figure 6.21: Hybrid Input Circuit When used as a source-type input, connect the negative terminal of the power supply to the common terminal; when used as a sink-type input, connect the positive terminal of the power supply to the common terminal. This allows wiring according to site-specific requirements, making the wiring process more flexible. It should be noted here that Mitsubishi and Siemens have exactly opposite definitions for source-type and sink-type input circuits. The explanation above follows Mitsubishi's classification method, so please keep this distinction in mind when using the system. 2. Connecting External Digital Signals to the PLC In addition to dry-contact signals like those from buttons, PLCs now also accept NPN and PNP collector-open output signals from certain sensors. Connecting dry contacts to the PLC input module is straightforward, so we won’t go into detail here. However, when it comes to choosing between NPN or PNP sensors for different PLC input circuits, users sometimes find themselves unsure of which to select. Below, we’ll explain how these two types of sensors connect to PLC input circuits. The configurations of NPN and PNP output circuits As shown in Figure 6.22, the output terminal OUT of the NPN collector-open circuit is connected to 0V through a switching transistor. When the sensor activates, the switching transistor saturates and turns on fully, connecting the OUT terminal directly to 0V and generating a low-level 0V signal at the output. The PNP collector… The output terminal OUT of the open-circuit output circuit is connected to +V through a switching transistor. When the sensor activates, the switching transistor saturates and turns on, connecting OUT directly to +V and generating a high-level +V signal at the output. Chapter 6: Simulation Software for Fault Diagnosis in Mechatronic Systems and Case Studies

193 Figure 6.22 NPN open-collector output and PNP open-collector output Connecting NPN and PNP output circuits to PLC input modules (1) NPN collector-open output. From the above analysis, it is clear that the NPN collector-open output is at 0 V. When the output terminal OUT is connected to the PLC input, current flows from… The input from the PLC flows out and returns to the PLC's common terminal—this is known as the PLC's sink-type circuit configuration, specifically: NPN collector open-collector. PLCs accepting only sink-type (where the common terminal connects to the positive side of an external power supply) or mixed-type input circuit configurations, as shown in Figure 6.23. Figure 6.23: NPN Collector-Open Output and PLC Connection (2) PNP collector open-collector output. The PNP collector-open output provides a +V high level; when the output terminal OUT is connected to the PLC input, current flows into the PLC input and out through the PLC's common terminal. This configuration represents the PLC's source-type circuit form—specifically, the PNP collector-open output can only be connected to PLCs with either a source-type (where the common terminal is tied to the negative side of an external power supply) or a mixed-type input circuit, as illustrated in Figure 6.24. Figure 6.24: Connection Between PNP Collector-Open Output and PLC – A Case Study on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Mechatronic Systems 194 Precisely because of the diversity in PLC input module circuit configurations and the variety of output signals from external sensors, it is essential to thoroughly understand the type of PLC input circuit and the format of the sensor's output signal before wiring the PLC input module. 6.5 Case Study on Electrical System Motor Failures

Fault Description Guide rail 1 moves left to the blank part (Step 1), guide rail 2 extends outward (Step 2), the pneumatic gripper closes to pick up the part (Step 3), guide rail 2 retracts (Step 4), guide rail 1 moves right to the pre-compression cylinder position (Step 5), and finally, guide rail 2 extends again to the pre… Press position (Step 6), pneumatic finger opens (Step 7), guide rail 2 retracts to its original position and stops (Step 8), pre-pressure cylinder remains… There are protruding stamped parts. Step 8 is completed, but Step 9 has not been executed.

Analysis and Testing Process As the system's control core, the PLC can determine whether a fault occurs in the electrical system's input or output section by monitoring the status of its input/output ports, according to System Workflow Table 6.1. By referring to Table 6.1 along with Figures 6.25 and 6.26, proceed to Step 9: The PLC should output Q5.1 to energize the solenoid directional control valve coil YH3V. Figure 6.25: Wiring Diagram of Solenoid Valve Coil to PLC Output Port Step 1: Observe the status of the PLC's corresponding output port (Q5.1). If Q5.1 is detected as "1," it indicates that the controller has already sent the control signal to execute the action in Step 9—but this action has not been carried out. This strongly suggests that the fault lies either in the output section of the control system (the actuator) or in the hydraulic system. Step 2: Use a multimeter to measure the voltage across the 3V1 solenoid valve coil YH3V. The measured coil voltage is 24 V (as shown in Figure 6.27). Based on Steps 1 and 2, it can be determined that the electrical control section of the solenoid directional control valve is functioning properly with no faults. Now, let’s move on to the analysis.

Hydraulic system. Step 3: As shown in Figure 6.28, use a pressure gauge to check the pump's outlet pressure. The measurement indicates an outlet pressure of 0 MPa, strongly suggesting either a hydraulic pump motor failure or a fault in the motor control circuit (motor is not running). Chapter 6: Simulation Software and Case Studies for Fault Diagnosis in Mechatronic Systems Figure 6.26: Hydraulic System Circuit Diagram

Figure 6.27: Measuring the Coil Voltage of the Solenoid Valve Figure 6.28: Monitoring the Pump Outlet Pressure Step 4: The electrical control diagram for the hydraulic pump motor is shown in Figure 6.29. Measure the lines between the motor’s three-phase windings. Voltage measurements show 400 VAC between windings 1 and 2 (normal), and 400 V AC between windings 1 and 3 (normal). Between groups 2 and 3 is 400 V AC (normal). Conclusion: By measuring the voltage across each phase winding of the three-phase motor and finding that all phase voltages are within normal limits, we can conclude that the internal windings of the hydraulic pump motor have likely burned out and become open-circuited, or that some other motor fault has occurred. 3. Solution

Disconnect the main power switch, repair the motor, or replace it with a motor of the same specifications. 1. Fault Description Rail 1 is moved to the blank part (Step 1), rail 2 extends (Step 2), and the pneumatic gripper remains open (Step 3)—meaning Step 2 has been completed, while Step 3 is still pending. 2. Analysis and Testing Process According to system workflow table 6.1, to perform step 3, the PLC should output Q5.6 to control the solenoid valve coil. YP5V, which actuates the valve spool to drive the pneumati c finger into a closed position. The pneumatic circuit diagram for the pneumatic finger (gripper) is shown in Figure 6.33. Under normal circumstances, PLC output Q5.6 energizes YP5 V, activating the solenoid valve in its left position. Compressed air flows from port 2 through the throttle valve 5V3 and enters the rod-side chamber of cylinder 5A, causing the c ylinder piston rod to retract and closing the pneumatic gripper. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial

Step 1: Observe the status of the PLC's corresponding output port (Q5.6); the measurement shows that Q5 .6 is in state  "1 ". Step 2: Use a multimeter to measure the voltage across the solenoid coil YP5V. The measured coil voltage is 24V. Based on Steps 1 and 2, it can be determined that the electrical  system is functioning properly with no faults. Now, let’s move on to analyzing the pneumatic system. Step 3: According to Figure 6.34, measure the pressure at the air port B of so lenoid valve 5V1. If the readings for air port P and air port B are both 6 bar (as shown in Figure 6.34), this indicates that the solenoid valve is functioning properly. Figure 6.3 3: Pneumatic Finger Pneumatic Circuit Diagram Figure 6.34: Pressure of the 5V1 Solenoid Valve Step 4: Measure the pressure at cylinder port 5A. The reading shows 6 bar at port B and also 6 bar at port A. Normally, when the cy linder retracts, port A acts as the exhaust port, and its pressure should be lower than 6 bar—ideally close to 0 bar. Step 5: Further measure the pressure at the 5V2 one-way thrott le valve’s air ports—specifically, the inlet port A reads 6 bar, while the exhaust port B shows 0 bar, as illustrated in Figure 6.35. Figure 6.35: Monitoring the Pressure of Thrott le Valve 5V2 Conclusion: When the cylinder retracts, the function of the 5V2 one-way throttle valve is to regulate the retraction speed of the cylinder. This process involves exhau st throttling. Measurements show that the inlet port A reads 6 bar, while the exhaust port B registers 0 bar, indicating that the 5V2 throttle valve is fully closed and not allowin g airflow. 3. Solution

Adjust the throttle valve from 5V2 to the appropriate opening to ensure the pneumatic finger picks up the part at the right speed. Chapter 6: Simulation Software for Electromechanical System Fault Diagnosis and Case Studies 199

Security This industrial robot complies with current safety technical standards. However, violating these regulations could result in personal injury, damage to the robot, or other  equipment. Use is permitted only when the industrial robot is in perfect working condition, strictly adheres to all regulations, and operators maintain a strong safety awareness.  To ensure that any safety-related faults are promptly addressed, always follow the instructions outlined in this manual when operating the robot. Huashu Robotics Co., Ltd. is commi tted to providing reliable safety information but assumes no responsibility for it. Even when all operations are carried out strictly according to the safety instructions, there is  still no guarantee that the robot will not cause personal injury or property damage. 1.1 Instructions for the Safe Use of Robots Before installation, operation, maintenance, or ma jor repairs, be sure to familiarize yourself with this book and other accompanying documents, and use the product correctly. Please thoroughly review the equipment guidelines, safe ty information, and all relevant precautions before using the product. 1.1.1 Safety Precautions During Adjustment, Operation, Maintenance, and Related Processes (1) Operators shoul d wear work uniforms, safety helmets, safety shoes, and other appropriate protective gear. (2) Before powering on, ensure there are no operators within the robot's operational rang e. (3) When the robot is in automatic mode, no personnel are allowed to enter the robot's operating area. (4) Operators must disconnect the power supply before entering the robot's  operational area. Additionally, they should carry the teach pendant at all times to prevent unauthorized or accidental operation by others. (5) Whenever live electrical work such  as repairs or maintenance is required, two people should operate together: one person should always be ready to press the emergency stop button. One person operates the button, whi le the other carefully and swiftly carries out the task within the robot's operational range. Additionally, the retracing path must be confirmed before starting the作业. (6) The load  on the wrist and robotic arm must be kept within the allowable capacity range. Failure to comply with the permitted load limits may result in abnormal movement of mechanical compo nents or premature damage. (7) Use a carbon dioxide fire extinguisher in case of fire. (8) The emergency stop button must not be short-circuited. (9) Please read the instructions i n the  "Precautions " section of the  "Mechanical Operation and Maintenance Manual. " (10) Do not disassemble or operate any components not mentioned in the service manual. The robot is equipped with multiple self-diagnosis and anomaly detection features, allowing  it to safely shut down in case of an abnormality. Nevertheless, accidents caused by the robot still occur from time to time. These conditions are commonly found in robot accidents : (1) Perform automatic operation, ensuring no one is within the robot's range of motion. (2) After entering the robot's motion range for automatic operation mode, the robot unexpe ctedly moved.

(3) Focus only on the robot ahead, ignoring all other robots. All of the above incidents were caused by  "neglecting safety procedures, "  "failing to anticipate the robot's sudden movements, " and other similar reasons. In other words, these accidents were triggered by unsafe behaviors such as  "lack of concentration " and  "failure to follow operational protocols. "  "Emergency situations " can easily lead to serious accidents, as their sudden nature leaves operators with insufficient time to press the  "emergency stop " or  "evacuation " button. Typically,  "emergency situations " encompass the following scenarios: (1) A slow motion suddenly transitions into high speed.
(2) Operated by other carriers. (3) Another program was launched due to peripheral devi ce anomalies and software errors. (4) Abnormal actions caused by noise, malfunctions, defects, and the like.

(5) Misoperation. (6) I had planned to perform the action at a low spee d, but ended up completing it at high speed instead. (7) The robot-carried workpiece fell and scattered all over the floor. (8) When the workpiece is clamped, the robot loses contr ol and enters an interlocked standby stop state. (9) The robot located next to or behind this robot performs the action. The examples above are just a few; in reality, "emergencies" can take many different forms. In most cases, people simply cannot "stop" or "avoid" these robots in the midst of sudden operations, so it’s crucial to immediately implement the following countermeasures to prevent such incidents from occurring. Attention: No approaching the robot. When the robot is not in use, ensure it cannot operate by pressing the "Emergency Stop" button or disconnecting the power supply. During robot operation, please assign a third-party monitoring personnel who can immediately press the emergency stop button to ensure safety. The robot must operate under the condition that the emergency stop button can be pressed at any time during operation. To comply with these principles, the latter's preventive measures must be thoroughly understood and strictly followed. 1.1.2 Safety Measures for the Robot Body When designing robots, unnecessary protrusions or sharp components should be eliminated, materials suitable for the working environment should be selected, and fail-safe protective structures should be incorporated to ensure the robot remains durable and prevents accidents during operation. Additionally, to ensure safety, robots should be equipped with malfunction detection and shutdown features, as well as an emergency stop function, while also incorporating interlock mechanisms to prevent risks triggered by peripheral equipment. When safety features or protective devices are turned off or removed, the robot must not operate. When installing the included machine onto the end effector or robotic arm, strictly follow this manual and use the bolts specified in the manual—both in terms of type and quantity. Be sure to tighten them using a torque wrench to the exact torque setting provided. Additionally, rusted or dirty bolts should not be used. Failure to tighten according to the specified or improper methods will lead to bolt loosening, which could subsequently cause a serious accident. When designing and manufacturing end effectors, ensure that the relevant data complies with the allowable load values of the robot wrist components. Adopt a fail-safe protection mechanism to ensure that, in the event of a power or compressed air supply failure at the end effector, the gripped object will neither be released nor drop. Additionally, pay attention to edges and protruding parts to prevent injury to personnel or damage to items. Providing power sources, compressed air, or welding cooling water that do not meet specifications is strictly prohibited, as this can compromise equipment performance, lead to abnormal operations, and even trigger dangerous situations such as malfunctions or damage. Although electromagnetic interference depends on its type or intensity, current technology still lacks effective countermeasures. When operating or powering up the robot, please follow the safety guidelines carefully. Additionally, recorded data may be lost due to factors such as electromagnetic interference, other types of noise, or substrate defects. Therefore, please back up the program or constants to an external storage medium, such as a CompactFlash card. In large systems where multiple operators work simultaneously, operators should use gestures—or other polite communication methods—to accurately convey their true intentions when needing to interact over long distances. Noise and other environmental factors can undermine communication effectiveness and even lead to accidents. Industrial robot gestures (example) Operators should always be prepared to evacuate from hazards during the work process. This way, they can escape danger in an emergency. Always focused on the robot's movements, unable to re-engage with the robot. Delayed responses from robots can also lead to accidents. In case of an emergency, please immediately press the emergency stop button. This clause must always be strictly adhered to. Based on the site conditions and operational tasks, prepare job procedures and checklists covering robot startup methods, operating instructions, and troubleshooting steps, and ensure strict adherence to these procedures during execution. Relying solely on operators' memory or experience for operations will lead to accidents due to their forgetfulness and mistakes. When the robot doesn't need to move or perform any actions, please disconnect the power supply to continue operation. Before teaching, confirm the number of procedures or steps, then proceed with the operation.

Incorrectly editing the program or steps will lead to accidents. Use the storage protection feature to safeguard completed programs against accidental editing. After completing the teaching operation, manually check the robot's status at low speed. If the robot is immediately operated in automatic mode at 100% speed, factors such as program errors could lead to accidents. After the teaching operation is completed, cleaning should be carried out immediately, and ensure that all tools have been put away. Any oil spills or leftover tools in the work area can easily lead to safety hazards such as slips and falls. Ensure safety during the cleaning process. Please secure the robotic arm before removing the motor. Please secure the robotic arm before removing the motor. 1.2 Transporting, transferring, or selling the robot Unless the original sales contract includes specific provisions, safety-related terms will not be inherited by the new recipient when the robot is transported, transferred, or sold overseas. The original customer should sign a new contract with the new successor. When transporting, transferring, or selling this robot, please ensure that the operation manual, maintenance guide, and any other relevant documents included with the device are also handed over to the new user. Customers are responsible for preparing operation and maintenance manuals in the appropriate language, as well as changing the display language, when shipping, transferring, or exporting robots to foreign countries—and must also ensure compliance with local laws and regulations. New users, without reading the operation manual, may perform improper or unsafe actions, potentially leading to accidents. 1.3 Abandoned Robots Do not disassemble, heat, or incinerate the batteries used in control devices and the robot body, as this may cause fire, rupture, or combustion. After disassembly, do not discard the control unit's baseplate and components directly, as sharp edges from cracks, cuts, or other damaged areas, along with exposed wires, could cause injury. Please remove the cables and external circuit wires from the connectors and junction boxes, then discard them directly—no further disassembly is required. Otherwise, operators could risk cuts to their hands or eyes from sharp conductors or other objects. Please exercise caution during the disposal process to avoid pinching or getting injured. Discarded items should be disposed of safely. To prevent environmental pollution, waste materials such as used batteries and waste oils should be properly managed according to local environmental regulations. 2 Basic Instructions

2.4 Handling and Storage This section outlines the unpacking, handling, and associated precautions for the robot; in principle, cranes or forklifts should be used for robot transportation. During the transport and storage of the HSR-JR615-2000/HSR-JR620-1800/HSR-JR630-1800 industrial robots, it’s essential to take appropriate preventive measures: ensure that the temperature in the transport and storage environment remains between -25°C and 55°C, while also allowing for short-term exposure (no longer than 24 hours) to extreme temperatures up to 70°C. To prevent damage to electrical components, make sure to implement proper moisture protection and avoid severe impacts, vibrations, shocks, and rough handling during transit. 2.4.1 Unboxing

Upon receipt, please inspect the package contents and ensure the parcel is undamaged. Please carefully open the packaging to ensure the robot remains undamaged. After unpacking, do not forcefully bend, hang, or sit on the robot. Once the box is opened, remove the securing screws from the robot’s base—be sure to hold the robot firmly to keep it balanced and prevent it from falling. Please do not pull, hang from, or sit on the robot. The robot should remove the transport support frame before activating its mobility features. 2.4.2 Handling Method The lifting weight is approximately 280 kg (excluding peripherals, handling fixtures, and pallets). Please select a forklift or crane with sufficient load capacity, and ensure it is equipped with lifting slings of adequate strength. When operating the robot, be sure to avoid subjecting it to excessive shock and vibration. When moving robots using a forklift or crane, remove obstacles and other hindrances beforehand to ensure the robot is safely transported to its installation location. When handling robots using a crane or forklift, it is strictly prohibited to support the robot body directly with your hands. Please assign qualified personnel to perform lifting, crane operations, forklift driving, and other material-handling tasks. Operating without proper certification could lead to severe injuries or significant damage, posing an extremely high risk. When lifting the robot, please support it with your hands to maintain balance. If the robot falls due to unstable handling, it could result in serious injury or significant damage—extremely dangerous. When using the portable fixing device, be sure to remove it after use. When using the threaded holes installed with the handling fixture to mount other auxiliary equipment, the robot's range of motion will be limited—please ensure you carefully consider the actual operating conditions. In principle, cranes or forklifts should be used to move the robot. Before lifting with a forklift, the robot and its baseplate (pallet) must be secured, including using any provided fixing screws and inserting spring washers if necessary. Before the forklift begins moving, refer to Table 2.3 for the robot’s correct handling posture; specific details can be found in Figures 2.11 through 2.12. Table 2.3: Robot Pose During the Processing Procedure When using a crane for lifting, first adjust the robot's position (refer to Figure 2.3), then secure four M16 eye bolts at the robot base and one M10 eye bolt at the motor base. Additionally, protect the wire rope connection point between the robot and the crane with rubber hoses and foam blocks. Please note that the wire rope must never be connected to the motor or pipeline components—see Figure 2.11 for details. During lifting, always ensure the robot’s center of gravity remains above its midpoint; otherwise, imbalance could cause the robot to tip over. 2.5 Installation Set up a safety fence for robot operations, otherwise accidents such as physical injuries or equipment damage could occur. It is strictly prohibited to power on or operate the robo t when it is not securely stabilized, as this could lead to equipment tipping over, personal injury, and damage to the device. Please ensure that the ceiling or wall can support su fficient weight before mounting the robot upside down or on the wall. Additionally, consider implementing measures to prevent the robot from falling, thereby avoiding potential acc idents such as injuries to personnel or damage to equipment. Do not install or operate robots with damaged or missing components. After completing the setup, be sure to remove all  related accessories and tools from the robot, and stay outside the robot's maximum operating range before powering it on for the first time. 2.5.1 Safety Switch According to Articl e 5.4,  "Robot Motion Restrictions, " of GB11291.2-2013, the National Standard of the People's Republic of China titled  "Safety Requirements for Industrial Robots—Part 2: Robot Systems and Integration, " it is stipulated that  "the design and integration of robotic equipment should minimize the potential exposure of personnel to hazards. " Specifically, 5.4.2 emphasizes the need to establish a safety protection zone and carefully limit its scope, stating:  "A safety protection zone must be defined through perimeter safeguarding measures. When designing this zone, full consideration should be given to the robot’s installation location  and layout, as well as all types of hazardous sources present within the safety area. " Additionally, 5.5.2 further clarifies the requirements for intervention pathways:  "For tasks requiring manual high-speed operation, the minimum clear distance provided must be no less than 0.5 meters. " Finally, Article 5.10 on safety protection specifies:  "When hazards cannot be completely eliminated by design or are insufficiently mitigated, appropriate safety protection measures must be implemented. Personnel entering hazardous ar eas must be equipped with safety devices such as guardrails, protective enclosures, or other suitable barriers to ensure their safety. " During the automated operation of industrial robots, operators and nearby personnel may be injured by contact with the robot. To prevent injuries to people and damage to equipmen t during robotic operations, be sure to install safety switches or implement appropriate protective measures. (1) The safety fence should be sufficient to ensure the robot’s maximu m working space, ensuring that it does not interfere with the surrounding environment—even after the necessary fixtures are installed and the workpiece is securely clamped. (2) The  entrances and exits of safety fences should be minimized. Whenever possible, only one should remain open in principle, and a lockable security gate must be installed to prevent un authorized personnel from entering freely and avoid potential personal injuries. (3) The scope of the safety fence can be referenced in Figure 2.14, while the robot's operational r ange is shown in Figure 2.8. As for the fixture and workpiece, they will be determined based on the customer's specific requirements. 2.5.2 Installation Environment The installatio n environment is critical to the robot's performance. The installation environment is as follows: (1) The flatness deviation of the mounting surface should be controlled within 0.5 mm; (2) Installation temperature should be between 0°C and 45°C; (3) Install in an environment with humidity levels between 20% and 80%, ensuring no condensation occurs; (4) The installation altitude should not exceed 1000 meters; (5) The pollution category is Class III; (6) Areas free of flammable or corrosive liquids or gases; (7) Stay away from locations with strong sources of electrical noise; (8) Locations without significant impact or vibration. 2.5.3 Robot Installation and Fixing Dimensions A: Flange installation dimensions, see Figure 2.17 B: Attachment equipment installation area I, see Figure 2.18 C: Attachment Equipment Installation Area II, see Figure 2.19 D: Attachment equipment installation area III, see Figure 2.20 E: Attachment equipment installation area IV, see Figure 2.21 F: Robot base mounting dimensions, see Figure 2.22 2.5.4 Robot Installation Practice The robot base should be securely fastened to the mounting holes on the baseplate using 4 M16 screws; if necessary, please install additional positioning bolts. If you plan to mount the robot upside down or on a wall, ensure that the ceiling or wall can support its weight adequately. If the load-bearing capacity is insufficient, take appropriate precautions in advance to prevent the robot from falling, which could result in personal injury or equipment damage. For detailed installation dimensions of the robot base, refer to Figure 2.22. Mount the robot onto the mounting base, ensuring the base has sufficient strength and that the contact surface with the ground is perfectly flat—free of any protrusions or cracks. During installation, prioritize personal safety to prevent the robot from tipping over. When installing robots in inverted or side-mounted configurations, secure them with screws, and if necessary, add positioning bolts and anti-fall devices to further enhance safety. Additionally, during handling, lifting, or installation, never apply excessive force to the robot's forearm or wrist, as this could lead to damage due to overexertion. Finally, always prioritize your own safety when performing installation or removal tasks for side-mounted or inverted robots—take care to avoid injuries caused by collisions or pinching. 2.6 Robot-Allowed Payload This section focuses on robot payloads. If the relevant robot, torque, or inertia exceeds the allowable limits, please select a robot with a higher payload capacity, or contact our company for assistance. Please refer to Chapters 2.5.3 and 2.5.4 for the installation dimensions of the robot body. The installation load of the robot's forearm is influenced by the wrist's allowable load capacity, the permitted load torque value, and the allowed inertial torque value—where the permissible load torque can vary depending on the actual load's inertial torque. Wrist load must be strictly kept within the permissible limits. Exceeding the allowed wrist load will cause the robot to malfunction. Table 2.4 specifies allowable load capacities. Please note: The allowable payload refers to the robot's rated load capacity under its standard configuration. Exceeding this value may lead to reduced performance or even damage. If your intended load exceeds this limit, please contact us promptly. We will assess the situation based on your specific operating conditions and implement appropriate measures to effectively mitigate risks and prevent unnecessary losses. 2.7 Electrical Connections The robot body's nameplate number must match the nameplate number on the control cabinet; otherwise, it could lead to inaccuracies in the robot's positioning. The robot body and the control cabinet are connected via a single power and encoder cable. This cable includes the motor’s power lines and the encoder signal wires, with one end split into two heavy-duty connectors that plug directly into the robot body, while the other end merges into a single robust connector designed for connection to the control cabinet. The robot base is equipped with an M8 grounding screw hole for connecting the grounding terminal. Before turning on the control cabinet's power, be sure to ground it securely. Failure to connect a ground wire could result in an electric shock hazard. The robot delivers electrical signals through the base to the forearm and tracheal channel, for use by the end effector. 2.8 Robot External Wiring Conduit Packaging If an external harness needs to be connected when using the robot, please select the wiring method shown in Figure 2.29, or contact our company for assistance. For installation dimensions, refer to Section 2.5.3, "Robot Installation and Fixing Dimensions"; alternatively, you can design your own installation dimensions based on your specific requirements. Additionally, to prevent other operators fr om accidentally reconnecting the power, please hang a  "Do Not Close " warning sign next to the main power switch. 3.2 Comprehensive Overhaul of Main Bolts When tightening and replacing screws, always use a torque wrench to ensure bolts are securely fa stened to the proper torque specification before proceeding with painting and final securing. Additionally, never retighten loose bolts to the specified torque values mentioned abo ve. 3.3 Inspection and Replacement of Lubricants

The lubricant inspection and replacement procedures described in this manual apply to robots installed on the floor. For lubricant  replacement processes specific to side-mounted or inverted robots, please contact our service department. Please measure the concentration of iron powder in the reducer lubricant e very 5,000 hours or once a year. If the test results exceed the standard values, promptly replace the lubricant or the reducer—please contact us for assistance. Required tools: an iron powder concentration meter specifically designed for lubricants (we recommend the OM-810 model, manufactured by Oki Seisakusho, which is tailored for this  purpose), along with a lubrication gun equipped with oil confirmation and counting functions. During maintenance, if redundant lubricant is found leaking from the unit, use a greas e gun to top it up. However, be aware that exceeding the amount of leaked lubricant could lead to oil leaks or even affect the robot's motion trajectory and other issues. After maintenance or refueling, to prevent oil leaks, be sure to wrap sealing tape around the plug at the pipe thread before installation. Table 3.3: Lubricant Usage Replacement Chart It is recommended to use the provided robot positions when performing lubrication replacement or replenishment tasks. Table 3.4 illustrates the robot's orientation during the lubrication process. Table 3.4 Robot Pose To ensure efficiency, robots should be regularly lubricated and thoroughly inspected in accordance with the following guidelines. Mixing different types of lubricants can cause serious damage to the gearbox. When adding oil to the gearbox, never combine oils from different brands or models unless the instructions specifically recommend it. Always use only the type of lubricant specified by the manufacturer. Note: If the amount of oil injected exceeds the amount discharged, the excess oil could cause internal pressure to rise, potentially leading to oil leaks. In this case, after heating the robot, please open the vent to release the pressure and reduce the risk of oil leakage. If improper steps are taken when replenishing the lubricant, the pressure within the lubrication chamber could rise suddenly, potentially damaging sealing components, leading to lubricant leakage and abnormal equipment operation. After refilling or replacing, thoroughly remove any excess oil from the floor and the robot’s surface to prevent workers from slipping and causing accidents. Refilling and replacing J1-type lubricant (see Figure 3.1) (1) Move the robot to the position shown in Figure 3.4, turn off the power, and disconnect the plugs from the oil inlet and oil outlet ports. (Attention: Do not refuel until the drain plug has been removed, as this could lead to motor failure or oil leakage.) (2) Install the oil fill tube and fitting (G 1/4), preparing for both refueling and draining. (3) Use an oiling gun to fill the reservoir through the filling port, ensuring that the amount of oil added equals the amount of oil drained (the drained old oil must be handled properly). Collect and pour into the waste oil tank. Note that the injection pressure must not exceed 0.03 MPa, and the factory air supply must not be used directly as the power source for the oil injection gun. If the amount of oil injected exceeds the amount discharged, you can remove the excess fluid by moving joint J1 and pulling out the plug. (4) Wipe away any excess oil and reattach the plug (G 1/4). Apply Loctite 5699 sealant to the plug’s threads, or wrap sealing tape around them. Refueling and replacing J2 lubricant (see Figure 3.2) (1) Move the robot to the position shown in Figure 3.4, turn off the power, and disconnect the plugs from the oil inlet and oil outlet ports. Attention: Do not refuel until the drain plug has been removed, as failure to do so may result in motor damage or oil leakage. (2) Install the fuel line and fittings (G 1/4), preparing for fuel filling and draining. (3) Use an oiling gun to inject lubricating oil through the filler port, ensuring the amount injected equals the amount discharged (the discharged old oil must be properly collecte d and transferred to the waste oil container). The injection pressure should not exceed 0.03 MPa, and direct use of the factory air supply as the power source for the fueling gun i s strictly prohibited. If the amount of oil injected exceeds the discharge volume, excess oil can be removed by disconnecting the plug and then moving connector J2 to allow the exc ess fluid to drain out. (4) Remove excess oil and install the plug (G 1/4). (Apply Loctite 5699 sealant or wrap sealing tape around the plug threads.)

Lubricant Filling and Replace ment for Type J3 (see Figure 3.3) (1) Move the robot to the position shown in Figure 3.4, turn off the power, and disconnect the plugs from the oil inlet and oil outlet ports. (Att ention: Do not refuel until the drain plug has been removed, as this could lead to motor failure or oil leakage.) (2) Install the oil fill tube and fitting (G 1/4), preparing for b oth refueling and draining. (3) Use an oiling gun to inject lubricating oil through the filling port, ensuring the amount injected equals the amount discharged (the discharged oil  should be collected promptly and directed into the waste oil tank). The injection pressure must not exceed 0.03 MPa, and factory air sources cannot be used directly as the power so urce for the oiling gun. If the amount of oil injected exceeds the discharge volume, excess oil can be removed by disconnecting the plug and then moving connector J3 to allow the s urplus fluid to drain out. (4) Remove excess oil and install the plug (G 1/4). (Apply Loctite 5699 sealant to the plug threads, or wrap sealing tape around them.)

Filling and Repla cing J5-Type Lubricant (see Figure 3.4) (1) Move the robot to the position shown in Figure 3.4, turn off the power, and disconnect the plugs from the oil inlet and oil outlet ports . (Attention: Do not refuel until the drain plug has been removed, as this could lead to motor failure or oil leakage.) (2) Install the oil fill tube and fitting (G 1/4), preparing  for both refueling and draining. (3) Use an oiling gun to inject机油 into the filling port, ensuring the amount injected equals the amount discharged (the discharged oil should be c ollected promptly and poured into the waste oil tank). If the amount of oil injected exceeds the discharge volume, you can remove the plug and then use the movable joint J5 to drain the excess oil. (4) Remove excess oil a nd install the plug (G 1/4). (2) Install the oil fill tube and fitting (G 1/4), preparing for both refueling and draining. Lubrication Oil Filling and Replacement for the Gearbox (see Figure 3.6) (1) Move the robot to the position shown in Figure 3.4, turn off the power, and disconnect the plugs from the oil inlet and oil outlet ports. (Attention: Do not refuel until the drain plug has been removed, as this could lead to motor failure or oil leakage.) (2) Install the oil fill tube and fitting (G 1/4), preparing for both refueling and draining. (3) Use an oiling gun to inject lubricant through the filling port, ensuring the amount injected equals the amount discharged (the discharged old oil must be properly collected into the waste oil tank). The injection pressure should not exceed 0.03 MPa, and factory air supply must not be used directly as the power source for the oiling gun. If the injection volume exceeds the discharge volume, excess oil can be removed by disconnecting the plug and then moving connectors J5 and J6 to allow the surplus fluid to drain out. (4) Remove excess oil and install the plug (G 1/4). (Apply Loctite 5699 sealant to the plug threads, or wrap sealing tape around them.) Steps to release residual pressure in the grease canister:

(1) Open the oil inlet plug on the pressure shaft of the grease can to be emptied, and place a collection bag beneath the outlet to prevent the spilled grease from splashing around. (2) Start the robot, activate its single-axis motion program, and move the single axis to its maximum travel range, ensuring continuous operation for 1 hour under full load and at 100% speed. (3) Stop the robot's running program, return the robot to its home position, and turn off the enable switch on the teach pendant. (4) After confirming safety, remove the plugs from the oil filling ports of each shaft (make sure to apply sealant to the plugs). When removing the plugs, avoid pointing directly at them to prevent high-pressure, high-temperature oil from spraying out and causing injury. (5) After removing, re-tighten the plug 3–5 seconds later, and wipe away any oil residue around the plug with a clean cloth. 3.4 Replace the battery The robot unit's battery should be replaced annually; additionally, the battery should also be promptly replaced whenever the robot triggers an encoder battery alarm. If you need to replace the battery or have any questions, please don’t hesitate to contact us. To avoid zero-point drift, reset the robot to zero before replacing the battery. When installing the cover plate, do not squeeze the cables. Replacement steps: (1) Reset the robot to the zero point and press the emergency stop button—do not disconnect the power supply. (2) Remove the battery sealing plate, then pull out the battery; (3) Remove the old battery; (4) Insert the new battery into the plug, then place it into the battery compartment of the robot base. (5) Reinstall the battery sealing plate; (6) Check for the existence of zero; (7) If you replace the battery while the device is powered off, or if the zero point is lost after replacing the battery, please recalibrate the zero point. If the battery replacement does not reset the value to zero, or if the robot loses its zero reference after battery replacement for any other reason, refer to Section 3.5 for calibration instructions. For information on battery models and specifications, please contact us. 3.5 Zero-point Calibration This section focuses on the robot's zero-point reference position in case of zero-loss scenarios. The robot undergoes mechanical zero-point calibration before leaving the factory. If, due to a malfunction, the robot loses its zero position, it will need to undergo mechanical zero-point recalibration. For zero-point calibration procedures for standard robots HSR-JR615-2000, HSR-JR620-1800, and HSR-JR630-1800, refer to Figure 3.6. Please set the speed to low at the zero-point calibration. During zero-point calibration, please avoid having your hands caught in the robot's moving parts. 4 Fault Handling Robot design must meet the following requirements: In case of an anomaly, it must be able to immediately detect the issue and halt robot operation. Even so, Still prohibited from continuing operation, as the robot remains in danger. Robot malfunctions can be categorized into the following types: (1) Once this malfunction occurs, the robot will be unable to operate until the repair is completed. (2) Once this failure occurs, the robot can continue operating after a certain period of time. (3) If this malfunction occurs, immediately turn off the power supply; afterward, the robot will resume normal operation. (4) Once this failure occurs, the robot can immediately resume operation. (5) Robot malfunctions caused by system-side failures. (6) System-side anomalies caused by robot-side failures. Under conditions (2), (3), and (4), these failures are almost certain to occur again. Moreover, even experienced engineers may find it challenging to easily pinpoint the root cause of faults in complex systems. Therefore, when a malfunction occurs, immediately halt robot operation and notify a professionally trained safety operator, who will take responsibility for identifying the issue and carrying out the necessary repairs. Additionally, these procedures should be incorporated into operational guidelines, establishing a robust implementation mechanism to ensure that corrective measures are effectively put into practice—otherwise, accidents could still arise. When a robot exhibits abnormal movement or operation that isn't caused by the control system, check whether the issue stems from a mechanical failure. To quickly resolve the problem, first identify the situation and pinpoint exactly which component is responsible for the malfunction. Step 1: Which joint is affected by the abnormality? First, it’s important to identify exactly where the anomaly is occurring. If the surface-level abnormality isn’t enough to determine the issue, further inspection should focus on the area emitting the unusual sound, the region experiencing abnormal heat, and any areas with noticeable gaps. Step 2: Which part is the anomaly located in? After identifying the abnormal joint, further investigation is conducted to pinpoint exactly which part is affected. A single phenomenon can often result from the interaction of multiple components. Figure 4.1 illustrates the fault and its underlying causes. Step 3: Until the Invalidated Section After identifying the faulty component, proceed as outlined in Figure 4.3. If the cause remains unclear and it's uncertain how to address the issue, Please contact our company's service department.

4.3.1 Gear Reducer After the reducer is damaged, it may produce vibrations or unusual noises, which could disrupt normal operation, leading to overload, abnormal misalignment, and overheating—potentially even resulting in complete inability to move and causing positional deviations. (1) Check the concentration of iron powder in the reducer lubricant: If the iron powder concentration exceeds 1000 ppm, internal damage may have already occurred. Please regularly test the iron powder concentration in the reducer lubricant every 5,000 operating hours or once a year. When the test results exceed the standard value, promptly replace the lubricant or the reducer itself, and contact our company’s service department for assistance. Check the operating condition of the gearbox: Remove the gearbox, manually turn the input end, and listen for any sticking or unusual noises.

Check the gearbox temperature: If the temperature is 10°C higher than during normal operation, it can generally be determined that the gearbox has failed. (2) Please replace the gearbox. Since replacing the gearbox is a complex procedure, please contact our company’s service department if needed.

4.3.2 Motor Abnormal phenomena such as shaking during pauses or vibrations during operation can be classified as motor malfunctions. Additionally, unusual overheating or strange noises may also occur. Since these symptoms are identical to those seen when the gearbox is damaged, it can be challenging to pinpoint the exact cause. Please inspect all components of both the gearbox and the balance cylinder simultaneously. (1) Check for any unusual noises or overheating, among other things. (2) Please replace the motor. Since replacing the motor is a complex process, please contact our company’s service department if needed. 5 Appendix

5.1 Robot spare parts 5.2 Screw Fastening Instructions During inspection and maintenance, screws should be tightened in a cross pattern using a torque wrench; the tightening torque for the screws must meet the specifications shown in Figure 5.1. Cross Method: As shown in the diagram, first tighten the screw in a cross-shaped pattern. The tightening process should be carried out in multiple stages: apply 30% of the torque during the first tightening; increase to 80% torque for the second tightening; and finally reach 100% torque during the third tightening. Screw installation and precautions:

(1) Obtain the screws as required and inspect their appearance before installation. (2) When tightening screws, make sure to mark them clearly to distinguish between those that have already been tightened and those that remain loose. After tightening, simultaneously mark both the screw and the fastener, as shown in the figure. (3) Washers (spring washers and Belleville washers) should be discarded after being removed twice and replaced with new ones. (4) After repeated use, screws with damaged threads should be discarded. (5) When securing a part with a screw, if the screw gets stuck in the hole and cannot advance further, to prevent the screw from slipping out or breaking, you must first remove that screw and then replace it with another one. Table 5.1 Screw Fastening Torque Note: If the screw fasteners are made of aluminum, tighten them to the torque specified for Grade 8.8. 5.3 Applications of Sealants

(1) Clean and dry the surface to be sealed ① Blow away the dust from the surface to be sealed. ② Degrease the installed sealing surfaces—either by wiping them with a cloth dampened with detergent, or by spraying the detergent directly onto the area. ③ Dry the surface using gas. (2) Apply sealant ① Ensure the installation surface is dry and free of any residual cleaning agents (if present, wipe clean or allow to dry thoroughly). ② Apply the sealant to the surface and wait for it to soften (about 10 minutes). Then, use a scraper to remove the softened sealant. (3) Assembly ① To prevent dust from settling on the sealant surface, components and parts should be installed in place as soon as possible after the sealant is applied. Do not touch the freshly applied sealant; if you notice any damage to the sealant, reapply it immediately. ② After the parts and components are installed, they should be quickly secured with screws and washers to ensure they sit snugly against the surface. ③ Do not use lubricants before applying sealant, as this may cause leaks. Lubrication of the gearbox should be performed at least 1 hour after installation is complete.
